Actaeon (Elk Centaur).biography:
The Actaeon is a rare and solitary protector of woodland creatures. Standing 9 feet tall, it has the arms, torso, and face of a human, but the lower body and antlers of an elk. Covered in a brown, elklike hide, it can blend into forest environments as if invisible.

Actaeons react aggressively to the slaying of woodland creatures or other similar offenses. They often attack with large wooden or bone spears, appearing suddenly from hiding with a 1-5 chance on a 1d6 for surprise.

Once per day, an Actaeon can use a breath weapon that fills a 10' cube. Those caught must save vs. dragon breath or be polymorphed into a normal forest creature such as an owl, squirrel, or deer. A successful save results in a 24-hour transformation.

Actaeons are integral members of the woodland community, often found among creatures such as centaurs and dryads. Their rarity and bravery make them celebrated champions of the forest. They frequently collaborate with druids to safeguard the woodlands, particularly when a serious threat arises.

Some actaeons may possess spellcasting abilities.

Terrain: Forests.

Load: 3,000 cn at full speed; 6,000 cn at half speed.

A failed roll often results in death (for poison) or other severe consequences, though optional rules may instead inflict substantial damage​​​.

Adaptor.biography:
Adaptors are a mysterious and highly intelligent species found across all planes. They are known for their vast knowledge and unique cultural philosophy that prohibits sharing information between planes or with human societies. Adaptors travel extensively, observing civilizations, and exchange information only with their own kind.

These creatures are natural polymorphs, able to transform into any being of human or demihuman size. After exposure to an attack, they can change color as a sign of adaptation. Adaptors rarely stay in one place for more than three days and can shift between planes at will.

Adaptors can alter their physical structure to survive in any environment. Once exposed to a particular magical attack, they become immune to it. For example, if struck by a lightning bolt, they take full or half damage once, but will become immune to electrical attacks afterward. This adaptation lasts for 1d10 turns if not used again.

In combat, adaptors are skilled with swords, attacking twice per round with a +4 attack roll and damage bonus. They may also use advanced devices incomprehensible to others, such as a flame tube, trance inducer, or energy neutralizer, if the DM wishes.

Although they share some traits with doppelgangers, adaptors cannot replicate specific individuals.

Terrain: Anywhere humans are found.

Load: 3,000 cn at full speed; 6,000 cn at half speed.

Aerial Servant (Haoou)*.biography:
Aerial servants, also known as haoou, are humanoid figures composed of roiling fog and have an ominous presence. They are native to the elemental plane of Air and are only found on the Prime Plane when summoned by a cleric using the aerial servant spell.

These beings do not relish being summoned for service and are resentful towards those who bring them to the Prime Plane. Despite this, they do not intentionally misinterpret commands. They are powerful beings who do not engage in combat but are exceptionally skilled at capturing and retrieving objects or creatures as ordered by their summoners.

Only magical weapons or spells can harm them, and they can travel at incredible speeds, often surprising their targets. Their grip is nearly impossible to escape, with a victim's chance of breaking free equal to their Hit Dice or level percentage.

On their home plane, haoou have an empire in regions with few other inhabitants, where they often clash with helions and djinn. They fear creatures and attacks related to the element of earth.

Terrain: Plane of Air; Any.

Load: 5,000 cn at full speed; 10,000 cn at half speed when carrying items or prisoners.

Animal Herd (1 HD).biography:
This set of monster statistics represents most wild grazing creatures, such as caribou, deer, elk, goats, moose, and wild oxen. All but the most inhospitable climates in the world will feature at least one type of herd beast. PCs might target members of a herd to obtain meat. The Hit Dice and damage dealt by these creatures vary depending on their species. Below are some typical herd creatures:

In a typical herd, only one out of every four animals is male; the others are females and young. Males have at least 3 hit points per Hit Die, while females have the standard number of hit points. The young have only 1-4 hit points per Hit Die. If the herd is threatened, the females and young will retreat, while the males stay to defend them.

If a group of 16 or more creatures is attacked, there is a 40% chance they will panic and stampede toward the source of danger, trampling anything in their path for 1d20 points of damage. This action requires no attack roll.

These creatures are typically found in open areas and lightly wooded regions.

Animal Herd (4 HD).biography:
This set of monster statistics represents most wild grazing creatures, such as caribou, deer, elk, goats, moose, and wild oxen. All but the most inhospitable climates in the world will feature at least one type of herd beast. PCs might target members of a herd to obtain meat. The Hit Dice and damage dealt by these creatures vary depending on their species. Below are some typical herd creatures:

In a typical herd, only one out of every four animals is male; the others are females and young. Males have at least 3 hit points per Hit Die, while females have the standard number of hit points. The young have only 1-4 hit points per Hit Die. If the herd is threatened, the females and young will retreat, while the males stay to defend them.

If a group of 16 or more creatures is attacked, there is a 40% chance they will panic and stampede toward the source of danger, trampling anything in their path for 1d20 points of damage. This action requires no attack roll.

These creatures are typically found in open areas and lightly wooded regions.

A failed roll often results in death (for poison) or other severe consequences, though optional rules may instead inflict substantial damage​​​.

Ant, Giant.biography:
Giant ants are large black ants, about 5’-7’ long. Unlike their smaller cousins who live in colonies of thousands, giant ants live in colonies of about [[/r 14d6 #Ant individuals]] individuals, [[/r 10d6 #Gathering food]] of which will be out gathering food at any given time and the remaining [[/r 4d6 #Guarding nest]] will be guarding the nest.

The morale of giant ants that are scavenging is 7, but when defending the nest and the (non-combatant) queen, their morale is 12 and they will fight to the death without any self preservation instinct.

Giant ants are nocturnal omnivores, although they will not normally attack live prey unless they outnumber it greatly. They prefer to scavenge corpses and vegetable matter.

For some reason, giant ants are sometimes attracted to shiny objects, and they will grab them and return them to their lair. They are even known to sometimes dig gold, and there is a 30% chance that their lair will contain 1d10x1,000gp worth of gold nuggets.

Terrain: Any except Arctic.

Ape, Snow.biography:
Snow apes are squat, baboon-like creatures with shaggy white fur, making them difficult to spot in snowy conditions. They are somewhat intelligent, capable of using simple tools like clubs or sharpened bones but unable to comprehend more complex weapons like bows.

These creatures are reclusive and cruel, often using ambush tactics against smaller prey. If cornered or trapped, they fight fiercely with increased morale.

The snow ape uses one arm to wield a weapon and the other to hug its victim. The hug deals 2d6 points of damage each round until the target is freed. Snow apes communicate using a complex sign language and leave messages using stacked rocks and snowballs.

Snow apes are omnivorous and particularly enjoy eating giant insects and red meat but will avoid very large monsters or groups. They live in snowy mountain forests and only seek shelter during severe snowstorms.

Terrain: Arctic, Mountains (cold).

Ape, White.biography:
White apes have lost their color due to many years of living in caves. They are nocturnal herbivores, looking for fruits and vegetables at night.

They do not go out of their way to attack characters; if approached by humans and demi-humans and given a chance to flee, they will do so. But if creatures approach their lair, the apes will threaten the intruders. If their threats are ignored, they will attack. They may throw one stone per round for 1d6 points each.

White apes are not intelligent and are sometimes kept as pets by Neanderthals (cavemen). Normally, in the wild, they live in caves in family groups of 2-8 members.

Terrain: Cavern, Hill, Mountain, Ruin.

Archon (Female).biography:
Archons are incredibly powerful beings of law and good, existing to oppose chaos and evil. They work both directly and indirectly, assisting adventurers in their quests against evil forces. Archons have the bodies of giant eagles with golden-feathered wings. Male archons possess the head, arms, and torso of a giant, muscular man, while females have a dragonlike neck and three heads: two bull's heads and a central human-like head.

In combat, the male archon can wield any human weapon, often using enchanted ones, while the female can either gore with her bull heads for 3d10 damage or breathe a 10' cone of fire for 4d6 damage. They are immune to fire, poison, and 1st-4th level spells of all types.

Archons can cast spells as 12th level clerics and teleport at will. Once per day, they may use a "bolt of purity" to make victims become Lawful and peaceful for 2d6 turns, or create a "sword of flame" that inflicts 4d8 damage. They live in small family units of one mated pair and 1d3 young, and are rarely encountered with their offspring.

Terrain: Any, any Planar.

Load Capacity: 5,000 cn at full speed; 10,000 cn at half speed.

JkdCGgy86cHmajhX.description:
A cleric who chooses to establish a stronghold with the approval of his clerical order is known as a "land-owning cleric." This term is convenient, as a land-owning cleric can still adventure with friends and is not bound to his land.

Advantages: The cleric can advance within his order, receive financial support for building the stronghold, and potentially expand his lands, leading to significant wealth.

Disadvantages: The cleric becomes the primary authority for his order in the area, bearing responsibilities to the local populace that may hinder his ability to travel with old adventuring companions or present him with challenging issues.

When a 9th-level cleric decides to build a stronghold, he must seek permission from a superior, either an official of his order or a local ruler. The ruler should grant the land unless there are past issues; in such cases, the ruler may require a service, like a quest, before approval. The DM will determine if the cleric's order has the authority to grant land based on the campaign's setting.

If the cleric has a clean record, his order may assist with construction costs, typically covering up to 50% of the expenses. The player can design the stronghold, and the DM will assess the costs, deciding what portion the order will fund. Regardless of the financial support, the stronghold remains the cleric's property, and he cannot deny access to order members, nor can he be reassigned against his will.

Once the stronghold is built, a number of lower-level clerics (typically 1d6) will arrive to assist with its clerical functions. These clerics are there to help operate the stronghold, not to join the cleric on adventures. The DM should create each assistant cleric with their own name, personality, background, goals, and abilities.

If the cleric manages his land and serves his order well, he is likely to gain power within the clerical hierarchy, receive additional land, and see an increase in tax income from the growing settlements around his stronghold.
JkdCGgy86cHmajhX.name: Establish Stronghold (C)

Notes:

  • 7, 9, or 11: Number needed to turn successfully.
  • T: Automatic turn; turns 2d6 Hit Dice of undead.
  • D: Automatic destroy; destroys 2d6 Hit Dice of undead.
  • D+: Automatic destroy; destroys 3d6 Hit Dice of undead.
  • D#: Automatic destroy; destroys 4d6 Hit Dice of undead.

Clerics have the divine power to repel or even destroy certain undead creatures, such as skeletons, zombies, and more powerful types. This ability is known as Turn Undead. When encountering these undead beings, the cleric can choose to either engage them in combat with weapons or spells, or attempt to turn them.

To turn undead, the cleric simply announces the intention to do so to the Dungeon Master. No holy symbol or other item is needed unless the DM specifies otherwise. The success of this attempt depends on the cleric’s level and the type of undead faced, as indicated on the Turning Undead table.

If the cleric succeeds, one or more undead creatures will flee or be destroyed immediately, depending on the result. However, a failed attempt means that particular undead creature cannot be turned by the cleric again during the same encounter. Multiple attempts are allowed in future encounters.

Should the attempt succeed, the Dungeon Master rolls to determine how many Hit Dice worth of undead are turned. At least one undead creature will always be affected. A turned undead creature will retreat as far as possible, but it has not been destroyed and may return after some time.

Athach.biography:
Athachs are gigantic humanoid monsters, standing 18 feet tall with a malformed body and a hideous appearance. Their most distinctive feature is a third arm located in the center of their chest, which they use to attack foes.

These creatures are extremely aggressive and unintelligent, often attacking anything they perceive as food. They inhabit hilly, mountainous, or wooded areas, living in small family units. When not hunting, they fight among themselves.

In combat, they bash opponents with heavy objects like tree stumps or stones, and their bite carries a potent poison. Victims of the bite must make a saving throw vs. poison with a -4 penalty or be rendered helpless for 1d6 turns. Although they are aggressive, athachs have a weakness for gems and jewelry and may accept bribes to avoid conflict.

Terrain: Hill, Mountain, Woods.

Baboon, Rock.biography:
Rock baboons are larger and more intelligent versions of normal baboons. They are omnivorous but have a preference for meat, often hunting small herd animals. Although they do not make tools or weapons, they will pick up bones or branches to use as clubs when attacking.

Rock baboons live in packs of up to 30 members, led by a dominant male. They are known for their ferocious nature and aggressive behavior. While they do not go out of their way to attack travelers, they will aggressively defend their territory and attempt to drive away intruders with loud screams and displays of aggression.

These baboons communicate with simple screams to convey warnings and express needs. Although not interested in humans as food, they will defend their hunting grounds if they feel threatened.

Terrain: Hill, Mountain, Open.

Bandits are NPC thieves who have come together to rob others. They typically operate in small groups or larger communities of 3-30 members. Often they send out raiding parties of 2-4 bandits to target travelers.

Bandits use deception, pretending to be ordinary people to surprise their victims. They are also known to set up ambushes, blocking roads with obstacles like fallen trees to force travelers to stop. Once stopped, the bandits attack from hiding, using ranged weapons to rob their victims.

In a bandit's lair, Treasure Type A can be found, but this is not carried by individual bandits. Bandits may be led by an NPC of any human character class, who is one or more levels higher than the bandits. This leader might have greater ambitions beyond robbery, such as organizing a network of bandit gangs for a more nefarious purpose or seeking revenge for an injustice.

Basilisk.biography:
A basilisk is a magical, nonintelligent creature resembling a 10-foot-long lizard with four legs and a crown-like growth on its head. Often referred to as the "king of snakes," it can be of various colors but is usually bright and distinctive.

Basilisks inhabit underground caverns or dense, wild thickets. They have the unique and dangerous ability to petrify any creature they bite or gaze upon, turning them and all their equipment to stone unless a successful saving throw vs. turn to stone is made. If surprised, a character automatically meets the basilisk’s gaze but still gets a saving throw.

Characters fighting a basilisk in melee combat must choose to either avoid its gaze, which imposes a -4 penalty to their attack rolls while granting the basilisk a +2 bonus, or meet its gaze and attack normally but risk petrification each round.

A mirror can be used to avoid direct eye contact, reducing the penalty to attack rolls to -2. If the basilisk sees its own reflection, it must make a saving throw vs. turn to stone or petrify itself!

Basilisks are native to both the Prime Plane and the elemental plane of Earth. On the Plane of Earth, they are creatures made of rock, with their gaze slowing earth-based creatures for 1d6 rounds and burrowing through rock at impressive speeds.

Terrain: Cavern, Woods; Plane of Earth.

Giant bees, also known as "killer bees," are foot-long aggressive insects with a nasty temperament. They will attack anyone within 30 feet of their hive. If a giant bee hits with its sting, the bee dies, but the victim must make a saving throw vs. poison or die.

If the saving throw is successful, the stinger still inflicts 1 point of damage per round as it works its way into the victim unless removed by spending one round pulling it out.

Giant bees prefer building their hives in small caves or underground areas near the surface. There will always be at least 10 bees and a queen in or near the hive. Some bees in the hive may have 1 Hit Die each (XP 13), and the queen bee has 2 Hit Dice (XP 35) and can sting repeatedly without dying.

Giant bees produce magical honey that, if consumed in large quantities (about two pints), has a half-strength potion of healing effect, curing 1d4 points of damage.

Beholder.biography:
A beholder, also known as a “sphere of many eyes,” resembles a large floating ball about 4 feet in diameter, covered with tough, armor-plated skin. It has ten small eyes on stalks atop its body, each with its own unique magical power, and a large central eye positioned on the front, with a toothy mouth below.

The beholder moves by means of a slow, natural flight that cannot be dispelled. It is highly intelligent, cruel, and greedy, and speaks many languages. This creature is typically found alone but may be accompanied by 1d6 young (each with 1/10 normal Hit Dice and eye effects, dealing 1d4 points of bite damage) with a 5% chance.

The central eye of an beholder emits an anti-magic ray, which negates all magical effects within 60 feet in front of it. Magical weapons in this area are treated as non-magical, and spells cast within the area of effect are instantly disrupted. Spells cast from outside the area are ruined when they enter its range. The beholder will turn to face any character who begins spellcasting, disrupting the spell. Once the anti-magic ray is no longer directed at an object or area, magical items and effects return to their normal function.

The anti-magic ray cannot be directed above or below the creature, only straight ahead. As the ray can negate any magic, even that of the smaller eyes, the beholder cannot use its smaller eye powers on targets within this area.

When attacking an beholder, players must declare whether they are aiming at the body, the large central eye, or an eye stalk, each with distinct armor class and hit points:

  • The body has AC 0 and 50 hit points.
  • The central eye has AC 2 and 20 hit points.
  • An eye stalk has AC 7 and can withstand 12 hit points of damage. Damage to eye stalks does not contribute to killing the creature.

Small Eyes and Eyestalks: If an attack hits an eye stalk, the GM should randomly determine which stalk is damaged. A severed eye stalk is rendered nonfunctional, but partial damage does not impede its operation. Lost eyes regenerate in 2d4 days, and partially damaged stalks heal at a rate of 1 hit point per day.

The beholder can only direct four small eyes in one direction at a time and cannot target directly beneath its body. Each eye can fire a ray with a different spell-like effect once per round. The spell effects are detailed below, with reversed versions indicated by an asterisk.

Eye Powers:

  1. Charm Person (range 120')
  2. Charm Monster (range 120')
  3. Sleep (range 240')
  4. Telekinesis (range 120', up to 5,000 cn weight)
  5. Flesh to Stone* (range 120')
  6. Disintegrate (range 60')
  7. Cause Fear* (range 120')
  8. Slow* (range 240')
  9. Cause Serious Wounds* (range 60')

Beholder, Undead*.biography:
An undead beholder is similar in appearance to its living counterpart but is actually a construct created for a specific malevolent purpose. These creatures are never naturally undead; instead, they are crafted for dark deeds. The undead beholder resembles a large floating sphere, about four feet in diameter, covered with tough, armor-plated skin. It has ten small eyes on stalks, each capable of a different magical effect, and a large central eye on the front of its body with a toothy mouth below. The creature moves using natural (non-magical) flight, and it is highly intelligent, capable of speaking many languages. A cleric of 25th level or higher can recognize it as an undead being upon sight.

Undead beholders are immune to normal, silver, and even +1 magical weapons; only a magical weapon of +2 or greater can harm them. They are unaffected by charm, hold, and sleep spells, as well as illusions, death rays, and poison. Their bodies regenerate 3 hit points per round once damaged. If reduced to 0 hit points, they shift into gaseous form and cannot regenerate until resting for 1 hour in complete darkness, after which their regeneration resumes. They often maintain areas of continual darkness around their lairs.

These creatures can assume gaseous form at will. In this state, they lose access to their special abilities but cannot be harmed except by magic that affects air. Their bite inflicts 2d10 points of damage and causes a two-level energy drain, similar to that of a vampire.

The central eye of an undead beholder projects a ray of reflection, bouncing any spell cast at it back to the caster. Similarly, any attempt to turn undead from this direction reflects back onto the cleric, who must succeed in a saving throw vs. spells or flee in terror for 2d6 rounds. The creature will typically turn to face any spellcasting character to utilize this defense. This reflective ray only works in the front arc and cannot be directed above or behind the creature.

When attacking, the player must specify whether they are targeting the body, the large eye, or an eye stalk. Each part has different armor classes and hit points:

  • The body has AC -4 and 90 hit points.
  • The central eye has AC -2 and 30 hit points.
  • Each eye stalk has AC 3 and can withstand 20 hit points of damage. Damage to the eye stalks does not count toward destroying the creature.

Small eyes and eyestalks: Each small eye can be used once per round, and only three eyes can focus in one direction (forward, backward, etc.). If the target is above the creature, all ten eyes can be used. The Undead beholder often uses only two eyes per round unless it perceives a serious threat. If an eye is destroyed, it can regrow in 1d4 + 1 hours, although this regeneration is slower than that of the body.

Eye Powers:

  1. Animate Dead (range 60')
  2. Charm (as vampire, 120' range, with a -2 penalty to the saving throw)
  3. Continual Darkness (range 120')
  4. Death Spell (range 120')
  5. Energy Drain (1 level, as wight)
  6. Energy Drain (2 levels, as spectre)
  7. Paralysis (as ghoul, range 60'; elves are immune to this ray)
  8. Animate Object (range 60')
  9. Dispel Magic (26th level)
  10. Telekinesis (4,000 cn)

Terrain: Cavern, Ruins.

Berserker.biography:
Berserkers are fierce fighters who enter a state of mad rage during battle. Hailing from barbarian cultures, typically northern seafaring communities, they are known for their ferocity in combat. When in battle, berserkers add +2 to their attack rolls against humans or humanoid creatures like kobolds, goblins, and orcs.

Berserkers fight to the death and may even turn on their comrades in their rage. They never retreat, surrender, or take prisoners. In a village of their culture, 10% of all fighters will be berserkers, and some societies may have entire warrior classes consisting of berserkers.

X62ehUQ8NdQiZ3JT.description:
A character on foot armed with a spear, pike, sword, shield, or lance can set the weapon against a charge. A charge occurs when a monster rushes towards the character, covering at least 20 yards before attacking. This maneuver can also be used against another character's lance attack.

To "set vs. charge," the character braces the weapon against the ground, pointing it at the approaching enemy. Strength and magic bonuses apply to both the attack and damage rolls. If the attack is successful, the character deals double damage, with adjustments applied after doubling.

The character must declare the set vs. charge maneuver before entering melee combat with the charging opponent. For example, if the character’s party wins initiative and expects a charge, they can declare this maneuver. Similarly, if charging monsters are spotted several rounds in advance, the character can set their weapon against the charge ahead of time.

Typically, the attack is made during the monster's movement phase, as soon as it comes within weapon range. If the attack succeeds and kills the monster, it prevents the creature from attacking. If the attack does not kill the monster, it can then attack during its own melee phase of the combat sequence.
X62ehUQ8NdQiZ3JT.name: Set Spear vs. Charge

Black Pudding*.biography:
A black pudding is a nonintelligent black blob, ranging from 5 to 30 feet in diameter. These creatures are always hungry and will attack any living being they encounter. Their corrosive touch deals 3d8 points of damage to living creatures and can dissolve wood and corrode metal within one turn. They cannot damage stone.

Black puddings can travel on ceilings and walls and can pass through small openings, though this is a slow process that may take a full turn or longer. They are immune to all non-fire attacks; any weapon or spell that hits a black pudding will split it into smaller puddings, each with 2 Hit Dice and dealing 1d8 damage. Only fire-based attacks, such as a flaming sword, can deal full damage to a black pudding.

Though they usually have no treasure, gems might be found nearby—leftovers from previous victims.

Terrain: Cavern, Ruins.

Blast Spore.biography:
A Blast Spore closely resembles a dangerous floating creature known as an Orb Guardian. However, it is actually a type of airborne fungus. In dim light, a Blast Spore is often mistaken for an Orb Guardian, with only a 10% chance to discern its true nature (roll 1-10 on a d100). When characters come within 10 feet, the chance of detection improves to 25%.

If a Blast Spore sustains any damage, it detonates violently, dealing 6d6 points of damage to all creatures within a 20-foot radius. Affected targets can make a saving throw vs. wands to halve the damage. This explosion does not release spores as its usual attack does.

When threatened, the Blast Spore may release a cloud of spores in a 20-foot cube around it. Each creature in this area must make a saving throw vs. poison. Failure means the spores take root, and within 24 hours, the victim will spawn 1d6 new Blast Spores, leading to certain death unless cured by a cure disease spell.

Terrain: Caverns, Ruins.

Blink Dog.biography:
This small, brown-furred canine with large jaws has a rugged appearance and is far from a typical animal. It possesses high intelligence, often travels in packs, and has a unique teleportation ability. The creature can "blink out" of one location and instantly "blink in" at another. Its instincts ensure it never reappears inside a solid object.

In combat, it uses this ability to teleport near an enemy, bite, and then vanish, reappearing 10 to 40 feet away. If the pack feels severely threatened, they will all blink away together and may not return.

Though as intelligent as many humans, these creatures communicate only among themselves and do not speak human or demihuman languages. They are solitary by nature, similar to wolves, and generally avoid conflict unless their territory is invaded. They feed on large game like wild elk, moose, and other herd animals.

Blink Dogs have a deep-seated enmity towards phantasmal panthers, whom they consider natural enemies. It is believed that both creatures originate from another plane of existence.

Terrain: Open, Woods, Desert.

Bugbear.biography:
Bugbears are large, hairy goblinoids, standing about 8 feet tall and covered in coarse, dark fur. Despite their imposing size and somewhat lumbering gait, they are exceptionally stealthy, able to move with surprising quietness. This allows them to launch sudden, unexpected assaults, surprising opponents on a roll of 1-3 on 1d6. Their formidable strength grants them a +1 bonus to both hit and damage rolls when wielding weapons.

In the wild, bugbears live in small communities of 5 to 20 members and form hunting parties of 2 to 16 fighters. They hunt herd animals and frequently raid farms, targeting grain stores and smokehouses. During desperate times, they may even turn to hunting humans for sustenance. Despite their brutish appearance, bugbears possess cunning intelligence. They craft their own rudimentary weapons, such as knives, clubs, and spears, but are more than capable of using superior arms stolen from human settlements.

Occasionally, bugbears can also be found with spellcasters among their ranks. For more information, refer to the section on "Monster Spellcasters."

Terrain: Cavern, Hill, Mountain, Woods.

Caecilia.biography:
This massive gray, worm-like creature stretches up to 30 feet in length and is a voracious carnivore that can be found in almost any environment. Caecilia often lie hidden just beneath the surface of loose soil, waiting to ambush unsuspecting animals or humans. When prey comes close, they burst out of the ground, attacking with their large mouths and sharp teeth.

If a Caecilia rolls a natural 19 or 20 on its attack, it swallows its victim whole. A swallowed creature suffers 1d8 points of damage each round until either the victim or the Caecilia perishes.

Terrain: Any except Arctic

Camel.biography:
Camels are notoriously ill-tempered creatures, prone to biting or kicking at any creature that annoys them, including their own handlers. They typically kick with a single leg. Despite their temperament, camels are widely used as pack and riding animals in deserts and barren lands, where they can move with ease as if traversing clear terrain. A well-hydrated camel can travel for up to two weeks without drinking. While primarily herbivores that feed on grasses and grains, camels will resort to eating animal skin and bones when food is scarce.

A camel with a single hump is known as a dromedary, while those with two humps are called Bactrian camels.

Terrain: Barren Lands (Bactrian), Desert (dromedary).
Load: 3,000 cn at normal speed; 6,000 cn at half speed.
Barding Multiplier: x1.

Carrion Crawler.biography:
This scavenger, known as a Carrion Crawler, is a 9-foot-long, 3-foot-high, many-legged creature. It can move effortlessly across floors, walls, and ceilings. Its small mouth is surrounded by eight 2-foot-long tentacles, which can paralyze a victim upon a successful hit unless a saving throw vs. paralysis is made. The tentacles themselves do not inflict any damage.

Carrion Crawlers are notorious scavengers, typically feeding on the remains of dead animals. However, they will eagerly pursue fresh prey if the opportunity arises. They often attack small groups of travelers, paralyzing their victims and consuming them within three turns unless interrupted. The paralysis will naturally wear off in 2d4 turns unless cured magically.

Terrain: Cavern, Ruins.

Centaur.biography:
A centaur is a creature with the head, arms, and upper body of a man joined to the body and legs of a horse. They are of average human intelligence and often carry weapons (clubs, lances, and bows; one weapon per creature). A centaur may use a charge attack with a lance.

Centaurs will form into small tribes or families. Their homes are in dense thickets or woods. The females and young will usually stay in the lair. If attacked, females and young will attempt to flee; if escape is impossible, they will fight to the death. The young fight as 2-HD monsters and do less damage (1d2/1d2/1d4).

There can be centaur spellcasters; see "Monster Spellcasters."

Centipede, Giant.biography:
A giant centipede is a foot-long insect with many legs. They prefer dark, damp places and are often found in dungeons or on the boles and branches of trees in deep forests. They do not commonly attack travelers but will usually attack someone who disturbs them.

They attack by biting. The bite does no damage to characters, but the victim must make a saving throw vs. poison or become violently ill for 10 days. Characters who do not make their saving throws move at half speed and will not be able to perform any other physical action. The bite is more effective against very small creatures, such as the birds and insects they eat; such creatures must save vs. poison or die.

Terrain: Cavern, Ruins, Woods.

Chimera.biography:
A chimera is a fearsome and terrifying creature, a mix of three beasts: a lion, a goat, and a dragon. Its body is a combination of these creatures, with the forequarters of a lion, hindquarters of a goat, and wings and tail of a dragon. It possesses three heads, each of which serves a different purpose in battle.

The chimera is a highly territorial and solitary beast, rarely seen in the company of others. It typically dwells in wild hills but can sometimes be found in deep dungeons or ruins. In some instances, chimeras are known to mate and live with their young in a small family group.

In combat, the chimera attacks fiercely with its multiple heads: the goat's head attempts to butt its foes, the lion’s head bites with deadly force, and the dragon’s head can either bite or unleash a fiery breath weapon. The dragon head’s breath attack is a cone of fire that extends 50 feet long and 10 feet wide at the far end, dealing 3d6 damage. It can breathe fire up to three times per day. In combat, there is a 50% chance each round that the chimera will use its breath attack if it has uses left.

Occasionally, a chimera will become rogue, attacking any nearby human settlements and attempting to drive all life from the area. These rogue chimeras are even more dangerous, as they will not stop their rampage until they are killed or their territory is completely empty of life.

Terrain: Cavern, Hill, Mountain, Ruins.
Load: 4,500 cn at full speed, 9,000 cn at half speed.
Barding Multiplier: x 3.

Cockatrice.biography:
The Cockatrice is a magical monster with the head, wings, and legs of a rooster and the tail of a snake. Its beak attack causes 1d6 points of damage. Any creature bitten or touched by a Cockatrice must make a saving throw or be turned to stone. Cockatrices may be found anywhere.

On the Plane of Earth, a Cockatrice is a foot-long birdlike creature made of soft earth. It is nearly harmless, able to inflict only 1 point of damage with a beak attack. Its touch can still petrify a creature not made of earth (the saving throw still applies). Cockatrices breed normally on their own plane.

Terrain: Any.

Cyclops.biography:
A cyclops (plural: cyclopes) is a rare type of giant, noted for its great size and the single eye in the center of its forehead. A cyclops is about 20' tall. It has poor depth perception because of its single eye, and it strikes with a penalty of -2 on all attack rolls. A cyclops will usually fight with a wooden club and can throw rocks to a 200' range (60/130/200), each hit causing 3d6 points of damage.

Some cyclopes (5%) are able to cast a curse once a week. The DM should decide the exact nature of the curse. Cyclopes are usually solitary but may sometimes share a large cave with a small group. They are known for their stupidity, and a clever party can often escape from them by trickery.

Terrain: Hill, Mountain.

Displacer Beast.biography:
The displacer beast resembles a large black feline with six legs and a pair of 6-foot long tentacles protruding from its shoulders. It uses these tentacles, which are edged with horn-like tips, to attack. The displacer beast's skin has a peculiar ability to bend light, causing it to appear several feet away from its actual position. This grants all attackers a -2 penalty to their attack rolls, while the Panther receives a +2 bonus to all saving throws.

If severely wounded (6 hit points or less), the displacer beast will resort to a ferocious bite attack, gaining a +2 bonus to hit and dealing 1d6 points of damage.

Displacer beasts are carnivorous, preying primarily on smaller herd animals in forested and jungle regions. They may occasionally wander into dungeons due to curiosity or the lure of food. They generally avoid conflict with adventurers unless driven by extreme hunger.

These creatures harbor an intense animosity towards Blink Hounds, attacking them and anyone in their vicinity on sight. It is believed that the two species originate from a distant plane and are embroiled in an endless interdimensional war.

Terrain: Hill, Jungle, Woods.

Djinni, Greater; Pasha*.biography:
Pashas are the rulers of the djinn on the elemental plane of Air. They appear as very large djinn and are immune to non-magical weapons or weapons with less than +2 enchantment. Pashas regenerate 3 hit points per round and can perform all the abilities of a normal djinni as often as desired, up to once per round. Additionally, they can enter or leave the Ethereal Plane by concentrating for 1 full round.

Pashas have special powers usable once per day, including granting another's wish, casting cloudkill, water to gas, and weather control. When in their whirlwind form, which they can assume or leave in a single round, they stand 120 feet tall and 40 feet in diameter at the top. This form deals 3d12 damage to all in its path and slays any creature with fewer than 5 Hit Dice unless the victim makes a saving throw vs. death ray.

Pashas cannot be summoned by spells and are influenced by very few magical items. They appear on the Prime Plane only when a mistreated djinni cries out for aid.

Terrain: Plane of Air, Desert.

Load: 10,000 cn at full speed; 20,000 cn at half speed. When walking, they can carry double these amounts.

Djinni, Lesser*.biography:
Djinn are intelligent, free-willed enchanted creatures from the elemental plane of Air. They appear as tall, humanlike beings, with equal chances of being male or female. Despite their Chaotic alignment, they are generally good-hearted and often use their powers to aid others.

Djinn are highly magical in nature and can only be harmed by magic or magical weapons. Each djinni has seven unique powers that they can use three times per day:

  • Create food and drink (as a 7th-level cleric).
  • Create metallic objects up to 1,000 cn in weight (temporary: gold lasts 1 day, iron lasts 1 round).
  • Create soft goods and wooden objects up to 1,000 cn in weight (permanent).
  • Become invisible.
  • Assume gaseous form.
  • Form a whirlwind.
  • Create illusions affecting sight and hearing (lasts until touched or dispelled).

A djinni can attack with a powerful fist or transform into a whirlwind that deals 2d6 damage to all in its path. The transformation takes five rounds, and the whirlwind can sweep away creatures with fewer than 2 HD unless they make a saving throw vs. death ray. If a djinni is slain, its spirit returns to its own plane.

Djinn dislike being enslaved by magic-users and view them with suspicion. On their own plane, they are immune to normal weapons, all 1st-level spells, and attacks based on water. They can also detect invisible creatures at will.

Terrain: Plane of Air, Desert (preferred).

Load: A djinni can carry 3,500 cn of weight at full speed or 7,000 cn at half speed. In times of great need, it can carry up to 12,000 cn for a short duration but must rest afterward.

Dogs are carnivores and hunt in packs. Though they prefer wilderness, they may occasionally be found in caves. If three or fewer dogs are encountered, or if the pack is reduced to less than 50% of its original numbers, their morale is 6 rather than 8.

Dog, War.biography:
These are actually normal dogs trained, and by breeding programs enhanced. Generally large mastiffs or wolfhounds, they have keen senses of smell and hearing, making them adept at detecting intruders. Most war dogs are not usually vicious, and will rarely attack without cause. The status of war dogs varies greatly; some are loyal and beloved pets, some are watch dogs, others are hunting dogs, and some are trained for battle. Selected for their size and ferocity and trained for combat, they are loyal to their master/trainer and will attack on command. They are typically protected by light, leather armor (AV1 or 2) or other and a spiked collar. The number appearing depends on the owner.

Terrain: Any.

Load: 200 to 1000 cn max, depending on breed.

Dolphin.biography:
Dolphins are seagoing mammals closely related to whales but much smaller in size, typically around 10 feet long. With smooth hides, they are highly intelligent and known for their high-pitched language. Dolphins cannot breathe underwater and must surface every 15 minutes to breathe air.

They can communicate telepathically with other dolphins within a 50-mile radius and can detect magic underwater up to 360 feet. Dolphins despise sharks and may attack them, but they are generally friendly to sailors and have been known to assist people in need. Mermen sometimes ride dolphins as mounts, and they can even be harnessed to chariots by fantastical sea beings.

**Terrain:** Ocean.

**Load:** Can carry 1,500 cn at full speed or 3,000 cn at half speed.

Doppleganger.biography:
Dopplegangers are man-sized shape-changing creatures known for their intelligence and malevolent nature. They can transform into the exact form of any human, demihuman, or humanoid they see (up to 7 feet tall). After assuming the form of their target, they aim to kill the original person and take their place, often using stealth and deception to avoid alerting others.

Once in disguise, they attack the group from within, often when the party is already engaged in combat. Dopplegangers are immune to sleep and charm spells and save as 8th-level fighters due to their magical resilience. Upon death, they revert to their natural form—a hairless, genderless humanoid with pale, rubbery skin.

Dopplegangers can establish a limited telepathic link with their intended victim, quickly learning everything their target knows. However, they cannot use memorized spells of spellcasting victims. Spellcaster Dopplegangers are rare but can cast spells in any form they take.

Dragon, Black (Huge).biography:
The Huge Black Dragon is a menacing and vile creature that rules over swampy areas and marshes with fear. It can spew a line of corrosive acid up to 120 feet long and 5 feet wide, capable of melting armor and flesh alike. With its increased intelligence and magical abilities, this dragon is a formidable foe both on the ground and in the air.

Types of Physical Attacks

Dragons usually make two claw attacks and one bite attack; at the OM's option, they can use other special attack forms (kick, tail, wing) defined later. When a flying dragon attacks an aerial target, it gets two claw attacks and one bite attack but cannot use wing, kick, or tail attacks. When attacking a ground-level victim from the air, a dragon can use one Crush, Hover, or Swoop attack (as described below), but not two in combination.

If a dragon attacks while on the ground, it can substitute a wing, kick, or tail attack for any of its normal attacks, so long as it makes only three attacks in the round. (For example, the dragon might bite one target, kick another, and sweep its tail across a third instead of using two claws and one bite.)

Combat Tactics

Huge dragons use all attacks effectively against any opponent within melee range through maneuvering. Wing attacks can be aimed at any opponents to the sides, or, if more than one opponent is in front of the dragon, against those on either side. If its swoop attack hits, a huge dragon can pick up one, two, or three man-sized victims, two horse-sized victims, or one giant-sized opponent.

Large and huge dragons use breath weapons intelligently, not randomly. They rarely aim at single opponents and normally save the attack for use against groups. The volume of the breath weapon increases with the size of the dragon.

Breath Weapon: Acid, 120 feet long and 5 feet wide, dealing damage equal to the dragon's current hit points.

Terrain: Swamps, Marshes

Load: A dragon can move at its full speed when carrying 1,000 times its Hit Dice; or at half speed when carrying 2,000 times its Hit Dice.

Barding Multiplier: This varies depending on size: Small Dragon x 3, Large Dragon x 5, Huge Dragon x 10.

When a dragon swoops. its victims suffer a -1 penalty to their surprise roll, because of the creature's silent glide. If the dragon surprises the victim, each hit inflicts double damage.

Dragon, Black (Small).biography:
The Small Black Dragon is a sinister predator of swamps and marshes. Known for its vicious acid breath, it can unleash a deadly line of acid 60 feet long and 5 feet wide. Despite being one of the smaller black dragons, its cunning and evil intelligence make it a dangerous adversary. It can also cast spells, adding a magical element to its physical and breath attacks.

Types of Physical Attacks

Dragons usually make two claw attacks and one bite attack; at the OM's option, they can use other special attack forms (kick, tail, wing) defined later. When a flying dragon attacks an aerial target, it gets two claw attacks and one bite attack but cannot use wing, kick, or tail attacks. When attacking a ground-level victim from the air, a dragon can use one Crush, Hover, or Swoop attack (as described below), but not two in combination.

If a dragon attacks while on the ground, it can substitute a wing, kick, or tail attack for any of its normal attacks, so long as it makes only three attacks in the round. (For example, the dragon might bite one target, kick another, and sweep its tail across a third instead of using two claws and one bite.)

Combat Tactics

Small dragons normally attack with claws and bite when on the ground, without using kicks or tail attacks. Their legs are too short for effective kicking unless an opponent is close behind them. They are not proficient in attacking with the tail (though it may be used to inflict damage only, at the DM's choice). If its swoop attack hits, a small dragon can pick up one man-sized opponent.

Breath Weapon: Acid, 60 feet long and 5 feet wide, dealing damage equal to the dragon's current hit points.

Terrain: Swamps, Marshes

Load: A dragon can move at its full speed when carrying 1,000 times its Hit Dice; or at half speed when carrying 2,000 times its Hit Dice.

Barding Multiplier: This varies depending on size: Small Dragon x 3, Large Dragon x 5, Huge Dragon x 10.

Dragon, Blue (Huge).biography:
The Huge Blue Dragon is a force of nature, dominating the skies and land with its immense size and power. It unleashes a devastating lightning breath weapon, which strikes in a line 200 feet long and 5 feet wide, capable of annihilating anything in its path. The Huge Blue Dragon's intellect and mastery of magic make it a cunning and dangerous adversary. Its ability to cast spells only adds to the threat it poses, both in the air and on the ground.

Types of Physical Attacks

Dragons usually make two claw attacks and one bite attack; at the OM's option, they can use other special attack forms (kick, tail, wing) defined later. When a flying dragon attacks an aerial target, it gets two claw attacks and one bite attack but cannot use wing, kick, or tail attacks. When attacking a ground-level victim from the air, a dragon can use one Crush, Hover, or Swoop attack (as described below), but not two in combination.

If a dragon attacks while on the ground, it can substitute a wing, kick, or tail attack for any of its normal attacks, so long as it makes only three attacks in the round. (For example, the dragon might bite one target, kick another, and sweep its tail across a third instead of using two claws and one bite.)

Combat Tactics

Huge dragons use all attacks effectively against any opponent within melee range through maneuvering. Wing attacks can be aimed at any opponents to the sides, or, if more than one opponent is in front of the dragon, against those on either side. If its swoop attack hits, a huge dragon can pick up one, two, or three man-sized victims, two horse-sized victims, or one giant-sized opponent.

Large and huge dragons use breath weapons intelligently, not randomly. They rarely aim at single opponents and normally save the attack for use against groups. The volume of the breath weapon increases with the size of the dragon.

Breath Weapon: Lightning, 200 feet long and 5 feet wide, dealing damage equal to the dragon's current hit points.

Dragon, Blue (Small).biography:
The Small Blue Dragon is a fearsome predator of arid and desert regions, known for its destructive lightning breath weapon. It attacks by unleashing a bolt of lightning in a straight line, 100 feet long and 5 feet wide, which can deal significant damage to anything in its path. While it is one of the smaller blue dragons, it is no less dangerous, and it has some spellcasting ability to complement its physical and breath weapon attacks.

Types of Physical Attacks

Dragons usually make two claw attacks and one bite attack; at the OM's option, they can use other special attack forms (kick, tail, wing) defined later. When a flying dragon attacks an aerial target, it gets two claw attacks and one bite attack but cannot use wing, kick, or tail attacks. When attacking a ground-level victim from the air, a dragon can use one Crush, Hover, or Swoop attack (as described below), but not two in combination.

If a dragon attacks while on the ground, it can substitute a wing, kick, or tail attack for any of its normal attacks, so long as it makes only three attacks in the round. (For example, the dragon might bite one target, kick another, and sweep its tail across a third instead of using two claws and one bite.)

Combat Tactics

Small dragons normally attack with claws and bite when on the ground, without using kicks or tail attacks. Their legs are too short for effective kicking unless an opponent is close behind them. They are not proficient in attacking with the tail (though it may be used to inflict damage only, at the DM's choice). If its swoop attack hits, a small dragon can pick up one man-sized opponent.

Dragon, Gold (Small).biography:
The Small Gold Dragon is known for its dual breath weapon capabilities, allowing it to breathe either fire or chlorine gas. Its fire breath forms a cone that stretches 90 feet long and 30 feet wide, while its chlorine gas forms a cloud 50 feet wide, 40 feet deep, and 30 feet high. Both breath weapons deal damage equal to the dragon's current hit point value. Gold dragons are highly intelligent and often align with lawful causes, using both their might and magic in battle.

Types of Physical Attacks

Dragons usually make two claw attacks and one bite attack; at the OM's option, they can use other special attack forms (kick, tail, wing) defined later. When a flying dragon attacks an aerial target, it gets two claw attacks and one bite attack but cannot use wing, kick, or tail attacks. When attacking a ground-level victim from the air, a dragon can use one Crush, Hover, or Swoop attack (as described below), but not two in combination.

If a dragon attacks while on the ground, it can substitute a wing, kick, or tail attack for any of its normal attacks, so long as it makes only three attacks in the round. (For example, the dragon might bite one target, kick another, and sweep its tail across a third instead of using two claws and one bite.)

Combat Tactics

Small dragons normally attack with claws and bite when on the ground, without using kicks or tail attacks. Their legs are too short for effective kicking unless an opponent is close behind them. They are not proficient in attacking with the tail (though it may be used to inflict damage only, at the DM's choice). If its swoop attack hits, a small dragon can pick up one man-sized opponent.

Breath Weapon: Either Fire (90 feet long, 30 feet wide) or Chlorine gas (50 feet wide, 40 feet deep, 30 feet high), dealing damage equal to the dragon's current hit points.

Terrain: Mountains, Caves

Load: A dragon can move at its full speed when carrying 1,000 times its Hit Dice; or at half speed when carrying 2,000 times its Hit Dice.

Barding Multiplier: This varies depending on size: Small Dragon x 3, Large Dragon x 5, Huge Dragon x 10.

This massive dragon's breath attack creates a cloud 50 feet wide, 50 feet deep, and 30 feet high, dealing damage equal to the dragon's current hit point value. The Huge Green Dragon is highly intelligent and magically potent, capable of casting spells in addition to its formidable physical abilities.

Dragon, Red (Huge).biography:
The Huge Red Dragon is a terrifyingly powerful force of destruction. Its fiery breath can engulf entire groups of foes in a devastating cone of fire, stretching 180 feet long and 30 feet wide. As one of the largest and most intelligent dragons, the Huge Red Dragon is not only deadly in combat but also possesses powerful magical abilities, making it a fearsome enemy on the battlefield.

Types of Physical Attacks

Dragons usually make two claw attacks and one bite attack; at the OM's option, they can use other special attack forms (kick, tail, wing) defined later. When a flying dragon attacks an aerial target, it gets two claw attacks and one bite attack but cannot use wing, kick, or tail attacks. When attacking a ground-level victim from the air, a dragon can use one Crush, Hover, or Swoop attack (as described below), but not two in combination.

If a dragon attacks while on the ground, it can substitute a wing, kick, or tail attack for any of its normal attacks, so long as it makes only three attacks in the round. (For example, the dragon might bite one target, kick another, and sweep its tail across a third instead of using two claws and one bite.)

Combat Tactics

Huge dragons use all attacks effectively against any opponent within melee range through maneuvering. Wing attacks can be aimed at any opponents to the sides, or, if more than one opponent is in front of the dragon, against those on either side. If its swoop attack hits, a huge dragon can pick up one, two, or three man-sized victims, two horse-sized victims, or one giant-sized opponent.

Large and huge dragons use breath weapons intelligently, not randomly. They rarely aim at single opponents and normally save the attack for use against groups. The volume of the breath weapon increases with the size of the dragon.

Breath Weapon: Fire, 180 feet long and 30 feet wide, dealing damage equal to the dragon's current hit points.

Terrain: Mountains, Caves

Load: A dragon can move at its full speed when carrying 1,000 times its Hit Dice; or at half speed when carrying 2,000 times its Hit Dice.

Barding Multiplier: This varies depending on size: Small Dragon x 3, Large Dragon x 5, Huge Dragon x 10.

If a dragon attacks while on the ground, it can substitute a wing, kick, or tail attack for any of its normal attacks, so long as it makes only three attacks in the round. (For example, the dragon might bite one target, kick another, and sweep its tail across a third instead of using two claws and one bite.)

Huge dragons use all attacks effectively against any opponent within melee range through maneuvering. Wing attacks can be aimed at any opponents to the sides, or, if more than one opponent is in front of the dragon, against those on either side. If its swoop attack hits, a huge dragon can pick up one, two, or three man-sized victims, two horse-sized victims, or one giant-sized opponent.

Drake, Elemental*.biography:
Elemental Drakes are rare and dangerous creatures that hail from the elemental planes. These drakes can polymorph into young giant forms (up to 4 feet shorter than normal giants) on the Prime Plane, or into small elemental forms on their home plane. In drake form, they attack with claws and a bite, dealing significant damage. Elemental Drakes are immune to normal and silver weapons, requiring magical weapons to harm them. They also possess the abilities of a 5th-level thief, making them cunning foes.

Polymorph: On the Prime Plane, Elemental Drakes can polymorph into young giant forms (cloud, stone, fire, or storm giants), but cannot use giant rock-throwing abilities. On their home plane, they transform into small elemental forms with the abilities of a 6 HD elemental.

Elemental Immunities: Immune to normal and silver weapons; only magical weapons can harm them.

Flight: The drake can fly at a speed of 30 feet per turn, but only for 1 hour at a time.

Terrain: Any

Drolem*.biography:
A Drolem is a type of golem that looks like a dragon. It can be made to resemble any dragon color or may appear as a dragon skeleton. Like other golems, it is not alive, but a construct created by a high-level magic-user or cleric. Drolems are extremely rare, typically built to guard a special item or location. A special book and several rare materials are required to create a Drolem.

A Drolem is nonintelligent and follows instructions exactly. It can see invisible creatures within 60 feet and is immune to:

  • Charm, hold, sleep, and all mind-affecting spells
  • All forms of fire, cold, and gases
  • Spells of 4th level or lower
  • All normal and silver weapons, as well as magical weapons of +2 or lesser enchantment

The Drolem's claws inflict 2d6 points of damage each, and its massive jaws cause 11-30 (1d20 + 10) points of damage. It can also breathe a poisonous cloud up to three times per day. The cloud is 20 feet x 20 feet x 20 feet, and creatures within the area must make a saving throw versus dragon breath or die.

Terrain: Any

Load: 20,000 cn at full speed; 40,000 cn at half speed

Dryad.biography:
Dryads are elusive, beautiful tree spirits inhabiting deep forests. Though peaceful by nature, they are wary of outsiders. If a Dryad wishes to avoid detection, she merges with her tree, becoming part of it. She can cast Charm Person at will, but only uses this power on those who threaten her or on males she finds attractive. Victims of this charm save with a -2 penalty.

Charmed individuals may be sent to deadly ambushes or drawn into her tree. Once inside, victims often disappear unless rescued quickly. Dryads will go to great lengths to protect their trees, as they are bound to them and will die if separated from their tree by more than 240 feet for over a turn. They typically do not carry weapons but may wield a javelin or spear if defending their home.

They store treasures in hidden hollows beneath their tree’s roots. If a Dryad’s tree is threatened, she will often negotiate, releasing any captured individuals rather than risk its destruction.

Terrain: Woods (dense)

Each creature’s breath weapon has specific effects, such as damage, paralysis, or petrification. A successful saving throw generally halves the damage or avoids the secondary effect (such as paralysis or petrification), while failure applies the full consequences. The target number for the saving throw is determined by the character’s class and level.

PUQCqvFMDV1cokUo.description:
A character on foot armed with a spear, pike, sword, shield, or lance can set the weapon against a charge. A charge occurs when a monster rushes towards the character, covering at least 20 yards before attacking. This maneuver can also be used against another character's lance attack.

To "set vs. charge," the character braces the weapon against the ground, pointing it at the approaching enemy. Strength and magic bonuses apply to both the attack and damage rolls. If the attack is successful, the character deals double damage, with adjustments applied after doubling.

The character must declare the set vs. charge maneuver before entering melee combat with the charging opponent. For example, if the character’s party wins initiative and expects a charge, they can declare this maneuver. Similarly, if charging monsters are spotted several rounds in advance, the character can set their weapon against the charge ahead of time.

Typically, the attack is made during the monster's movement phase, as soon as it comes within weapon range. If the attack succeeds and kills the monster, it prevents the creature from attacking. If the attack does not kill the monster, it can then attack during its own melee phase of the combat sequence.
PUQCqvFMDV1cokUo.name: Set Spear vs. Charge

Efreeti (Greater, Amir)*.biography:
On the elemental plane of Fire, the rulers of the efreet are known as amirs. These mighty beings appear as enormous efreet, standing between 15 and 30 feet tall. Unlike lesser efreet, an amir cannot be harmed by normal weapons or even by magical weapons of less than +2 enchantment. They also regenerate 2 hit points per round.

Amirs possess all the abilities of a lesser efreeti and can use them as often as desired, once per round. Additionally, they can enter or leave the Ethereal Plane by concentrating for one full round.

Once per day, an amir can grant another's wish, cast fireball, or unleash an explosive cloud, all as if cast by a 20th-level magic-user.

Amirs can assume a pillar of flame form without limit, igniting all flammable objects within 15 feet. While in this form, their melee attacks deal an additional 2d8 fire damage.

These beings cannot be summoned by spells and are resistant to most magical items. They rarely appear on the Prime Plane, doing so only in response to the cries of mistreated efreeti. When they do, they can appear anywhere but prefer hot environments such as deserts.

Terrain: Plane of Fire

Load: Flies with up to 10,000 cn at full speed or 20,000 cn at half speed. Walks with up to 20,000 cn at full speed or 40,000 cn at half speed.

For example, a fireball cast by a 6th-level caster deals 6d6 (6-36) points of damage. On a successful saving throw, the damage is halved.

sBlqcp8vJLw3Sswf.description:
The Wish spell is the most powerful spell a magic-user can cast. It is never found on scrolls but may be placed in rare magical items, such as rings. Only magic-users of 36th level with a Wisdom score of 18 or greater may cast this spell.

Wording the Wish:

The player must clearly state or write the exact wish. The wording is critically important, as the wish will usually follow the literal meaning of the words spoken—regardless of the caster's intentions.

The DM is responsible for maintaining game balance. Poorly worded wishes may have unintended consequences, while selfish or greedy wishes may be deliberately twisted by the DM. If a wish is unreasonable, the DM may simply rule that it has no effect.

Examples of Faulty Wishes:

  • "I wish that I knew everything about this dungeon." - The character gains full knowledge for a moment but then immediately forgets everything.
  • "I wish for a million gold pieces." - The gold pieces may appear, but they might land on the caster (crushing them) and then vanish.
  • "I wish to permanently gain the gaze power of a basilisk while retaining all my abilities." - This could result in the caster growing an additional basilisk head.

Wish Limitations & Effects:

  • A wish cannot be used to gain experience points or levels.
  • A properly worded wish can substitute for any magic-user spell of 8th level or lower or any clerical or druidic spell of 6th level or lower at the DM’s discretion.
  • If the wish is used to harm a creature, the target may make a saving throw vs. spells. If successful, the effect is halved, and the other half rebounds on the caster (who may save with a -4 penalty).
  • If the wish is used to inconvenience rather than harm (such as teleporting a victim into a prison cell), no saving throw is allowed.

Special Uses of a Wish:

  • A wish can create treasure, up to 50,000 gold pieces. However, the caster loses 1 XP per gold piece gained, and this loss cannot be restored.
  • A wish can temporarily change one ability score to a minimum of 3 or maximum of 18, lasting six turns.
  • Permanent ability score increases require casting a number of wishes equal to the desired score (e.g., raising Strength from 15 to 16 requires 16 wishes within one week).
  • Wishes cannot permanently lower ability scores.

Racial & Class Effects:

  • A wish cannot raise a human character beyond 36th level, but it can grant a demihuman one additional Hit Die (maximum HD: Halflings 9, Elves 11, Dwarves 13).
  • A wish can change a demihuman to a human (or vice versa), allowing them to advance as a new class at the same level.
  • If a wish is used to change another character’s class, the target may make a saving throw vs. spells with a +5 bonus to resist.

Altering Past Events:

A wish can alter events from the past 24 hours. However, it cannot fully overturn impossible odds. Examples include:

  • A lost battle may be changed into a less severe defeat.
  • A character’s death could instead become a near-death experience.
  • A permanent loss may be converted into a temporary one.

Important Note:

If an effect is stated to be unchangeable "even with a wish", this limitation overrides the spell’s normal capabilities.

Game Balance & DM Discretion:

The DM must ensure that wishes remain within reason. A wish cannot alter fundamental game mechanics (such as preventing dragons from using their breath weapons). The more unreasonable a wish is, the less likely it is to succeed as intended.
sBlqcp8vJLw3Sswf.name: Wish
sBlqcp8vJLw3Sswf.spellEffect: Alters reality based on the caster’s wording

Efreeti, Lesser*.biography:
Efreeti are powerful enchanted beings from the elemental plane of Fire. They appear as smoke that condenses into giant-sized humanoids wreathed in flame. The air around them is hot and smoky, and they radiate an aura of menace. Efreeti are highly magical, and can only be harmed by magical weapons. If slain, their spirit returns to the Plane of Fire.

Efreeti can create objects, produce illusions, and turn invisible at will. They can also cast wall of fire up to three times per day. Once per turn, they may transform into a pillar of flame for up to three rounds, setting fire to all flammable items within 5 feet. While in this form, their melee attacks deal an additional 1d8 fire damage.

Summoning an efreeti requires a high-level magic-user with access to both create magical monsters and wish spells. When summoned, the efreeti must serve for 101 days but will seek to twist its master's instructions in ways that cause trouble.

Efreet dwell in grand cities on their home plane, similar to those of wealthy desert-dwelling humans. They despise djinn and will attack them on sight. While generally at peace with fire elementals, they have fought wars against them in the past. Efreet fear water-based creatures and attacks.

Terrain: Plane of Fire

Load: 5,000 cn at full speed, 10,000 cn at half speed

Elemental, Air (Plane of Air)*.biography:
Elementals of the Plane of Air exist in a universe made of endless skies, where they live in massive cloud cities and refer to themselves as "people." They are the dominant race of their plane and rule over thousands of floating worlds composed of air, mist, and vapor.

On their home plane, Air Elementals appear as ever-shifting blobs of wind, able to form and reshape their bodies at will. They can create a number of "arms" equal to their Hit Dice but can only attack once per round.

Their size is based on their Hit Dice, ranging from 1 HD (tiny whirling breeze) to 32 HD (vast storm clouds). They can live up to 35 Hit Dice before aging forces them to weaken and disperse.

Elementals generally distrust creatures from the Prime Plane, recognizing them by their scent. However, if a visitor appears in elemental form, the reaction penalty is reduced.

HD & Scaling: Air Elementals range in strength depending on their age and power:

  • 1-2 HD: AC 5, 1d2 damage, XP 20
  • 3-4 HD: AC 4, 1d4 damage, XP 75
  • 5-6 HD: AC 3, 1d6 damage, XP 275
  • 7-8 HD: AC 2, 1d8 damage, XP 650
  • 9-10 HD: AC 1, 2d6 damage, XP 1,000
  • 11-12 HD: AC 0, 2d8 damage, XP 1,250
  • 13-14 HD: AC -1, 2d10 damage, XP 1,500
  • 15-16 HD: AC -2, 3d8 damage, XP 1,850
  • 17+ HD: Gains more power, beyond standard elementals

Some elementals study magic and become powerful spellcasters, but only after reaching 9 HD or higher.

Terrain: Elemental Plane of Air

Elemental, Earth (Plane of Earth)*.biography:
Elementals of the Plane of Earth live deep within a universe made of endless rock, gemstone, and tunnels. They rule sprawling underground kingdoms of solid stone, where they refer to themselves as "people" and consider themselves the oldest race of all.

On their home plane, Earth Elementals appear as massive shifting forms of stone, able to shape themselves at will. They can form a number of limbs equal to their Hit Dice but can only strike once per round.

Their size is based on their Hit Dice, ranging from 1 HD (small chunk of stone) to 32 HD (massive fortress-sized being). They live up to 35 Hit Dice before they age and crumble apart.

Earth Elementals distrust creatures from the Prime Plane, recognizing them by their unnatural movement. However, if a visitor appears in elemental form, the reaction penalty is reduced.

HD & Scaling: Earth Elementals vary greatly in power:

  • 1-2 HD: AC 5, 1d2 damage, XP 20
  • 3-4 HD: AC 4, 1d4 damage, XP 75
  • 5-6 HD: AC 3, 1d6 damage, XP 275
  • 7-8 HD: AC 2, 1d8 damage, XP 650
  • 9-10 HD: AC 1, 2d6 damage, XP 1,000
  • 11-12 HD: AC 0, 2d8 damage, XP 1,250
  • 13-14 HD: AC -1, 2d10 damage, XP 1,500
  • 15-16 HD: AC -2, 3d8 damage, XP 1,850
  • 17+ HD: Grows larger and stronger, beyond normal elementals

Some Earth Elementals become clerics or magic-users, but only after reaching 9 HD or higher.

Terrain: Elemental Plane of Earth

Elephants are massive, four-legged herbivores that inhabit the edges of sub-tropical forests, living in large herds. Despite their calm nature, they become extremely dangerous when provoked or defending their young.

3NFATWULRaya8kWv.description:
A character on foot armed with a spear, pike, sword, shield, or lance can set the weapon against a charge. A charge occurs when a monster rushes towards the character, covering at least 20 yards before attacking. This maneuver can also be used against another character's lance attack.

To "set vs. charge," the character braces the weapon against the ground, pointing it at the approaching enemy. Strength and magic bonuses apply to both the attack and damage rolls. If the attack is successful, the character deals double damage, with adjustments applied after doubling.

The character must declare the set vs. charge maneuver before entering melee combat with the charging opponent. For example, if the character’s party wins initiative and expects a charge, they can declare this maneuver. Similarly, if charging monsters are spotted several rounds in advance, the character can set their weapon against the charge ahead of time.

Typically, the attack is made during the monster's movement phase, as soon as it comes within weapon range. If the attack succeeds and kills the monster, it prevents the creature from attacking. If the attack does not kill the monster, it can then attack during its own melee phase of the combat sequence.
3NFATWULRaya8kWv.name: Set Spear vs. Charge

Either the Dungeon Master should roll or the roll should be blind, regardless of whether a secret door is present, to maintain player uncertainty. Once found, the location of the secret door can be noted, allowing future discovery without a roll.

yH5ZotWuorzTv0nS.description:
Elves harness arcane energy through natural affinity and careful memorization of spells recorded in their spellbooks. Unlike Clerics, who receive divine magic, Elves must prepare spells in advance by studying their books each day. Once a spell is cast, it is erased from memory until re-memorized.

Elves have a limited selection of spells they can prepare per day, increasing as they gain levels. Their spells range from minor utilities such as Read Magic to devastating attacks like Fireball and reality-warping incantations at higher levels.

Because of their reliance on spellbooks, Elves must protect and expand their libraries, seeking out lost tomes, scrolls, and ancient knowledge to improve their magical repertoire. Unlike Magic-Users, however, Elves also train in combat, allowing them to wield swords and bows while wearing armor without disrupting their spellcasting.

Elf (3 HD).biography:
Elves are woodland humanoids, highly skilled in combat and magic. They use weapons effectively and can cast a 1st-level spell. Elves are often encountered in groups, and when a group of 15 or more appears, one of them will be a leader. This leader may possess magical items.

Weapon Damage: Varies by weapon.
Special: Each elf has access to a 1st-level spell.
Terrain: Forests, Woodlands.
Barding: None

182F4DzYozXPSnTY.description: Elves have infravision, allowing them to see in the dark up to 60 feet. They can perceive creatures and objects based on their temperature difference from the surroundings.
182F4DzYozXPSnTY.name: Infravision (E)

3ExrZ5UmN1sEOZMg.description: The saving throw against Breath Weapons is used to resist or mitigate the effects of a wide range of powerful exhaled attacks, not limited to dragons. This includes attacks like a dragon’s fiery or icy breath, a gorgon's petrifying breath, or a chimera's elemental breath. Each creature’s breath weapon has specific effects, such as damage, paralysis, or petrification. A successful saving throw generally halves the damage or avoids the secondary effect (such as paralysis or petrification), while failure applies the full consequences. The target number for the saving throw is determined by the character’s class and level.
3ExrZ5UmN1sEOZMg.name: Dragon Breath

3NFATWULRaya8kWv.description:
A character on foot armed with a spear, pike, sword, shield, or lance can set the weapon against a charge. A charge occurs when a monster rushes towards the character, covering at least 20 yards before attacking. This maneuver can also be used against another character's lance attack.

To "set vs. charge," the character braces the weapon against the ground, pointing it at the approaching enemy. Strength and magic bonuses apply to both the attack and damage rolls. If the attack is successful, the character deals double damage, with adjustments applied after doubling.

The character must declare the set vs. charge maneuver before entering melee combat with the charging opponent. For example, if the character’s party wins initiative and expects a charge, they can declare this maneuver. Similarly, if charging monsters are spotted several rounds in advance, the character can set their weapon against the charge ahead of time.

Typically, the attack is made during the monster's movement phase, as soon as it comes within weapon range. If the attack succeeds and kills the monster, it prevents the creature from attacking. If the attack does not kill the monster, it can then attack during its own melee phase of the combat sequence.
3NFATWULRaya8kWv.name: Set Spear vs. Charge

EgQeqRpUgpa2gGAE.description:
To detect a secret door, a character must specify the exact area being searched. The process typically takes one turn (10 minutes) for each 10-foot section of wall, floor, or ceiling. Elves, due to their keen sight, are given a bonus of 1 to their roll.
Either the Dungeon Master should roll or the roll should be blind, regardless of whether a secret door is present, to maintain player uncertainty. Once found, the location of the secret door can be noted, allowing future discovery without a roll.
EgQeqRpUgpa2gGAE.name: Detect Secret Door

G6NDxhJH5fd32zRX.description: The saving throw for Spells or Magic Staff includes resistance against magical effects cast by rods, staves, wands, or through spells. A successful save, rolled on a d20, often reduces or negates the spell's effects entirely. This saving throw is applicable to numerous magical attacks, such as charm spells, fireballs, or paralysis effects, and covers damage, control, or debilitating conditions caused by magical devices or spellcasters. The target number for success is based on the character's class and level.
G6NDxhJH5fd32zRX.name: Spells or Magic Staff

Paralysis leaves a character aware but unable to act, while petrification turns the character and their carried equipment into a stone statue. yH5ZotWuorzTv0nS.description:
Elves harness arcane energy through natural affinity and careful memorization of spells recorded in their spellbooks. Unlike Clerics, who receive divine magic, Elves must prepare spells in advance by studying their books each day. Once a spell is cast, it is erased from memory until re-memorized.

Elves have a limited selection of spells they can prepare per day, increasing as they gain levels. Their spells range from minor utilities such as Read Magic to devastating attacks like Fireball and reality-warping incantations at higher levels.

Because of their reliance on spellbooks, Elves must protect and expand their libraries, seeking out lost tomes, scrolls, and ancient knowledge to improve their magical repertoire. Unlike Magic-Users, however, Elves also train in combat, allowing them to wield swords and bows while wearing armor without disrupting their spellcasting.
yH5ZotWuorzTv0nS.name: Arcane Spellcasting (E)
