Faerie.biography:
Faeries are small, winged humanoids that inhabit the air and clouds. They have traits of multiple races: dwarven noses and beards, elven eyes and ears, and halfling-sized bodies. Their empire in the sky is hidden from most other beings.

Natural Invisibility: Faeries are invisible at all times and cannot be seen with normal sight. However, they can see invisible creatures without difficulty.

Innate Magical Abilities: Faeries can use the following powers at will, once per round:

  • Assume Gaseous Form: Functions like the potion.
  • Create Fog: Forms a 10' cube of mist around the faerie.
  • Condense Fog: Causes drizzle within the fog.
  • Return to Normal Form: Exits gaseous state.
  • Summon Breeze: Causes flames to flicker, blows out candles, and allows the faerie to fly at 360' (120') for one turn.

Faerie Society: Faeries live in floating homes made of "clouds," enjoying life above the storms. Their empire of wind is known only to them and a few air creatures.

Leaders & Spellcasters: Common faeries have 1+1 HD, but their leaders can have up to 9 HD. Some rare faeries are magic-users or clerics (see "Monster Spellcasters").

Terrain: Any.

Fish, Giant Rockfish.biography:
Giant spiny rockfish are found in shallow saltwater, lurking motionless on the sea floor. Their natural camouflage makes them difficult to detect; observers have a 70% chance of mistaking them for a rock or lump of coal.

When disturbed, the rockfish lashes out with four venomous spines. If a creature is hit or touches the rockfish, it is automatically struck by all four spines.

Poison: Any creature struck by a spine must make a saving throw vs. poison for each hit. Failure results in instant death.

Despite their dangerous defenses, rockfish are normally peaceful and attack only when provoked.

Terrain: Ocean (Shallow Waters).

Fish, Giant Sturgeon.biography:
The giant sturgeon is a massive, armored fish reaching nearly 30 feet in length. It is an aggressive predator, capable of swallowing prey whole.

Bite Attack: The sturgeon delivers a devastating bite that deals 2d10 damage.

Swallow Whole: If the sturgeon rolls an 18 or higher on an attack, it swallows its target. A swallowed victim takes 2d6 damage per round and must make a saving throw vs. death ray or be paralyzed. If not paralyzed, they can attack from inside.

Thick Scales: Its body is covered in natural armor, giving it AC 0.

Terrain: River, Lake, Ocean.

Gargantua, Carrion Crawler.biography:
A gargantua carrion crawler is a gigantic, grotesque arthropod created through magical experiments by the mad wizard Gargantua. It is twice the size of a normal carrion crawler, growing up to 40 feet long.

Hunting & Combat: This massive scavenger cannot surprise enemies due to its size and the noise it makes while moving. It suffers a -4 penalty to attacks against man-sized or smaller creatures.

Paralysis Tentacles: The worm lashes out with 8 paralyzing tentacles, each dealing 1d4+1 damage. Any creature hit must make a saving throw vs. paralysis or be unable to move.

Massive Appetite: Gargantua carrion crawler primarily feed on corpses but will attack living creatures if hungry.

Terrain: Same as the original species (Underground, Ruins).

0bhbKPHumYhp1DFv.description: The Magic Wand saving throw is used to avoid the effects of attacks or abilities activated through magical wands, such as paralysis rays or damage-dealing beams. A successful save, rolled on a d20, indicates that the character avoids or mitigates the harmful effects. The target number to save is determined by the character's class and level, as found on the saving throw table​​.
0bhbKPHumYhp1DFv.name: Magic Wand

3opiCDVB2woFoW4H.description: The Death Ray or Poison saving throw is a roll made by a character to resist deadly effects like instant death or paralysis from poisons, spells, or traps. The player rolls a d20 and compares it to their class- and level-specific target number on the saving throw table; success means avoiding or mitigating the harm. A failed roll often results in death (for poison) or other severe consequences, though optional rules may instead inflict substantial damage​​​.
3opiCDVB2woFoW4H.name: Death Ray or Poison

8MEccpgA3kRZ2Z6U.description: Gargantua are too large to move quietly and cannot surprise enemies. It also takes a -4 penalty to attacks against man-sized or smaller opponents.

AjhDoZwv70mROyNx.description: The saving throw against "Stone or Paralysis" protects a character from attacks or effects that could freeze them in place (paralysis) or turn them into stone. If the saving throw is failed, the character becomes immobilized or petrified, depending on the effect. Paralysis leaves a character aware but unable to act, while petrification turns the character and their carried equipment into a stone statue. The duration or permanence of these effects is specified by the source, and successful saving throws avoid them entirely​​​.

This saving throw is applicable to numerous magical attacks, such as charm spells, fireballs, or paralysis effects, and covers damage, control, or debilitating conditions caused by magical devices or spellcasters. The target number for success is based on the character's class and level.
hsezqHyk15zn29Mw.name: Spells or Magic Staff

qp9zIGgzsUtC0E0P.description: The saving throw against Breath Weapons is used to resist or mitigate the effects of a wide range of powerful exhaled attacks, not limited to dragons. Each creature’s breath weapon has specific effects, such as damage, paralysis, or petrification. A successful saving throw generally halves the damage or avoids the secondary effect (such as paralysis or petrification), while failure applies the full consequences. Gargantua, Gargoyle*.biography:
The gargantua gargoyle is a colossal, winged stone construct, standing over 20 feet tall. Created by the mad wizard Gargantua, it is a devastating predator of the skies.

Enchanted Nature: Unlike most gargantuas, this creature is fully magical. It is immune to normal weapons and can only be harmed by magical attacks or weapons.

Hunting & Combat: This terrifying beast can fly at great speeds (300') and attacks with its massive stone claws, bite, and horn.

Terrain: Same as the original species (Ruins, Mountains).

Gargantua, Troll.biography:
The gargantua troll is a towering, regenerating brute, standing over 30 feet tall. Created by the mad wizard Gargantua, this enormous troll is a terrifying force of destruction.

Hunting & Combat: A gargantua troll can move at incredible speed (240') and unleashes devastating attacks with two massive claws and a crushing bite.

Regeneration: The troll regenerates 12 hit points per round. Even severed limbs will grow back rapidly unless destroyed by fire or acid.

Gargoyle*.biography:
Gargoyles are magical constructs, created by wizards to serve various purposes, particularly as guardians. Over time, many gargoyles have escaped or outlived their creators, forming groups and defending their own territories.

Resembling hideous humanoids with horns, claws, fangs, and bat-like wings, gargoyles are often mistaken for statues due to their stone-like skin. Cunning and semi-intelligent, they can remain still for years without need for food or drink, watching over their territory patiently.

Gargoyles are immune to normal weapons, sleep, and charm spells. They can only be harmed by magical weapons and are fiercely territorial, attacking anyone who encroaches on their domain.

Terrain: Cavern, Ruins.
Load: 2,000 cn at full speed, 4,000 cn at half speed.

Gelatinous Cube.biography:
The gelatinous cube is a massive, nearly invisible ooze that moves through dungeon corridors, consuming all organic material in its path.

Surprise Attack: Due to its transparency, it is difficult to see, surprising foes on a roll of 1-4 (on 1d6).

Paralysis Attack: If a creature is struck, it takes 2d4 damage and must make a saving throw vs. paralysis or be paralyzed for 2d4 turns. A paralyzed creature is automatically hit.

Absorption: The cube picks up weapons, coins, and other non-digestible objects as it moves. These may be visible inside its form.

Resistances: The gelatinous cube is immune to cold and lightning.

Reproduction: Gelatinous cubes reproduce by splitting into two full-sized adults; no smaller or "young" cubes exist.

Terrain: Cavern, Ruins.

Ghoul.biography:
Ghouls are hideous, bestial undead that hunger for the flesh of the living. They retain no real memories of their past lives, act like ravenous predators, and are incapable of speech.

Undead Nature: Ghouls are immune to sleep and charm spells.

Paralyzing Attacks: Any creature ogre-sized or smaller (except elves) hit by a ghoul must make a saving throw vs. paralysis or be paralyzed for 2d4 turns. A ghoul will ignore paralyzed victims to attack other opponents.

Sunlight Aversion: While not harmed by the sun, ghouls avoid daylight and prefer to hunt at night.

Scavengers: When living prey is unavailable, ghouls feast on rotting flesh and carrion.

Terrain: Cavern, Ruins.

Giant, Cloud.biography:
Cloud giants are fierce beings with white or gray skin and hair. Standing 20 feet tall, they wear pale robes and possess keen eyesight and a sharp sense of smell, making them difficult to surprise (only 1 chance in 6). They are capable of throwing boulders at ranges of 60, 130, or 200 feet. These giants reside in castles built into mountainsides or perched atop massive clouds.

As guards, they keep either [[/r 1d6 #Small roc guards]] small rocs (if in clouds or mountains) or [[/r 6d6 #Dire wolf guards]] dire wolves (only in mountains).

Cloud giants despise being disturbed and often block mountain passes to discourage trespassers.

Terrain: Clouds or Mountains.

Giant, Fire.biography:
Fire giants have red skin, dark black hair, and thick beards. Standing 16 feet tall, they wear armor made of copper, brass, or bronze. They frequently throw rocks at ranges of 60, 130, or 200 feet. These giants typically dwell near volcanoes or other intensely hot environments, with their castles often constructed from black baked mud reinforced with crude iron.

As guards, they always have either [[/r 1d100 #Hydra guards if roll equal to or under 20, otherwise Hellhound guards]] [[/r 1d3 #Hydra guards]] hydras (20%) or [[/r 3d6 #Hellhound guards]] hellhounds (80%).

They are completely immune to fire-based attacks.

Terrain: Volcanoes, Intensely Hot Environments.

They always have either [[/r 1d100 #Polar bear guards if roll equal to or under 20 otherwise wolves]] [[/r 3d6 #Polar bear guards]] polar bears (20%) or [[/r 6d6 #Wolf guards]] wolves (80%) as guards.

They are completely immune to cold-based attacks.

Rock Damage: 3d6, up to 200 range.

Giant, Sea (10HD).biography:
Sea giants are typically amicable beings, though they are seldom encountered as they prefer to inhabit the deepest trenches of the ocean. They bear a striking resemblance to humans, aside from their towering height of 15 to 20 feet. These giants can breathe underwater but are capable of holding their breath for up to a full turn when briefly leaving the sea, a rare occurrence. Although they can wield weapons, usually massive spears dealing 1d10 × 4 damage, they seldom do so.

A remarkable ability of sea giants is their control over water currents. Underwater, they can generate a powerful surge in a cone extending 50 feet long and 30 feet wide at the base, forcefully propelling everything within the area 60 feet away without allowing a saving throw. Each affected creature must make a saving throw vs. death ray or be stunned for [[/r 1d6 #Rounds stunned by water surge]] rounds. On the ocean surface, this effect transforms into a massive wave measuring 120 feet long and 60 feet wide at its base, capable of dealing [[/r 2d6 #Hull points of damage]] hull points of damage to any vessel in its path​.

Terrain: Deep Sea.

Passionate about thunderstorms, they can create one in just 1 turn. If a storm is already present, a storm giant can unleash a lightning bolt once every 5 rounds, dealing damage equal to their remaining hit points (a successful saving throw vs. spells reduces this damage by half). These giants make their homes on mountaintops, in cloud castles, or deep underwater.

Their castles are always guarded by either [[/r 2d4 #Griffon guards]] griffons (if in mountains or clouds) or [[/r 3d6 #Giant crab guards]] giant crabs (if underwater).

Immune to lightning, storm giants are often found in the heart of violent storms, reveling in the chaos of the weather.

Gnome.biography:
Gnomes are small humanoids closely related to dwarves, standing about 3 1/2' to 4' tall with long noses and full beards. They typically live in burrows or underground cities and are known for their craftsmanship.

Infravision: Gnomes have well-developed infravision with a 90' range.

Smiths & Miners: Excellent metalworkers, gnomes have a deep love for gold and gems and sometimes take risks to obtain them. They also have a keen interest in machinery.

Preferred Weapons: Gnomes favor crossbows and war hammers in combat.

Enemy of Kobolds & Goblins: Gnomes consider these creatures thieves and will attack kobolds on sight.

Leadership Bonuses:

  • For every 20 gnomes, one is a leader with 11 HP, fighting as a **2 HD monster**.
  • In gnome villages, the **clan chieftain (18 HP, attacks as 4 HD, +1 damage)** is protected by **1d6 bodyguards (10-13 HP, attack as 3 HD).**
  • If the **chieftain or leader is alive**, all gnomes within sight have Morale 10 instead of 8.

Gnome Spellcasters: Some gnomes can use magic; see "Monster Spellcasters" for details.

Terrain: Cavern, Open.

7zn1KbWaKlGcQ0OP.description: A sling is a long (4’ to 6’) leather cord with a pouch half way along. The wielder straps one end of the cord around their wrist and holds the other end in the same hand. They then place a lead pellet in the pouch and swing the cord over their head. At the mid-point of the swing, they let go of the loose end, which releases the pellet. Slings normally require pellets as ammunition, although they can be used with stones taken from the ground, albeit with a –1 penalty on to-hit and damage rolls.

Goblins live in underground caves and caverns, and they are uncomfortable in daylight, fighting with a -1 penalty to attack rolls in bright light. They send hunting parties at night to scavenge food and ambush weakly-defended human groups. Goblins hate dwarves, attacking them on sight.

In their lair, a goblin king with 15 hit points leads them. He fights as a 3 HD monster, dealing +1 extra damage. The king is always accompanied by a bodyguard of 2d6 goblins who fight as 2 HD creatures. Goblin morale is improved to 9 when their king is present and alive.

Terrain: Cavern, Hill, Mountain, Woods.

3TwkQtcOnltyaUCF.description: The saving throw against "Stone or Paralysis" protects a character from attacks or effects that could freeze them in place (paralysis) or turn them into stone. If the saving throw is failed, the character becomes immobilized or petrified, depending on the effect. Paralysis leaves a character aware but unable to act, while petrification turns the character and their carried equipment into a stone statue. The duration or permanence of these effects is specified by the source, and successful saving throws avoid them entirely​​​.
3TwkQtcOnltyaUCF.name: Turn to Stone or Paralysis

CXd27MNXLTAJwKPf.description: The Death Ray or Poison saving throw is a roll made by a character to resist deadly effects like instant death or paralysis from poisons, spells, or traps. The player rolls a d20 and compares it to their class- and level-specific target number on the saving throw table; success means avoiding or mitigating the harm. A failed roll often results in death (for poison) or other severe consequences, though optional rules may instead inflict substantial damage​​​.
CXd27MNXLTAJwKPf.name: Death Ray or Poison

i4otc86b78eiqYDo.description: The saving throw against Breath Weapons is used to resist or mitigate the effects of a wide range of powerful exhaled attacks, not limited to dragons. This includes attacks like a dragon’s fiery or icy breath, a gorgon's petrifying breath, or a chimera's elemental breath. Each creature’s breath weapon has specific effects, such as damage, paralysis, or petrification. A successful saving throw generally halves the damage or avoids the secondary effect (such as paralysis or petrification), while failure applies the full consequences. Fire Immunity: The bronze golem is completely immune to all fire-based attacks, including magical fire.

Resistances:

  • Immune to sleep, charm, and hold spells.
  • Does not breathe, making it immune to all gas-based attacks.

Golem, Mud*.biography:
The mud golem is a shambling, humanoid construct made entirely of living mud. It stands roughly 6 feet tall and has a featureless, shifting body.

Movement Through Mud & Quicksand: The mud golem can walk or swim on mud and quicksand without sinking. It can remain fully submerged in these substances indefinitely.

Smothering Hug: The mud golem attacks with its massive, clay-like arms, attempting to engulf and suffocate its victim. A successful hit automatically deals 2d6 damage per round as the victim struggles for air.

Resistances:

  • Immune to sleep, charm, and hold spells.

The green slime is a horrifying, mindless ooze that clings to ceilings and walls, waiting to drop onto unsuspecting victims.

Always Hit: The green slime is AC 20 and can always be hit by attacks.

Destructive Touch: It dissolves cloth and leather instantly, wood and metal in 6 rounds, but cannot dissolve stone.

Body Transformation: When green slime touches flesh, it sticks and starts transforming the victim into green slime. The process is irreversible after 1d4 rounds unless it is burned off or removed with cure disease.

Burning & Removal: Green slime cannot be scraped off. Fire and cold damage it, but fire also harms the victim (splitting damage between both).

Resistances & Weaknesses:

  • Immune to all attacks except fire or cold.
  • Cannot be harmed by normal weapons.

Terrain: Cavern, Ruins.

Gremlin.biography:
The gremlin is a mischievous, 3-foot-tall humanoid with pasty gray-green skin, saucer-like eyes, and pointed ears. They have an evil sense of humor and love causing mayhem.

Chaotic Aura (20' Radius): Gremlins radiate a powerful aura of chaos, where "anything that can go wrong will go wrong." Each round, all creatures within the aura must save vs. spells or suffer random bad luck (determined by the DM).

Missed Attacks: Any creature that misses an attack against a gremlin must reroll the attack against themselves.

Spell Reversal: Any character casting a spell within the chaotic aura must roll a save vs. spells. If successful, the spell affects the gremlins; if failed, it backfires and affects the caster.

Mechanical Interference: Gremlins love breaking mechanical objects—crossbows might snap, axeheads may fall off, and magical devices may malfunction in bizarre ways.

Gremlin Spellcasters: Some gremlins practice magic; see Monster Spellcasters for details.

Terrain: Any.

Griffons are large, majestic creatures with the head, wings, and front claws of an eagle and the body and hindquarters of a lion. Guardian Owl (10HD).biography:
The Guardian Owl (Hsiao, sh-HOW) is a race of peaceful cleric-philosophers who inhabit woodlands and forests. Hsiao look like giant owls with broad feathered wings and large intelligent golden eyes. These creatures live in trees, making earthen nests and runnels high above the forest floor.

The Guardian Owls know and work closely with other woodland creatures (including actaeons, centaurs, dryads, elves, giants, and unicorns) and may call on them for aid. Their goals include the preservation of woodland wilderness against intrusions by dangerous humanoids. They will not interfere with passing PCs who do no damage to the woodlands or the races of the forest.

Most of these avian clerics are 4th level; 25% are higher levels (as given above; maximum level is 15th). Although able to physically defend themselves with their sharp claws and beak, these creatures depend on their spells and the assistance of their woodland allies for protection. The Guardian Owls are known to some druids, though their philosophies (alignments) obviously differ greatly.

No one knows where these creatures come from, but their alignment and clerical powers suggest that they were created to serve the ends of lawful mortals.

Terrain: Woods.

Load: A Guardian Owl can move at up to full speed when carrying 250 cn x its HD in encumbrance; it can move at half speed when carrying 500 cn x its HD.

Clerics have the divine power to repel or even destroy certain undead creatures, such as skeletons, zombies, and more powerful types. This ability is known as Turn Undead. When encountering these undead beings, the cleric can choose to either engage them in combat with weapons or spells, or attempt to turn them.

RaaVNdtHutNuDVos.description:
A cleric who chooses to establish a stronghold with the approval of his clerical order is known as a "land-owning cleric." This term is convenient, as a land-owning cleric can still adventure with friends and is not bound to his land.

Advantages: The cleric can advance within his order, receive financial support for building the stronghold, and potentially expand his lands, leading to significant wealth.

Disadvantages: The cleric becomes the primary authority for his order in the area, bearing responsibilities to the local populace that may hinder his ability to travel with old adventuring companions or present him with challenging issues.

When a 9th-level cleric decides to build a stronghold, he must seek permission from a superior, either an official of his order or a local ruler. The ruler should grant the land unless there are past issues; in such cases, the ruler may require a service, like a quest, before approval. The DM will determine if the cleric's order has the authority to grant land based on the campaign's setting.

If the cleric has a clean record, his order may assist with construction costs, typically covering up to 50% of the expenses. The player can design the stronghold, and the DM will assess the costs, deciding what portion the order will fund. Regardless of the financial support, the stronghold remains the cleric's property, and he cannot deny access to order members, nor can he be reassigned against his will.

Once the stronghold is built, a number of lower-level clerics (typically 1d6) will arrive to assist with its clerical functions. These clerics are there to help operate the stronghold, not to join the cleric on adventures. The DM should create each assistant cleric with their own name, personality, background, goals, and abilities.

If the cleric manages his land and serves his order well, he is likely to gain power within the clerical hierarchy, receive additional land, and see an increase in tax income from the growing settlements around his stronghold.

This saving throw is applicable to numerous magical attacks, such as charm spells, fireballs, or paralysis effects, and covers damage, control, or debilitating conditions caused by magical devices or spellcasters. The target number for success is based on the character's class and level.
YxNlofKfIJ1HRsq2.name: Spells or Magic Staff

pcdBLWKxB0T2tZST.description: The Flight ability allows a character or creature to move through the air, either through magical means or natural capabilities, such as having wings. This ability enables the user to ascend, descend, and navigate in three-dimensional space, often at a specified speed. Flight may come with limitations, such as a maximum altitude, duration, or specific conditions for its use.
pcdBLWKxB0T2tZST.name: Flight

uXTYuK9AEf4SDGpj.description: The saving throw against "Stone or Paralysis" protects a character from attacks or effects that could freeze them in place (paralysis) or turn them into stone. If the saving throw is failed, the character becomes immobilized or petrified, depending on the effect. Paralysis leaves a character aware but unable to act, while petrification turns the character and their carried equipment into a stone statue. The duration or permanence of these effects is specified by the source, and successful saving throws avoid them entirely​​​.
uXTYuK9AEf4SDGpj.name: Turn to Stone or Paralysis

yncd1M2e85Nirb9M.description:
The Guardian Owl possesses a unique ability to summon assistance from other woodland creatures. Once per day, the Guardian Owl can emit a resonant call that echoes through the forest, reaching the ears of nearby allies. This call can attract a variety of creatures, including centaurs, dryads, unicorns, and other friendly woodland beings, who are drawn to aid the Guardian Owl in times of need.

When the Guardian Owl uses this ability, it can request specific types of assistance, such as healing, combat support, or guidance through the forest. The summoned creatures will arrive within a few rounds, ready to assist the Guardian Owl and its allies. The number and strength of the creatures that respond depend on the situation and the Guardian Owl's relationship with the local fauna. This ability reflects the Guardian Owl's role as a protector of the woodland realm, fostering harmony and cooperation among its inhabitants.
yncd1M2e85Nirb9M.name: Call of the Wild

Guardian Owl (11HD).name: Guardian Owl (11HD)

Guardian Owl (12HD).biography:
The Guardian Owl (Hsiao, sh-HOW) is a race of peaceful cleric-philosophers who inhabit woodlands and forests. Hsiao look like giant owls with broad feathered wings and large intelligent golden eyes. These creatures live in trees, making earthen nests and runnels high above the forest floor.

The Guardian Owls know and work closely with other woodland creatures (including actaeons, centaurs, dryads, elves, giants, and unicorns) and may call on them for aid. Their goals include the preservation of woodland wilderness against intrusions by dangerous humanoids. They will not interfere with passing PCs who do no damage to the woodlands or the races of the forest.

Most of these avian clerics are 4th level; 25% are higher levels (as given above; maximum level is 15th). Although able to physically defend themselves with their sharp claws and beak, these creatures depend on their spells and the assistance of their woodland allies for protection. The Guardian Owls are known to some druids, though their philosophies (alignments) obviously differ greatly.

No one knows where these creatures come from, but their alignment and clerical powers suggest that they were created to serve the ends of lawful mortals.

Terrain: Woods.

Load: A Guardian Owl can move at up to full speed when carrying 250 cn x its HD in encumbrance; it can move at half speed when carrying 500 cn x its HD.

2vf4V5OvNenRQMZW.description: Clerics do not cast spells at 1st level but gain access to divine spells at 2nd level, progressing in power as they level up. Clerics do not need spellbooks but must pray for spells each day.
2vf4V5OvNenRQMZW.name: Divine Spellcasting

Notes:

  • 7, 9, or 11: Number needed to turn successfully.
  • T: Automatic turn; turns 2d6 Hit Dice of undead.
  • D: Automatic destroy; destroys 2d6 Hit Dice of undead.
  • D+: Automatic destroy; destroys 3d6 Hit Dice of undead.

Clerics have the divine power to repel or even destroy certain undead creatures, such as skeletons, zombies, and more powerful types. This ability is known as Turn Undead. When encountering these undead beings, the cleric can choose to either engage them in combat with weapons or spells, or attempt to turn them.

To turn undead, the cleric simply announces the intention to do so to the Dungeon Master. No holy symbol or other item is needed unless the DM specifies otherwise. The success of this attempt depends on the cleric’s level and the type of undead faced, as indicated on the Turning Undead table.

If the cleric succeeds, one or more undead creatures will flee or be destroyed immediately, depending on the result. However, a failed attempt means that particular undead creature cannot be turned by the cleric again during the same encounter. Multiple attempts are allowed in future encounters.

Should the attempt succeed, the Dungeon Master rolls to determine how many Hit Dice worth of undead are turned. At least one undead creature will always be affected. A turned undead creature will retreat as far as possible, but it has not been destroyed and may return after some time.
3H7hNXLYhsord5Zw.name: Turn Undead (C)

4Idiq0b6WFWVCOL4.description: The Magic Wand saving throw is used to avoid the effects of attacks or abilities activated through magical wands, such as paralysis rays or damage-dealing beams. A successful save, rolled on a d20, indicates that the character avoids or mitigates the harmful effects. The target number to save is determined by the character's class and level, as found on the saving throw table​​.
4Idiq0b6WFWVCOL4.name: Magic Wand

8Q7hYJbn1lT4MRQS.description: The Death Ray or Poison saving throw is a roll made by a character to resist deadly effects like instant death or paralysis from poisons, spells, or traps. The player rolls a d20 and compares it to their class- and level-specific target number on the saving throw table; success means avoiding or mitigating the harm. A failed roll often results in death (for poison) or other severe consequences, though optional rules may instead inflict substantial damage​​​.
8Q7hYJbn1lT4MRQS.name: Death Ray or Poison

B8P7duWHYxklw11Y.description: The saving throw against Breath Weapons is used to resist or mitigate the effects of a wide range of powerful exhaled attacks, not limited to dragons. This includes attacks like a dragon’s fiery or icy breath, a gorgon's petrifying breath, or a chimera's elemental breath. Each creature’s breath weapon has specific effects, such as damage, paralysis, or petrification. A successful saving throw generally halves the damage or avoids the secondary effect (such as paralysis or petrification), while failure applies the full consequences. The target number for the saving throw is determined by the character’s class and level.
B8P7duWHYxklw11Y.name: Dragon Breath

RaaVNdtHutNuDVos.description:
A cleric who chooses to establish a stronghold with the approval of his clerical order is known as a "land-owning cleric." This term is convenient, as a land-owning cleric can still adventure with friends and is not bound to his land.

Advantages: The cleric can advance within his order, receive financial support for building the stronghold, and potentially expand his lands, leading to significant wealth.

Disadvantages: The cleric becomes the primary authority for his order in the area, bearing responsibilities to the local populace that may hinder his ability to travel with old adventuring companions or present him with challenging issues.

When a 9th-level cleric decides to build a stronghold, he must seek permission from a superior, either an official of his order or a local ruler. The ruler should grant the land unless there are past issues; in such cases, the ruler may require a service, like a quest, before approval. The DM will determine if the cleric's order has the authority to grant land based on the campaign's setting.

If the cleric has a clean record, his order may assist with construction costs, typically covering up to 50% of the expenses. The player can design the stronghold, and the DM will assess the costs, deciding what portion the order will fund. Regardless of the financial support, the stronghold remains the cleric's property, and he cannot deny access to order members, nor can he be reassigned against his will.

Once the stronghold is built, a number of lower-level clerics (typically 1d6) will arrive to assist with its clerical functions. These clerics are there to help operate the stronghold, not to join the cleric on adventures. The DM should create each assistant cleric with their own name, personality, background, goals, and abilities.

If the cleric manages his land and serves his order well, he is likely to gain power within the clerical hierarchy, receive additional land, and see an increase in tax income from the growing settlements around his stronghold.
RaaVNdtHutNuDVos.name: Establish Stronghold (C)

The target number for success is based on the character's class and level.

pcdBLWKxB0T2tZST.description: The Flight ability allows a character or creature to move through the air, either through magical means or natural capabilities, such as having wings. This ability enables the user to ascend, descend, and navigate in three-dimensional space, often at a specified speed. Flight may come with limitations, such as a maximum altitude, duration, or specific conditions for its use.
pcdBLWKxB0T2tZST.name: Flight

uXTYuK9AEf4SDGpj.description: The saving throw against "Stone or Paralysis" protects a character from attacks or effects that could freeze them in place (paralysis) or turn them into stone. If the saving throw is failed, the character becomes immobilized or petrified, depending on the effect. Paralysis leaves a character aware but unable to act, while petrification turns the character and their carried equipment into a stone statue. The duration or permanence of these effects is specified by the source, and successful saving throws avoid them entirely​​​.
uXTYuK9AEf4SDGpj.name: Turn to Stone or Paralysis

yncd1M2e85Nirb9M.description:
The Guardian Owl possesses a unique ability to summon assistance from other woodland creatures. Once per day, the Guardian Owl can emit a resonant call that echoes through the forest, reaching the ears of nearby allies. This call can attract a variety of creatures, including centaurs, dryads, unicorns, and other friendly woodland beings, who are drawn to aid the Guardian Owl in times of need.

When the Guardian Owl uses this ability, it can request specific types of assistance, such as healing, combat support, or guidance through the forest. The summoned creatures will arrive within a few rounds, ready to assist the Guardian Owl and its allies. The number and strength of the creatures that respond depend on the situation and the Guardian Owl's relationship with the local fauna. This ability reflects the Guardian Owl's role as a protector of the woodland realm, fostering harmony and cooperation among its inhabitants.
yncd1M2e85Nirb9M.name: Call of the Wild

Guardian Owl (14HD).name: Guardian Owl (14HD)

Guardian Owl (15HD).biography:
The Guardian Owl (Hsiao, sh-HOW) is a race of peaceful cleric-philosophers who inhabit woodlands and forests. Hsiao look like giant owls with broad feathered wings and large intelligent golden eyes. These creatures live in trees, making earthen nests and runnels high above the forest floor.

The Guardian Owls know and work closely with other woodland creatures (including actaeons, centaurs, dryads, elves, giants, and unicorns) and may call on them for aid. Their goals include the preservation of woodland wilderness against intrusions by dangerous humanoids. They will not interfere with passing PCs who do no damage to the woodlands or the races of the forest.

Most of these avian clerics are 4th level; 25% are higher levels (as given above; maximum level is 15th). Although able to physically defend themselves with their sharp claws and beak, these creatures depend on their spells and the assistance of their woodland allies for protection. The Guardian Owls are known to some druids, though their philosophies (alignments) obviously differ greatly.

No one knows where these creatures come from, but their alignment and clerical powers suggest that they were created to serve the ends of lawful mortals.

Terrain: Woods.

Load: A Guardian Owl can move at up to full speed when carrying 250 cn x its HD in encumbrance; it can move at half speed when carrying 500 cn x its HD.

2vf4V5OvNenRQMZW.name: Divine Spellcasting

Clerics have the divine power to repel or even destroy certain undead creatures, such as skeletons, zombies, and more powerful types. This ability is known as Turn Undead. When encountering these undead beings, the cleric can choose to either engage them in combat with weapons or spells, or attempt to turn them.

To turn undead, the cleric simply announces the intention to do so to the Dungeon Master. No holy symbol or other item is needed unless the DM specifies otherwise. The success of this attempt depends on the cleric’s level and the type of undead faced, as indicated on the Turning Undead table.

If the cleric succeeds, one or more undead creatures will flee or be destroyed immediately, depending on the result. However, a failed attempt means that particular undead creature cannot be turned by the cleric again during the same encounter. Multiple attempts are allowed in future encounters.

Should the attempt succeed, the Dungeon Master rolls to determine how many Hit Dice worth of undead are turned. At least one undead creature will always be affected. A turned undead creature will retreat as far as possible, but it has not been destroyed and may return after some time.
3H7hNXLYhsord5Zw.name: Turn Undead (C)

4Idiq0b6WFWVCOL4.name: Magic Wand

8Q7hYJbn1lT4MRQS.description: The Death Ray or Poison saving throw is a roll made by a character to resist deadly effects like instant death or paralysis from poisons, spells, or traps. The player rolls a d20 and compares it to their class- and level-specific target number on the saving throw table; success means avoiding or mitigating the harm. A failed roll often results in death (for poison) or other severe consequences, though optional rules may instead inflict substantial damage​​​.
8Q7hYJbn1lT4MRQS.name: Death Ray or Poison

B8P7duWHYxklw11Y.description: The saving throw against Breath Weapons is used to resist or mitigate the effects of a wide range of powerful exhaled attacks, not limited to dragons. This includes attacks like a dragon’s fiery or icy breath, a gorgon's petrifying breath, or a chimera's elemental breath. Each creature’s breath weapon has specific effects, such as damage, paralysis, or petrification. A successful saving throw generally halves the damage or avoids the secondary effect (such as paralysis or petrification), while failure applies the full consequences. The target number for the saving throw is determined by the character’s class and level.
B8P7duWHYxklw11Y.name: Dragon Breath

RaaVNdtHutNuDVos.description:
A cleric who chooses to establish a stronghold with the approval of his clerical order is known as a "land-owning cleric." This term is convenient, as a land-owning cleric can still adventure with friends and is not bound to his land.

Advantages: The cleric can advance within his order, receive financial support for building the stronghold, and potentially expand his lands, leading to significant wealth.

Disadvantages: The cleric becomes the primary authority for his order in the area, bearing responsibilities to the local populace that may hinder his ability to travel with old adventuring companions or present him with challenging issues.

When a 9th-level cleric decides to build a stronghold, he must seek permission from a superior, either an official of his order or a local ruler. The ruler should grant the land unless there are past issues; in such cases, the ruler may require a service, like a quest, before approval. The DM will determine if the cleric's order has the authority to grant land based on the campaign's setting.

If the cleric has a clean record, his order may assist with construction costs, typically covering up to 50% of the expenses. The player can design the stronghold, and the DM will assess the costs, deciding what portion the order will fund. Regardless of the financial support, the stronghold remains the cleric's property, and he cannot deny access to order members, nor can he be reassigned against his will.

Once the stronghold is built, a number of lower-level clerics (typically 1d6) will arrive to assist with its clerical functions. These clerics are there to help operate the stronghold, not to join the cleric on adventures. The DM should create each assistant cleric with their own name, personality, background, goals, and abilities.

If the cleric manages his land and serves his order well, he is likely to gain power within the clerical hierarchy, receive additional land, and see an increase in tax income from the growing settlements around his stronghold.
RaaVNdtHutNuDVos.name: Establish Stronghold (C)

uXTYuK9AEf4SDGpj.name: Turn to Stone or Paralysis

yncd1M2e85Nirb9M.description:
The Guardian Owl possesses a unique ability to summon assistance from other woodland creatures. Once per day, the Guardian Owl can emit a resonant call that echoes through the forest, reaching the ears of nearby allies. This call can attract a variety of creatures, including centaurs, dryads, unicorns, and other friendly woodland beings, who are drawn to aid the Guardian Owl in times of need.

When the Guardian Owl uses this ability, it can request specific types of assistance, such as healing, combat support, or guidance through the forest. The summoned creatures will arrive within a few rounds, ready to assist the Guardian Owl and its allies. The number and strength of the creatures that respond depend on the situation and the Guardian Owl's relationship with the local fauna. This ability reflects the Guardian Owl's role as a protector of the woodland realm, fostering harmony and cooperation among its inhabitants.
yncd1M2e85Nirb9M.name: Call of the Wild

Guardian Owl (6HD).name: Guardian Owl (6HD)

Guardian Owl (7HD).biography:
The Guardian Owl (Hsiao, sh-HOW) is a race of peaceful cleric-philosophers who inhabit woodlands and forests. Hsiao look like giant owls with broad feathered wings and large intelligent golden eyes. These creatures live in trees, making earthen nests and runnels high above the forest floor.

The Guardian Owls know and work closely with other woodland creatures (including actaeons, centaurs, dryads, elves, giants, and unicorns) and may call on them for aid. Their goals include the preservation of woodland wilderness against intrusions by dangerous humanoids. They will not interfere with passing PCs who do no damage to the woodlands or the races of the forest.

Most of these avian clerics are 4th level; 25% are higher levels (as given above; maximum level is 15th). Although able to physically defend themselves with their sharp claws and beak, these creatures depend on their spells and the assistance of their woodland allies for protection. The Guardian Owls are known to some druids, though their philosophies (alignments) obviously differ greatly.

No one knows where these creatures come from, but their alignment and clerical powers suggest that they were created to serve the ends of lawful mortals.

Terrain: Woods.

Load: A Guardian Owl can move at up to full speed when carrying 250 cn x its HD in encumbrance; it can move at half speed when carrying 500 cn x its HD.

yncd1M2e85Nirb9M.description:
The Guardian Owl possesses a unique ability to summon assistance from other woodland creatures. Once per day, the Guardian Owl can emit a resonant call that echoes through the forest, reaching the ears of nearby allies. This call can attract a variety of creatures, including centaurs, dryads, unicorns, and other friendly woodland beings, who are drawn to aid the Guardian Owl in times of need.

When the Guardian Owl uses this ability, it can request specific types of assistance, such as healing, combat support, or guidance through the forest. The summoned creatures will arrive within a few rounds, ready to assist the Guardian Owl and its allies. The number and strength of the creatures that respond depend on the situation and the Guardian Owl's relationship with the local fauna. This ability reflects the Guardian Owl's role as a protector of the woodland realm, fostering harmony and cooperation among its inhabitants.
yncd1M2e85Nirb9M.name: Call of the Wild

Halfling.biography:
Halflings are small, demihuman creatures who often live near their villages. They are skilled with missile weapons, receiving a +1 bonus to attack rolls when using them. Halflings are excellent at hiding, particularly in woods or underbrush, where there is only a 10% chance of being detected while hiding.

In combat, halflings gain a +2 bonus to Armor Class when fighting larger than man-sized enemies. For every 10 halflings, one will be a leader of level 2, and as long as the leader is alive and fighting alongside them, their morale is 10 rather than 8.

Halflings typically live in villages, or shires, of 30 to 300 inhabitants. Each village is led by a sheriff (a fighter of level 2-7) and protected by a village guard of 5-20 militia (each with 2 Hit Dice).

Special Abilities: Halflings get a +1 bonus to attack rolls when using missile weapons and a +2 bonus to Armor Class when fighting larger creatures.
Terrain: Hill, Open.

DcoyoppvdNsCNrl5.description: The saving throw against Breath Weapons is used to resist or mitigate the effects of a wide range of powerful exhaled attacks, not limited to dragons. This includes attacks like a dragon’s fiery or icy breath, a gorgon's petrifying breath, or a chimera's elemental breath. Each creature’s breath weapon has specific effects, such as damage, paralysis, or petrification. A successful saving throw generally halves the damage or avoids the secondary effect (such as paralysis or petrification), while failure applies the full consequences. The target number for the saving throw is determined by the character’s class and level.
DcoyoppvdNsCNrl5.name: Dragon Breath

This saving throw is applicable to numerous magical attacks, such as charm spells, fireballs, or paralysis effects, and covers damage, control, or debilitating conditions caused by magical devices or spellcasters. The target number for success is based on the character's class and level.
TFCZeG9ctHJksNx0.name: Spells or Magic Staff

r5wHntjta7Cs1ClG.description:
Halflings gain a +1 bonus to all attack rolls when using missile weapons, a +1 bonus to individual initiative, and a -2 AC bonus when attacked by creatures larger than man-sized.

A creature is considered larger than man-sized if its description includes terms like "giant," "gargantuan," or "enormous." Additionally, real-world creatures that the DM deems larger than a human (such as a horse) also fall into this category. As a general guideline, any non-humanoid creature without a specified size can be assumed to be larger than man-sized if it has 4 or more Hit Dice (HD).
r5wHntjta7Cs1ClG.name: Combat Bonuses (H)

sNwYq44qO0K1IGPb.description:
Indoors or in dungeons, a Halfling can attempt to hide in deep shadows or cover, but with less success than in natural environments. If sufficient shadows or concealment exist, they have a 33% chance to remain unseen (rolled secretly by the DM). If there is no available cover, the Halfling cannot hide at all.

A bright light, such as a magical light source that eliminates shadows, prevents hiding. A Halfling cannot use this ability while carrying a light source themselves.
sNwYq44qO0K1IGPb.name: Hide, Indoors (H)

uqmGGpdhi0ydtN5f.description: Fletched arrows in a quiver. Can be used with a long bow or short bow.

vhtRNobg3WzoIJjd.description:
A character on foot armed with a spear, pike, sword, shield, or lance can set the weapon against a charge. A charge occurs when a monster rushes towards the character, covering at least 20 yards before attacking. This maneuver can also be used against another character's lance attack.

To "set vs. charge," the character braces the weapon against the ground, pointing it at the approaching enemy. Strength and magic bonuses apply to both the attack and damage rolls. If the attack is successful, the character deals double damage, with adjustments applied after doubling.

The character must declare the set vs. charge maneuver before entering melee combat with the charging opponent. For example, if the character’s party wins initiative and expects a charge, they can declare this maneuver. Similarly, if charging monsters are spotted several rounds in advance, the character can set their weapon against the charge ahead of time.

Typically, the attack is made during the monster's movement phase, as soon as it comes within weapon range. If the attack succeeds and kills the monster, it prevents the creature from attacking. If the attack does not kill the monster, it can then attack during its own melee phase of the combat sequence.
vhtRNobg3WzoIJjd.name: Set Spear vs. Charge

The player rolls a d20 and compares it to their class- and level-specific target number on the saving throw table; success means avoiding or mitigating the harm. A failed roll often results in death (for poison) or other severe consequences, though optional rules may instead inflict substantial damage​​​.
wOKQgodXv2GboeXf.name: Death Ray or Poison

Harpy.biography:
Harpies are monstrous creatures with the lower body of a giant eagle and the upper body of a hideous woman. Their most dangerous ability is their mesmerizing song, which can charm anyone who hears it. Any creature hearing their song must make a saving throw vs. spells or become charmed. If a creature successfully makes the saving throw, they are immune to all harpy songs for the duration of the encounter.

Harpies prefer to live in secluded areas near places with steady human traffic, such as mountain passes or trade routes, where they can lure travelers to their doom. Once a location is no longer frequented by new victims, harpies will move to a new location and repeat the cycle.

Terrain: Hill, Mountain.
Load: 1,000 cn at full speed, 2,000 cn at half speed.

Haunt, Banshee*.biography:
The banshee is a lonely haunt that favors desolate moors and outdoor locations, although it can occasionally be found underground. It acts as a guardian of sorts and may aid a specific race in its territory (often sprites or pixies) by frightening and chasing away enemies. According to rumor, a banshee is the spirit of an evil female elf, seeking to atone for its past misdeeds.

The haunt is immune to sleep, charm, and mind-affecting spells. It can only be harmed by +2 or better magical weapons and is immune to all spells except those affecting evil beings.

Wail of Death: The Banshee can unleash a piercing wail three times per day. All creatures within 60' must make a saving throw vs. death ray or die instantly. The Banshee typically uses one wail at a distance to scare off intruders; NPCs and monsters hearing the wail must make a morale check at a +4 penalty. If avoided, the Banshee will not pursue.

The Banshee guards the wealth of past victims, stored somewhere within its haunted domain.

Terrain: Ruins, Moors, Deep Forests.

3g4QVS5f89vhSfQD.description:
A banshee can use its special attack, a wail, up to three times per day. All victims within 60 feet must make a saving throw versus death ray or die instantly.

The creature often uses one wail at a distance to ward off approaching enemies; in this case, an immediate morale check must be made for NPCs and monsters hearing it, with a +4 penalty to the roll.

The banshee can be tricked into wailing again, but it will not use its third wail until it is in the midst of combat. If its wail is avoided, a banshee will typically not pursue its opponents.
3g4QVS5f89vhSfQD.name: Wail of Death

XrwvkzoBFcqCU5US.description:
The haunt's touch inflicts [[/r 1d4*10 #Years of aging]] years of aging. Each 10 years aged reduces Constitution by 1 point permanently.

A wish will restore only one point lost in this manner, and less powerful magic cannot affect the loss. All aging can be countered only with a potion of longevity or a wish. If a victim's Constitution drops to 0, the victim dies permanently, and cannot be raised.

Elves may ignore the effects of the first 200 years of aging; dwarves may ignore the first 50 years, and halflings, the first 20 years.
XrwvkzoBFcqCU5US.name: Aging Touch

ahOh34PMlmysHXzG.description:

ahOh34PMlmysHXzG.name: Gaze of Paralysis

apKqm1bxpYluRHwm.name: Escape to Ethereal Plane

d4MbJ3H8fVMd6H3F.description:
When a haunt is first encountered, it typically starts oozing ectoplasm, which appears as wispy tendrils that slowly form a net.

The net has no effect on the movement of the haunt or others, and is only a visual effect for three rounds. However, after that time, the net is complete, forming a 10-foot radius around the haunt and moving with it.

Any living creature within a complete ectoplasmic net must make a saving throw versus spells or be pulled into the Ethereal Plane, where the net also exists.

The ethereal victim is helpless unless they possess special items or spells that permit escape from that plane, such as oil of etherealness, teleport, etc. The haunt will attack its ethereal victims when it returns to the Ethereal Plane.
d4MbJ3H8fVMd6H3F.name: Ectoplasmic Net

A successful save, rolled on a d20, often reduces or negates the spell's effects entirely. This saving throw is applicable to numerous magical attacks, such as charm spells, fireballs, or paralysis effects, and covers damage, control, or debilitating conditions caused by magical devices or spellcasters. The target number for success is based on the character's class and level.
y0Y95CJaMzKVVaHJ.name: Spells or Magic Staff

zX26rYIHXKvud8kE.description: The Death Ray or Poison saving throw is a roll made by a character to resist deadly effects like instant death or paralysis from poisons, spells, or traps. The player rolls a d20 and compares it to their class- and level-specific target number on the saving throw table; success means avoiding or mitigating the harm. A failed roll often results in death (for poison) or other severe consequences, though optional rules may instead inflict substantial damage​​​.
zX26rYIHXKvud8kE.name: Death Ray or Poison

Haunt, Banshee*.name: Haunt, Banshee*

Haunt, Ghost* (Chaotic).biography:
A Chaotic ghost appears as a nearly transparent bundle of cloth and can assume any desired form, including (but rarely) that of a Lawful or Neutral ghost. Regardless of its form, the creature is always accompanied by a dark candle, torch, or lantern. When first encountered, a Chaotic ghost immediately uses its magic jar spell, unless it is masquerading as one of the other types of ghosts.

The haunt is immune to sleep, charm, and mind-affecting spells. It can only be harmed by +2 or better magical weapons and is immune to all spells except those affecting evil beings.

Magic Jar (Possession): Once per turn, the ghost can attempt to possess a creature within 30'. The victim must make a saving throw vs. spells or fall under the ghost’s control until exorcised.

Terrain: Ruins, Cursed Lands, Haunted Houses.

CwaF3kOxYVzutr2S.description: The saving throw for Spells or Magic Staff includes resistance against magical effects cast by rods, staves, wands, or through spells. A successful save, rolled on a d20, often reduces or negates the spell's effects entirely. This saving throw is applicable to numerous magical attacks, such as charm spells, fireballs, or paralysis effects, and covers damage, control, or debilitating conditions caused by magical devices or spellcasters. The target number for success is based on the character's class and level.
CwaF3kOxYVzutr2S.name: Spells or Magic Staff

NzlneZn97XIHra8P.description: When a cleric's attempt to turn a haunt results in a "0", the creature may make a saving throw versus spells to avoid destruction. If the saving throw is successful, the monster is not turned or destroyed, although the cleric can repeat the attempt. Other turning results are handled normally.
NzlneZn97XIHra8P.name: Turning Resistance

XrwvkzoBFcqCU5US.description:
The haunt's touch inflicts [[/r 1d4*10 #Years of aging]] years of aging. Each 10 years aged reduces Constitution by 1 point permanently.

A wish will restore only one point lost in this manner, and less powerful magic cannot affect the loss. All aging can be countered only with a potion of longevity or a wish. If a victim's Constitution drops to 0, the victim dies permanently, and cannot be raised.

Elves may ignore the effects of the first 200 years of aging; dwarves may ignore the first 50 years, and halflings, the first 20 years.
XrwvkzoBFcqCU5US.name: Aging Touch

ahOh34PMlmysHXzG.description:
The haunt may gaze at a target from 60' away. The victim must make a save vs. spells or be paralyzed for [[/r 2d4 #Rounds paralyzed by gaze.]] rounds.

A haunt often ignores its paralyzed victims, concentrating its attacks on other enemies nearby, until only helpless ones remain.
ahOh34PMlmysHXzG.name: Gaze of Paralysis

apKqm1bxpYluRHwm.description: The Haunt may shift to the Ethereal Plane 3 times per day, remaining there for [[/r 1d8 #Haunt shifts to Ethereal Plane for this many days]] days.
apKqm1bxpYluRHwm.name: Escape to Ethereal Plane

d4MbJ3H8fVMd6H3F.description:
When a haunt is first encountered, it typically starts oozing ectoplasm, which appears as wispy tendrils that slowly form a net.

The net has no effect on the movement of the haunt or others, and is only a visual effect for three rounds. However, after that time, the net is complete, forming a 10-foot radius around the haunt and moving with it.

Any living creature within a complete ectoplasmic net must make a saving throw versus spells or be pulled into the Ethereal Plane, where the net also exists.

The ethereal victim is helpless unless they possess special items or spells that permit escape from that plane, such as oil of etherealness, teleport, etc. The haunt will attack its ethereal victims when it returns to the Ethereal Plane.
d4MbJ3H8fVMd6H3F.name: Ectoplasmic Net

fUTkwa7XcOPBMW3K.description: The saving throw against Breath Weapons is used to resist or mitigate the effects of a wide range of powerful exhaled attacks, not limited to dragons. This includes attacks like a dragon’s fiery or icy breath, a gorgon's petrifying breath, or a chimera's elemental breath. Each creature’s breath weapon has specific effects, such as damage, paralysis, or petrification. A successful saving throw generally halves the damage or avoids the secondary effect (such as paralysis or petrification), while failure applies the full consequences. The target number for the saving throw is determined by the character’s class and level.
fUTkwa7XcOPBMW3K.name: Dragon Breath

ft9azWn3PWj01Dcj.description:
Every ghost has the ability to use a magic jar effect (similar to the spell; range 30 feet) on one victim per turn. If successful, one item carried by the ghost will glow, powered by the life force of its victim. The ghost's force then possesses the body of the victim, and causes it to attack others. During this time, and for as long as it possesses another, the ghost's figure stops, merely holding the light (but still oozing the ectoplasmic net).

The ghost and the item both remain ethereal. If its magic jar attempt fails, a ghost usually materializes and attacks with blows or its gaze attack.
ft9azWn3PWj01Dcj.name: Magic Jar (Possession)

jz6OshlTmGEqiro5.description: The Magic Wand saving throw is used to avoid the effects of attacks or abilities activated through magical wands, such as paralysis rays or damage-dealing beams. A successful save, rolled on a d20, indicates that the character avoids or mitigates the harmful effects. The target number to save is determined by the character's class and level, as found on the saving throw table​​.
jz6OshlTmGEqiro5.name: Magic Wand

pcdBLWKxB0T2tZST.description: The Flight ability allows a character or creature to move through the air, either through magical means or natural capabilities, such as having wings. This ability enables the user to ascend, descend, and navigate in three-dimensional space, often at a specified speed. Flight may come with limitations, such as a maximum altitude, duration, or specific conditions for its use.
pcdBLWKxB0T2tZST.name: Flight

pdqjkLS2Q7qIfXzv.description: The saving throw against "Stone or Paralysis" protects a character from attacks or effects that could freeze them in place (paralysis) or turn them into stone. If the saving throw is failed, the character becomes immobilized or petrified, depending on the effect. Paralysis leaves a character aware but unable to act, while petrification turns the character and their carried equipment into a stone statue. The duration or permanence of these effects is specified by the source, and successful saving throws avoid them entirely​​​.
pdqjkLS2Q7qIfXzv.name: Turn to Stone or Paralysis

A Lawful ghost appears as a transparent human figure, typically carrying a lantern or candle. If attacked, it can retaliate with the same attacks as any other ghost. However, if approached with caution, the ghost will gesture, and if followed, it will lead the way to a special clue or treasure before disappearing. Some Lawful ghosts exist solely to guide Lawful living beings away from areas of great danger.

In return for aid, the ghost typically reveals the location of their treasure hoard.

Haunt, Poltergeist*.biography:
The Poltergeist is an invisible haunt that exists to torment intruders. Unlike other haunts, it has no physical form and cannot be seen without magic. Its presence is known only by the eerie movement of objects and the sudden formation of an ectoplasmic net.

The haunt is immune to sleep, charm, and mind-affecting spells. It can only be harmed by +2 or better magical weapons and is immune to all spells except those affecting evil beings.

Invisibility: The Poltergeist is naturally invisible and can only be detected by magical means.

Telekinetic Assault: The Poltergeist can hurl two objects per round at opponents, dealing damage based on the object’s size. A saving throw vs. spells is required to avoid the aging effect.

Terrain: Ruins, Haunted Buildings.

Headsman (10HD).biography:
The Headsman is a skilled executioner, trained in the art of swift and precise killing. Employed by dominion rulers, they are responsible for carrying out death sentences using blades, ropes, and poisons. Their loyalty is often to their guild rather than the law.

Guild Affiliation: Headsmen belong to a secretive guild linked to the Thieves' Guild. Their identities are carefully concealed, often leading double lives as common townsfolk.

Combat & Abilities: Headsmen rely on stealth, deception, and precision strikes. At 6+ HD, they become masters of disguise (90% undetectable), and at 10+ HD, they can even use the secret languages of other alignments.

Equipment: A Headsman typically carries a sharp executioner’s blade, a coiled garrote, and vials of poison.

Terrain: Any; Settled.

Helion*.biography:
Helions are intelligent, giant-sized creatures made of fire, native to the Elemental Plane of Fire. They are rarely encountered elsewhere and are extremely good, shunning violence. A helion appears as a 20-foot diameter ring of flame.

The helion has several notable abilities and immunities. It is immune to poison, normal weapons, all 1st and 2nd level spells, and attacks based on earth. Additionally, it can detect invisible creatures at will and detect magic. The helion can also dispel magic, create a wall of fire, and transform earth into fire up to three times per day. Furthermore, it has complete control over fire, able to change it into solid, liquid, or gaseous form at will (a saving throw applies for fire-type creatures).

When attacking, a helion forms a ring around its opponent. If its attack roll is successful, it shrinks around the victim, immobilizing them. The helion can then squeeze its opponent for [[/r 2d8 #Helion squeeze damage]] points of damage per round, although it rarely tries to harm opponents, preferring to negotiate peaceful terms. However, it will defend itself if attacked.

Helions are renowned philosophers and negotiators. They have two main enemies: the efreet and the hounds of Tiamat (also known as haoou). Additionally, helions have a deep-seated fear of water-type creatures and attacks.

Terrain: Plane of Fire.

c1IT8bcwWwTwpgws.description:
This spell removes existing spell effects within a 20' x 20' x 20' area. Spell effects cast by a spellcaster of equal or lower level are automatically dispelled.

Higher-Level Casters: Effects created by a higher-level spellcaster may resist dispelling. The chance of failure is 5% per level difference. For example, a 7th-level magic-user dispelling a spell cast by a 9th-level cleric has a 10% chance of failure.

Magical Items: This spell does not affect magical items themselves, but it can disrupt active effects they produce. For instance, dispel magic can free a person from the control of a ring of human control.
c1IT8bcwWwTwpgws.name: Dispel Magic

cnNez4KJLuP70GOU.description: A helion can move freely between the elemental planes of Earth and Fire, using a natural tunnel that only it can access. It may vanish into the ground or flame and emerge from the other element on the next round.
cnNez4KJLuP70GOU.name: Earth to Fire

eIV9zDJxnlwjpcGq.description:
This spell creates a thin, vertical wall of fire in any shape or dimension, totaling 1,200 square feet (e.g., 10' x 120', 20' x 60', 30' x 40'). The wall is opaque and blocks sight, and it cannot be created in a space already occupied by another object.

Duration: The wall remains as long as the caster concentrates on it without moving.

Breaking Through: Creatures with less than 4 Hit Dice cannot pass through the wall. Creatures with 4 HD or more may pass through, taking 1d6 fire damage in the process. Undead and cold-using creatures (e.g., white dragons, frost giants) each take double damage (2d6) when breaking through.
eIV9zDJxnlwjpcGq.name: Wall of Fire

mhzRCVVasROcXJYi.description: The helion encircles its opponent with a ring of flame. If successful, it constricts the victim, immobilizing them and dealing 2d8 points of damage per round. However, the helion prefers negotiation over harm and will only defend itself if attacked.
mhzRCVVasROcXJYi.name: Grasp

Hellhound (3HD).biography:
This reddish-brown, doglike creature is about as large as a small pony and is known as a hellhound. Often encountered near volcanoes, deep in dungeons, or among other fire-loving beings such as fire giants, it is both cunning and highly intelligent.

Hellhounds can detect invisible foes (using a method akin to the magic-user spell) with a 75% chance per round within a 60-foot range. They are immune to normal fire and make all saving throws as fighters of equivalent Hit Dice.

In combat, a hellhound targets a single opponent each round, choosing either a biting attack or a fire breath attack. The fire breath deals 1d6 points of damage for each Hit Die of the hellhound; the attack is triggered on a roll of 1–2 on a 1d6 (a one-in-three chance), while the bite occurs on a roll of 3–6 (a two-in-three chance). A target struck by the fire breath may attempt a saving throw versus dragon breath to halve the damage.

Terrain: Cavern, Mountain

Hippogriff.biography:
A hippogriff is a magical creature that has the foreparts and head of a giant eagle, and the hindquarters of a horse. These creatures are carnivorous, preferring to hunt herd animals. They are descended from a magical crossbreed of griffons and horses.

Hippogriffs are capable of carrying off man-sized or smaller prey and can be tamed to serve as mounts if raised from a young age. They usually nest in rocky crags but will fly wherever they need to hunt. They are natural enemies of pegasi, and when they encounter these creatures, hippogriffs must make a morale check or attack them despite their rider's commands.

Hobgoblins are larger, meaner relatives of goblins, standing taller and bulkier. They often live underground in caves or dungeons, but regularly venture into rough wilderness or wastelands for hunting, without suffering any penalties in daylight.

A hobgoblin king, along with 1d4 bodyguards, leads the group in their lair. The king has 22 hit points and fights as a 5 HD monster with an additional +2 damage bonus. His bodyguards are as tough as 4 HD monsters, and each has 3d6 hit points. If the king is present and alive, hobgoblin morale increases to 10.

Terrain: Cavern, Hill, Mountain, Woods.

FXqCWuIcG46uXuWA.description: The Magic Wand saving throw is used to avoid the effects of attacks or abilities activated through magical wands, such as paralysis rays or damage-dealing beams. A successful save, rolled on a d20, indicates that the character avoids or mitigates the harmful effects. The target number to save is determined by the character's class and level, as found on the saving throw table​​.
FXqCWuIcG46uXuWA.name: Magic Wand

QTLRJeBuPnCoDr89.description: The spear is a thrusting head attached to one end of a medium-to-long pole (6'-8'). Fighters, dwarves, elves, and mystics can use the set spear vs. charge maneuver.
QTLRJeBuPnCoDr89.name: Spear
QTLRJeBuPnCoDr89.unidentifiedDesc: The spear is a thrusting head attached to one end of a medium-to-long pole (6'-8'). Fighters, dwarves, elves, and mystics can use the set spear vs. charge maneuver.

d9hjgQKKhht4qPkp.description: The saving throw for Spells or Magic Staff includes resistance against magical effects cast by rods, staves, wands, or through spells. A successful save, rolled on a d20, often reduces or negates the spell's effects entirely. This saving throw is applicable to numerous magical attacks, such as charm spells, fireballs, or paralysis effects, and covers damage, control, or debilitating conditions caused by magical devices or spellcasters. The target number for success is based on the character's class and level.
d9hjgQKKhht4qPkp.name: Spells or Magic Staff

oAO6atDu0rDkRYWM.description: The saving throw against Breath Weapons is used to resist or mitigate the effects of a wide range of powerful exhaled attacks, not limited to dragons. This includes attacks like a dragon’s fiery or icy breath, a gorgon's petrifying breath, or a chimera's elemental breath. Each creature’s breath weapon has specific effects, such as damage, paralysis, or petrification. A successful saving throw generally halves the damage or avoids the secondary effect (such as paralysis or petrification), while failure applies the full consequences. The target number for the saving throw is determined by the character’s class and level.
oAO6atDu0rDkRYWM.name: Dragon Breath

pJFpv3ztaIEvVWmr.description: Hobgoblins wear armor that provides a natural Armor Class of 6.
pJFpv3ztaIEvVWmr.name: Hobgoblin Armor
pJFpv3ztaIEvVWmr.unidentifiedDesc: Hobgoblins wear armor that provides a natural Armor Class of 6.

qEii0ARk0HDsMawC.description: The saving throw against "Stone or Paralysis" protects a character from attacks or effects that could freeze them in place (paralysis) or turn them into stone. If the saving throw is failed, the character becomes immobilized or petrified, depending on the effect. Paralysis leaves a character aware but unable to act, while petrification turns the character and their carried equipment into a stone statue. The duration or permanence of these effects is specified by the source, and successful saving throws avoid them entirely​​​.
qEii0ARk0HDsMawC.name: Turn to Stone or Paralysis

xuDw3NbLo1JF58jJ.description: The Death Ray or Poison saving throw is a roll made by a character to resist deadly effects like instant death or paralysis from poisons, spells, or traps. The player rolls a d20 and compares it to their class- and level-specific target number on the saving throw table; success means avoiding or mitigating the harm. A failed roll often results in death (for poison) or other severe consequences, though optional rules may instead inflict substantial damage​​​.
xuDw3NbLo1JF58jJ.name: Death Ray or Poison

Horde (11HD).biography:
"The hordes" are life forms native to the elemental plane of Earth. Each single life force has hundreds of separate insect-like bodies. The size of the bodies ranges from 3 to 21 feet long; the length corresponds to the Hit Dice (i.e., a 3-HD body will be 3 feet long). Details on the individual bodies are given above.

One horde life force can control up to 10,000 Hit Dice of bodies. Replacement bodies can be created at the rate of 1 Hit Die per turn. Unlike insects, there is no "queen" body: the life force is widely spread, occupying all the bodies evenly. The life force can only control bodies within a volume 100 miles across; if taken outside that range, a body becomes a mindless thing, dying in [[/r 1d10 #Days until death]] 1-10 days. Each planet in the realm of the hordes is occupied by [[/r 1d100 #Life forces]] life forces.

Each individual life force has its own name. All the bodies of a single life force will respond to the same name, and this can cause confusion in dealing with a horde creature. The creature itself can only die if all of its bodies are destroyed. The horde creatures do not consider any other life forms to be intelligent. When a horde needs more room, it will simply try to take it, without regard for other creatures; thus, they are considered evil. The horde creatures often grapple with each other in this war for living space.

A horde creature can use ESP and telekinesis (up to 2,000 cn) as often as desired, up to once per round. It communicates by telepathy, speaking directly to the minds of others. It is incredibly intelligent and can easily handle dozens of conversations at once.

Each horde is very Lawful and always dangerous. A horde creature sacrifices as many bodies as needed to reach a goal, and thus the morale of a body is 12. The creature is immune to all mental effects (charm, hold, sleep, etc.), but the bodies are susceptible to blows and damage-causing attacks of most types. Because of its disregard for individual bodies, a horde normally does not bother to attempt to save them; in play, it simply fails all saving throws voluntarily. However, if 10% or more of a horde's bodies are lost in a single activity (an encounter with enemies, for example), the creature will either resolve the problem peacefully (negotiating, avoiding, etc.) or call other hordes for assistance.

Each horde can have a different species of insect as its bodies. One horde might consist of bodies that look like huge gold praying mantises with wings, while another might consist of smallish black beetles with glowing red tips on their antennae.

The hordes' enemies are the kryst and the undines. They fear fire-type creatures and attacks.

Terrain: Plane of Earth.

Horse, Riding.biography:
Horses are four-legged equines already familiar to players. They're herbivores: they run wild in the plains and can be tamed as riding beasts.

This beast can carry a rider for a greater distance than any other type of horse. It is smaller and can exist wherever there is grass to feed on. Most wild horses on the plains fall into the "riding horse" category once tamed.

Terrain: Open.

Load: 3,000 cn of weight at normal rates, or 6,000 cn at half normal.

Barding Multiplier: x1.

0YcX9niwA5B3MryY.description: The saving throw against Breath Weapons is used to resist or mitigate the effects of a wide range of powerful exhaled attacks, not limited to dragons. This includes attacks like a dragon’s fiery or icy breath, a gorgon's petrifying breath, or a chimera's elemental breath. Each creature’s breath weapon has specific effects, such as damage, paralysis, or petrification. A successful saving throw generally halves the damage or avoids the secondary effect (such as paralysis or petrification), while failure applies the full consequences. The target number for the saving throw is determined by the character’s class and level.
0YcX9niwA5B3MryY.name: Dragon Breath

AzqAKFKWYNWaw205.description: The saving throw against "Stone or Paralysis" protects a character from attacks or effects that could freeze them in place (paralysis) or turn them into stone. If the saving throw is failed, the character becomes immobilized or petrified, depending on the effect. Paralysis leaves a character aware but unable to act, while petrification turns the character and their carried equipment into a stone statue. The duration or permanence of these effects is specified by the source, and successful saving throws avoid them entirely​​​.
AzqAKFKWYNWaw205.name: Turn to Stone or Paralysis

OuDAdmUqHSEQD8rq.description: The Magic Wand saving throw is used to avoid the effects of attacks or abilities activated through magical wands, such as paralysis rays or damage-dealing beams. A successful save, rolled on a d20, indicates that the character avoids or mitigates the harmful effects. The target number to save is determined by the character's class and level, as found on the saving throw table​​.
OuDAdmUqHSEQD8rq.name: Magic Wand

bzMhsK7od6fEDCCa.description: The saving throw for Spells or Magic Staff includes resistance against magical effects cast by rods, staves, wands, or through spells. A successful save, rolled on a d20, often reduces or negates the spell's effects entirely. This saving throw is applicable to numerous magical attacks, such as charm spells, fireballs, or paralysis effects, and covers damage, control, or debilitating conditions caused by magical devices or spellcasters. The target number for success is based on the character's class and level.
bzMhsK7od6fEDCCa.name: Spells or Magic Staff

voQ4tsDTcmMjVLyy.description: The Death Ray or Poison saving throw is a roll made by a character to resist deadly effects like instant death or paralysis from poisons, spells, or traps. The player rolls a d20 and compares it to their class- and level-specific target number on the saving throw table; success means avoiding or mitigating the harm. A failed roll often results in death (for poison) or other severe consequences, though optional rules may instead inflict substantial damage​​​.
voQ4tsDTcmMjVLyy.name: Death Ray or Poison

Human, Brigand.biography:
Brigands are loosely organized outlaws and renegade mercenaries who live by raiding towns and robbing caravans and travelers. Most are fighters with low levels of training and equipment.

Brigands often organize into camps of 50-300 men, with leaders who are higher-level fighters. For every 20 brigands, there is a 2nd-level fighter leader, and for every 40 brigands, there is a 4th-level commander.

Half of the brigands are mounted, wear chain mail, and carry shields and swords. The rest wear leather armor, carry shields, short bows, and swords. Leaders wear plate mail, carry swords and lances, and ride warhorses with barding.

Brigand Leaders: Brigand camps may be led by a 9th-level fighter and might include higher-level clerics or magic-users. There is a 50% chance of a 9th-11th level magic-user in the camp and a 30% chance of an 8th-level cleric.

Weapons and Armor: Half the brigands are equipped with leather armor and short bows; the rest ride horses with chain mail and shields.
Terrain: Wilderness (Any).

8pCcBZLE1v8CfXbI.description: A shield is a large solid piece of wood or metal that is either held in one hand or strapped to one arm. It is used to parry melee attacks and provide cover from missile attacks. A shield is normally used in conjunction with armor and provides and extra bonus of –1 to the character’s armor class. If used without other armor, a shield provides a bonus of –1 to a character’s natural armor class of 9, for a total armor class of 8. Wooden shields may be used by druids, since they are made primarily of natural materials.
