A4kRr2eEno0noOnG.description:
A character on foot armed with a spear, pike, sword, shield, or lance can set the weapon against a charge. A charge occurs when a monster rushes towards the character, covering at least 20 yards before attacking. This maneuver can also be used against another character's lance attack.

To "set vs. charge," the character braces the weapon against the ground, pointing it at the approaching enemy. Strength and magic bonuses apply to both the attack and damage rolls. If the attack is successful, the character deals double damage, with adjustments applied after doubling.

The character must declare the set vs. charge maneuver before entering melee combat with the charging opponent. For example, if the character’s party wins initiative and expects a charge, they can declare this maneuver. Similarly, if charging monsters are spotted several rounds in advance, the character can set their weapon against the charge ahead of time.

Typically, the attack is made during the monster's movement phase, as soon as it comes within weapon range. If the attack succeeds and kills the monster, it prevents the creature from attacking. If the attack does not kill the monster, it can then attack during its own melee phase of the combat sequence.
A4kRr2eEno0noOnG.name: Set Spear vs. Charge

Human, Buccaneer.biography:
Buccaneers are sea raiders who live by plundering coastal towns and capturing ships. They are usually Neutral fighters and are organized in crews aboard ships. The number of buccaneers depends on the ship size, ranging from 10 to 80 men per ship.

For every 30 buccaneers, there is a 4th-level fighter leader, while each ship has a 7th-level captain and a 9th-level commander. There is a 30% chance that a 10th-11th level magic-user is aboard with the commander, and a 25% chance of an 8th-level cleric.

Buccaneers wear **leather armor** and wield **swords**, and some may carry **crossbows**. They prefer to sell their loot at hidden ports.

Weapons and Armor: Leather armor, sword, and crossbow.
Special Organization: Ship-based crew with leadership based on ship size.
Terrain: Rivers, Lakes, Oceans.

Human, Dervish.biography:
Dervishes are desert raiders, fanatical in their beliefs and intolerant of other views. They often form large camps or tribes of up to 300 men, led by a 10th-level cleric. About 90% of dervishes are fighters, while the rest are clerics.

Dervish camps may be made of tents or wooden or brick stockades. These camps hold their women, children, livestock, and treasure. Dervishes may also wage holy wars to capture or kill those with different beliefs, offering captives the chance to convert or face death or enslavement.

Weapons and Armor: Dervishes typically wear leather armor and wield swords, spears, or scimitars.
Leadership: A dervish camp is led by a 10th-level cleric, with additional leaders depending on the size of the group.

cLrG8lbNXRJHfm9l.description: The saving throw against Breath Weapons is used to resist or mitigate the effects of a wide range of powerful exhaled attacks, not limited to dragons. This includes attacks like a dragon’s fiery or icy breath, a gorgon's petrifying breath, or a chimera's elemental breath. Each creature’s breath weapon has specific effects, such as damage, paralysis, or petrification. A successful saving throw generally halves the damage or avoids the secondary effect (such as paralysis or petrification), while failure applies the full consequences. The target number for the saving throw is determined by the character’s class and level.
cLrG8lbNXRJHfm9l.name: Dragon Breath

fbjmzNvG10kqWv8K.description: The saving throw against "Stone or Paralysis" protects a character from attacks or effects that could freeze them in place (paralysis) or turn them into stone. If the saving throw is failed, the character becomes immobilized or petrified, depending on the effect. Paralysis leaves a character aware but unable to act, while petrification turns the character and their carried equipment into a stone statue. The duration or permanence of these effects is specified by the source, and successful saving throws avoid them entirely​​​.
fbjmzNvG10kqWv8K.name: Turn to Stone or Paralysis

lyprgAHNPJ0tgNSK.description: The Death Ray or Poison saving throw is a roll made by a character to resist deadly effects like instant death or paralysis from poisons, spells, or traps. The player rolls a d20 and compares it to their class- and level-specific target number on the saving throw table; success means avoiding or mitigating the harm. A failed roll often results in death (for poison) or other severe consequences, though optional rules may instead inflict substantial damage​​​.
lyprgAHNPJ0tgNSK.name: Death Ray or Poison

Human, Noble.biography:
Nobles are members of the ruling class, often fighters of high skill and authority. They typically wear plate mail and carry shields, as well as the finest weapons available.

Nobles usually travel with a **squire** (a 2nd-level fighter), as well as **retainers** and **hirelings** of various types, who handle their affairs. Their social rank may range from barons to dukes, and their titles depend on the campaign setting.

When encountered, a noble may be part of a larger retinue or military force, often in command of several other men.

Hit Dice: 3-8
Weapons and Armor: Plate mail armor and shield.
Special Organization: Accompanied by a squire and potentially up to 12 retainers or hirelings.
Terrain: Any.

9mtO8NYtcH99iLXj.description: When mounted and using a lance, a character can perform a powerful charge attack. If the attack is successful, the character gains double their Strength modifier to the damage roll. This ability is most effective when charging against opponents.
9mtO8NYtcH99iLXj.name: Lance Attack

D0PvrDyEucDF48bt.description: The saving throw for Spells or Magic Staff includes resistance against magical effects cast by rods, staves, wands, or through spells. A successful save, rolled on a d20, often reduces or negates the spell's effects entirely. This saving throw is applicable to numerous magical attacks, such as charm spells, fireballs, or paralysis effects, and covers damage, control, or debilitating conditions caused by magical devices or spellcasters. The target number for success is based on the character's class and level.
D0PvrDyEucDF48bt.name: Spells or Magic Staff

SjmxSOPDAjdo3gEt.description: A shield is a large solid piece of wood or metal that is either held in one hand or strapped to one arm. It is used to parry melee attacks and provide cover from missile attacks. A shield is normally used in conjunction with armor and provides and extra bonus of –1 to the character’s armor class. If used without other armor, a shield provides a bonus of –1 to a character’s natural armor class of 9, for a total armor class of 8. Wooden shields may be used by druids, since they are made primarily of natural materials.

e4PfDG3Ezuo0WDAF.description:
A character on foot armed with a spear, pike, sword, shield, or lance can set the weapon against a charge. A charge occurs when a monster rushes towards the character, covering at least 20 yards before attacking. This maneuver can also be used against another character's lance attack.

To "set vs. charge," the character braces the weapon against the ground, pointing it at the approaching enemy. Strength and magic bonuses apply to both the attack and damage rolls. If the attack is successful, the character deals double damage, with adjustments applied after doubling.

The character must declare the set vs. charge maneuver before entering melee combat with the charging opponent. For example, if the character’s party wins initiative and expects a charge, they can declare this maneuver. Similarly, if charging monsters are spotted several rounds in advance, the character can set their weapon against the charge ahead of time.

Typically, the attack is made during the monster's movement phase, as soon as it comes within weapon range. If the attack succeeds and kills the monster, it prevents the creature from attacking. If the attack does not kill the monster, it can then attack during its own melee phase of the combat sequence.
e4PfDG3Ezuo0WDAF.name: Set Spear vs. Charge

Human, Nomad.biography:
Nomads are wandering tribespeople, often seen in the desert or steppes. They may be peaceful traders or fierce raiders, depending on their alignment. Small groups of nomads may be found hunting or foraging, while larger groups form large camps, with leaders of higher levels guiding them.

Desert nomads are often mounted on camels or horses, equipped with lances, bows, and leather armor. Steppe nomads similarly favor bows, leather armor, and lances, but are mounted on horses.

For every 25 nomads, there is a 2nd-level fighter leader, while for every 40, there is a 4th-level fighter. Larger groups may be led by a 5th-level or 8th-level chieftain, with clerics and magic-users also sometimes present.

Weapons and Armor: Lances, bows, and leather armor.
Leadership: Nomad bands may be led by higher-level fighters, clerics, and magic-users, depending on the size of the group.
Terrain: Desert, Steppe.

Human, Pirate.biography:
Pirates are sea raiders who engage in plundering ships and coastal towns. They are often Chaotic fighters known for their cruelty and lawlessness. Pirates are organized into crews based on ship size, with 10 to 80 pirates per ship.

For every 30 pirates, there is a 4th-level fighter leader, and each ship has a 5th-level captain. For every fleet of 100 or more pirates, there is an 8th-level commander. Larger pirate fleets may also include an 11th-level Pirate Lord, with a 75% chance of an accompanying 9th-10th level magic-user.

Pirates often wear **leather armor**, wield **swords**, and some may carry **crossbows**. Pirates may carry treasure with them or have maps to buried treasure.

Weapons and Armor: Leather armor, sword, and crossbow.
Special Organization: Ship-based crew with leadership based on ship size.
Terrain: Rivers, Lakes, Oceans.

Human, Trader.biography:
Traders are merchants who travel in caravans between cities, buying and selling various goods such as wines, silks, jewels, and precious metals. They typically wear chain mail and carry a sword and dagger for protection.

Traders often organize themselves in caravans, consisting of several merchants and fighters for protection. The fighters wear chain mail and wield swords, daggers, and crossbows. The number of traders appearing in a caravan depends on the size of the caravan, which may range from small groups to large organized caravans with numerous wagons.

Weapons and Armor: Chain mail armor, sword, and dagger.
Organization: Traders travel in caravans, with fighters providing protection and animals carrying goods.
Terrain: Any (between cities).

Hydra (10HD).biography:
The hydra is a massive beast with a dragon-like body and multiple heads resembling snakes. Each hydra has between 5 and 12 heads, with one Hit Die and 8 hit points per head. The hydra attacks ferociously, using each of its heads every round. If a hydra loses a head, the damage it takes determines how many heads remain in the fight.

For every 8 points of damage taken, one of the hydra's heads is destroyed, reducing its ability to attack. For example, a hydra with 7 heads that takes 16 points of damage will lose two heads and attack with only five heads the following round.

Hydras can be found guarding treasures in remote and dangerous locations. While most hydras are found in swamps or other wilderness areas, variations of this creature exist with specialized abilities.

Terrain: Swamp.

Hydra, Regenerating (7HD).biography:
The hydra is a massive beast with a dragon-like body and multiple heads resembling snakes. Each hydra has between 5 and 12 heads, with one Hit Die and 8 hit points per head. The hydra attacks ferociously, using each of its heads every round. If a hydra loses a head, the damage it takes determines how many heads remain in the fight.

For every 8 points of damage taken, one of the hydra's heads is destroyed, reducing its ability to attack. For example, a hydra with 7 heads that takes 16 points of damage will lose two heads and attack with only five heads the following round.

Hydras can be found guarding treasures in remote and dangerous locations. While most hydras are found in swamps or other wilderness areas, variations of this creature exist with specialized abilities.

Terrain: Swamp.

Hydrax*.biography:
A hydrax is an intelligent, crablike being formed entirely of ice. Native to the elemental plane of Water, it is seldom seen on the Prime Plane. This creature resembles a giant crab with an 8-foot-long body, six legs, and three claws evenly arranged around its form. Although hydrax display Lawful behavior, the majority are inherently evil.

Hydrax are immune to conventional weapons, all 1st and 2nd level spells, and any attacks based on fire. They can detect invisible creatures at will and are capable of casting detect magic, web, dispel magic, ice storm/wall, and water to ice—much like the reverse of a magic-user's dissolve spell (substituting water and ice for mud and rock)—three times per day, as if cast by a 9th level magic-user.

Using tools fashioned from ice, hydrax construct intricate cities and various devices. Their principal adversaries are the undines and the kryst, and they harbor a deep-seated fear of air-type creatures and assaults.

Terrain: Plane of Water

Insect Swarm (2 HD).biography:
An insect swarm is a mass of small insects acting together as a single force. The swarm may fill a 10' x 10' x 30' area or larger, consisting of either crawling or flying insects, or a mix of both. These swarms may be drawn to light, strange smells, or may be defending a lair, such as a hive or nest.

The swarm does not make an attack roll, as it is an area effect attack that automatically hits. All armored characters and monsters with AC 5 or better take 2 points of damage per round. Unarmored characters or monsters with AC 6 or worse take 4 points of damage per round.

A victim who takes the time to swat at the insects (using a weapon or torch) instead of attacking or performing another action takes only 1 point of damage per round. Characters trying to swat with their hands or arms are ineffective.

If a swarm is attacked, it will relentlessly pursue its attacker. Victims can escape by disappearing from sight (such as with invisibility, moving around a corner, etc.) or by diving underwater, which kills all the insects after one round (normal damage applies during this round).

Terrain: Any (except Arctic)

Insect Swarm (4 HD).biography:
An insect swarm is a mass of small insects acting together as a single force. The swarm may fill a 10' x 10' x 30' area or larger, consisting of either crawling or flying insects, or a mix of both. These swarms may be drawn to light, strange smells, or may be defending a lair, such as a hive or nest.

The swarm does not make an attack roll, as it is an area effect attack that automatically hits. All armored characters and monsters with AC 5 or better take 2 points of damage per round. Unarmored characters or monsters with AC 6 or worse take 4 points of damage per round.

A victim who takes the time to swat at the insects (using a weapon or torch) instead of attacking or performing another action takes only 1 point of damage per round. Characters trying to swat with their hands or arms are ineffective.

If a swarm is attacked, it will relentlessly pursue its attacker. Victims can escape by disappearing from sight (such as with invisibility, moving around a corner, etc.) or by diving underwater, which kills all the insects after one round (normal damage applies during this round).

Invisible Stalker (Sshai).biography:
An Invisible Stalker (Sshai) is a magical, humanlike entity summoned from another plane via the invisible stalker spell. When given a clear and straightforward command, it obeys without hesitation; however, if the assignment is ambiguous or prolonged, it may twist the intent while following the literal wording—for example, guarding a treasure for over a week might result in it transporting the treasure back to its native plane to guard indefinitely.

Primarily employed to track and eliminate foes, this creature is not only highly intelligent but also an impeccable tracker. Should a target be unable to detect invisible entities, the stalker will launch a surprise attack on a roll of 1-5 (on [[/r 1d6 #Surprise on 1-5]]). Conversely, any creature capable of perceiving invisibility gains a +4 bonus when attacking it. Once its mission is complete, or if it is slain or dispelled, the stalker promptly returns to its home plane.

The term "invisible stalkers" is the human designation for this species, though they call themselves the sshai. Native to the elemental plane of Air, the sshai move with exceptional speed on their home plane—reaching 360' (120'). There, they resemble dopplegangers, possessing the ability to use ESP at will and to shapechange into nearly any form native to that plane, typically appearing as air elementals, djinn, or haoou (aerial servants). While their true form is nearly identical to an air elemental, subtle differences remain discernible. The sshai are sometimes employed by djinn and haoou as spies or guards, and in their own realm, they typically possess between 1 and 12 Hit Dice while remaining roughly man-sized. Although some may even wield spells, they generally prefer negotiation to combat and have few enemies—except for their notable apprehension toward earth-type creatures and attacks.

Terrain: Any; Plane of Air

These creatures have an intense hatred for gnomes and attack them on sight. Some kobolds possess magical talent, with spellcasters existing among their ranks.

Kryst*.biography:
Kryst are sentient beings composed entirely of crystalline rock, each appearing as a cluster of twelve gleaming golden crystal spikes radiating from a central core. Native to the elemental plane of Earth, they exude a distinctive, angular beauty.

They are immune to poison, standard weapons, all 1st and 2nd level spells, and any attack derived from air. A kryst can detect invisible creatures at will and is capable of casting detect magic, dispel magic, haste, or an 'air to earth' spell—similar to a magic-user's dissolve spell that transforms air into earth—three times per day, all as if cast by a 9th level magic-user. They communicate telepathically over a range of 120 feet or, if mental contact proves adverse, via written messages.

In combat, a kryst ram its foes with its crystal spikes, launching up to three attacks per round. Each spike functions as a natural weapon.

Beyond the battlefield, the kryst maintain a widespread and intricate society within their own realms, coexisting peacefully with earth elementals. They welcome visitors and eagerly seek new knowledge, yet they wage an unending war against the hordes and strive to unite other creatures against them. They are also known to oppose the hydrax—though encounters are rare—and harbor a deep-seated fear of water-based creatures and attacks.

Terrain: Plane of Earth

49L1pMgbauXIVMEu.description:
A Magic-User can attempt to create a new spell, but it must be of a level they can cast. The process requires:

  • 1,000 gp per spell level
  • Two weeks of research per spell level
  • Rare components, often requiring an adventure to obtain
  • A fully stocked laboratory or library

The chance of success depends on the Magic-User's Intelligence score and level, with modifications for spell difficulty​. If a research attempt fails, the process must be restarted, but each failure grants a +5% cumulative bonus to future attempts.

A Magic-User typically does not have a sufficient library for advanced research until 18th level, or at least 9th level if they have collected extensive magical tomes​. While research is technically possible at any level, low-level characters will likely struggle to meet the requirements.
49L1pMgbauXIVMEu.name: Spell Research

55vAZ8qW3TqUOuwE.description: A razor-sharp crystal spike used to ram opponents.

G6AhOk6vLWuGvKdL.description:
Magic-Users harness arcane energy through intense study and careful memorization of spells recorded in their spellbooks. Unlike Clerics, who receive divine magic, Magic-Users must prepare spells in advance by studying their books each day. Once a spell is cast, it is erased from memory until re-memorized.

Magic-Users have a limited selection of spells they can prepare per day, increasing as they gain levels. Their spells range from minor utilities such as Read Magic to devastating attacks like Fireball and reality-warping incantations at higher levels​.

Because of their reliance on spellbooks, Magic-Users must protect and expand their libraries, seeking out lost tomes, scrolls, and ancient knowledge to improve their magical repertoire.

Each creature’s breath weapon has specific effects, such as damage, paralysis, or petrification. A successful saving throw generally halves the damage or avoids the secondary effect (such as paralysis or petrification), while failure applies the full consequences. KoUkq0eWMLrBqHXL.description:
Upon reaching 9th level, a Magic-User may choose to build a tower, establishing themselves as a land-owning wizard. Unlike Fighters or Clerics, a Magic-User does not need permission from the local ruler to construct a stronghold, as rulers generally avoid antagonizing powerful wizards​.

Attracting Apprentices

Once a tower is built, the Magic-User will attract 1d6 apprentices, all Magic-Users of levels 1–3. These apprentices seek training, and while they are loyal, they will not sacrifice themselves for their master. The DM determines their names, backgrounds, and personalities​.

Stronghold and Dungeon Construction

A wizard's tower may include a dungeon beneath or near it. Some wizards construct dungeons as secure laboratories, while others leave an opening, attracting wandering monsters that take up residence. Some wizards encourage this, using monsters for research, spell experimentation, or personal defense​. However, monster-infested dungeons often cause conflict with local communities and attract adventurers seeking treasure.

Alternative to a Tower: Becoming a Magist

Instead of building a tower, a Name-level Magic-User may seek employment as a Magist in an existing stronghold. A Magist serves a ruler as an advisor on magical matters, handles magical needs, and is well-compensated—typically at least 3,000 gp per month. However, this requires the Magic-User to swear an oath of fealty to the ruler​.

Would you like additional details, such as construction costs or typical tower layouts?
KoUkq0eWMLrBqHXL.name: Establish Tower

A failed roll often results in death (for poison) or other severe consequences, though optional rules may instead inflict substantial damage​​​.

Paralysis leaves a character aware but unable to act, while petrification turns the character and their carried equipment into a stone statue. sZ137KXyp14k4F67.description:
At 9th level, a Magic-User can begin crafting magic items, but only items usable by Magic-Users. The process involves:

  • Gathering rare materials related to the item's magic (e.g., dragon scales for fire resistance)
  • Spending time and gold to craft and enchant the item
  • A base cost of 500 gp per spell level for items that duplicate spell effects
  • A 15% minimum chance of failure, determined at the end of the process​

Scrolls and potions are the easiest to create, while more powerful items require months of work and possibly special rituals. The DM may set additional requirements for powerful magic items, such as needing a specific location or celestial alignment​.

Lava Ooze.biography:
This creature is a formless mass of searing, molten rock that resembles either a stagnant puddle or a streaming ribbon, spanning roughly 10' x 10'. It typically inhabits areas near active volcanoes or other regions marked by extreme heat, and although it originates from the Prime Plane, it can also thrive on the elemental plane of Fire.

The lava ooze is exceptionally fluid, capable of squeezing through even the narrowest crevices, and it detects vibrations within a 60' radius. In combat, it projects up to three pseudopods per round that can reach targets up to 15' away. Each pseudopod strike deals [[/r 4d6 #strike damage]] points of damage and leaves a burning layer of lava on the target, which then inflicts an additional [[/r 3d6 #Heat damage]] points of heat damage per round for [[/r 1d4 #rounds]]. While multiple strikes on the same foe do not increase the per-round heat damage, their durations do stack.

This mindless ooze relentlessly attacks until it is destroyed. It is immune to both natural and magical fire as well as to all mind-affecting attacks (such as charm or ESP), but it takes double damage from cold-based assaults.

Terrain: Mountain (volcanic)

Lich, Cleric (21HD)*.biography:
A lich is a powerful undead monster of magical origin. It looks like a skeleton wearing fine garments and was once an evil and chaotic magic-user or cleric of level 21 or greater (often 27-36). A lich is still able to use spells as it did while alive, making it extremely dangerous. A lich is not normally found wandering but instead remains in or very near a well-defended lair, which might be a dungeon, catacomb, tomb, or necropolis ("city of the dead").

The very sight of a lich causes fear in all characters below 5th level (no saving throw). Its mere touch causes [[/r 1d10 #Touch damage]] points of damage and can paralyze any creature for [[/r 1d100 #Paralyzed for this many days]] days (though a saving throw applies, and the paralysis is magically dispellable).

Before any encounter with a lich, the DM should select spells for the creature with care, as a lich is extremely intelligent and uses them to its best advantage. Note that the lich's morale is given as 10, but a lich flees if in actual danger.

Liches are undead and can be turned (but not destroyed) by clerics. They are immune to charm, sleep, feeblemind, polymorph, cold, lightning, and death spells, and can be harmed only by magical weapons. They are also immune to the effects of all spells of less than 4th level. Outside of its lair, a lich always carries [[/r 1d4 + 1 #Powerful items]] powerful magical items to be used in case of trouble. These should be chosen, not randomly determined. Within its lair, a lich has 4d8 additional temporary magical items (or more), plus the amounts of coins, gems, and jewelry given for Treasure Type H in Chapter 16 (with a 90% chance for each type). The number and severity of traps and other dangers to intruders should be appropriate to protect such a hoard.

A magic-user lich normally has [[/r 1d2 #Spells]] spells of a permanent nature, most often detect invisible or fly. A clerical lich normally has [[/r 3d4 #Types of undead lairs nearby]] types of other undead nearby, acting as servants, with a full lair of each type (maximum number appearing) usually present.

Either type of lich can summon other powerful undead for aid. The summons can be made simply by concentrating, and the creature(s) responding arrive [[/r 1d100 #rounds]] rounds later, depending on their distance. The summons may be made as often as desired, but any one type of creature will respond only once per day at most. To randomly determine the creatures appearing in response to the summons, roll [[/r 1d20 #See lich summon table for result]] and refer to the table. Roll again if a type of creature has already responded that day.

Notes:

  • 7, 9, or 11: Number needed to turn successfully.
  • T: Automatic turn; turns 2d6 Hit Dice of undead.
  • D: Automatic destroy; destroys 2d6 Hit Dice of undead.
  • D+: Automatic destroy; destroys 3d6 Hit Dice of undead.

Clerics have the divine power to repel or even destroy certain undead creatures, such as skeletons, zombies, and more powerful types. This ability is known as Turn Undead. When encountering these undead beings, the cleric can choose to either engage them in combat with weapons or spells, or attempt to turn them.

To turn undead, the cleric simply announces the intention to do so to the Dungeon Master. No holy symbol or other item is needed unless the DM specifies otherwise. The success of this attempt depends on the cleric’s level and the type of undead faced, as indicated on the Turning Undead table.

If the cleric succeeds, one or more undead creatures will flee or be destroyed immediately, depending on the result. However, a failed attempt means that particular undead creature cannot be turned by the cleric again during the same encounter. Multiple attempts are allowed in future encounters.

Should the attempt succeed, the Dungeon Master rolls to determine how many Hit Dice worth of undead are turned. At least one undead creature will always be affected. A turned undead creature will retreat as far as possible, but it has not been destroyed and may return after some time.

Lich, Cleric (23HD)*.biography:
A lich is a powerful undead monster of magical origin. It looks like a skeleton wearing fine garments and was once an evil and chaotic magic-user or cleric of level 21 or greater (often 27-36). A lich is still able to use spells as it did while alive, making it extremely dangerous. A lich is not normally found wandering but instead remains in or very near a well-defended lair, which might be a dungeon, catacomb, tomb, or necropolis ("city of the dead").

The very sight of a lich causes fear in all characters below 5th level (no saving throw). Its mere touch causes [[/r 1d10 #Touch damage]] points of damage and can paralyze any creature for [[/r 1d100 #Paralyzed for this many days]] days (though a saving throw applies, and the paralysis is magically dispellable).

Before any encounter with a lich, the DM should select spells for the creature with care, as a lich is extremely intelligent and uses them to its best advantage. Note that the lich's morale is given as 10, but a lich flees if in actual danger.

Liches are undead and can be turned (but not destroyed) by clerics. They are immune to charm, sleep, feeblemind, polymorph, cold, lightning, and death spells, and can be harmed only by magical weapons. They are also immune to the effects of all spells of less than 4th level. Outside of its lair, a lich always carries [[/r 1d4 + 1 #Powerful items]] powerful magical items to be used in case of trouble. These should be chosen, not randomly determined. Within its lair, a lich has 4d8 additional temporary magical items (or more), plus the amounts of coins, gems, and jewelry given for Treasure Type H in Chapter 16 (with a 90% chance for each type). The number and severity of traps and other dangers to intruders should be appropriate to protect such a hoard.

A magic-user lich normally has [[/r 1d2 #Spells]] spells of a permanent nature, most often detect invisible or fly. A clerical lich normally has [[/r 3d4 #Types of undead lairs nearby]] types of other undead nearby, acting as servants, with a full lair of each type (maximum number appearing) usually present.

Either type of lich can summon other powerful undead for aid. The summons can be made simply by concentrating, and the creature(s) responding arrive [[/r 1d100 #rounds]] rounds later, depending on their distance. The summons may be made as often as desired, but any one type of creature will respond only once per day at most. To randomly determine the creatures appearing in response to the summons, roll [[/r 1d20 #See lich summon table for result]] and refer to the table. Roll again if a type of creature has already responded that day.

Lich, Cleric (25HD)*.biography:
A lich is a powerful undead monster of magical origin. It looks like a skeleton wearing fine garments and was once an evil and chaotic magic-user or cleric of level 21 or greater (often 27-36). A lich is still able to use spells as it did while alive, making it extremely dangerous. A lich is not normally found wandering but instead remains in or very near a well-defended lair, which might be a dungeon, catacomb, tomb, or necropolis ("city of the dead").

The very sight of a lich causes fear in all characters below 5th level (no saving throw). Its mere touch causes [[/r 1d10 #Touch damage]] points of damage and can paralyze any creature for [[/r 1d100 #Paralyzed for this many days]] days (though a saving throw applies, and the paralysis is magically dispellable).

Before any encounter with a lich, the DM should select spells for the creature with care, as a lich is extremely intelligent and uses them to its best advantage. Note that the lich's morale is given as 10, but a lich flees if in actual danger.

Liches are undead and can be turned (but not destroyed) by clerics. They are immune to charm, sleep, feeblemind, polymorph, cold, lightning, and death spells, and can be harmed only by magical weapons. They are also immune to the effects of all spells of less than 4th level. Outside of its lair, a lich always carries [[/r 1d4 + 1 #Powerful items]] powerful magical items to be used in case of trouble. These should be chosen, not randomly determined. Within its lair, a lich has 4d8 additional temporary magical items (or more), plus the amounts of coins, gems, and jewelry given for Treasure Type H in Chapter 16 (with a 90% chance for each type). The number and severity of traps and other dangers to intruders should be appropriate to protect such a hoard.

A magic-user lich normally has [[/r 1d2 #Spells]] spells of a permanent nature, most often detect invisible or fly. A clerical lich normally has [[/r 3d4 #Types of undead lairs nearby]] types of other undead nearby, acting as servants, with a full lair of each type (maximum number appearing) usually present.

Either type of lich can summon other powerful undead for aid. The summons can be made simply by concentrating, and the creature(s) responding arrive [[/r 1d100 #rounds]] rounds later, depending on their distance. The summons may be made as often as desired, but any one type of creature will respond only once per day at most. Clerics have the divine power to repel or even destroy certain undead creatures, such as skeletons, zombies, and more powerful types. This ability is known as Turn Undead. When encountering these undead beings, the cleric can choose to either engage them in combat with weapons or spells, or attempt to turn them.

To turn undead, the cleric simply announces the intention to do so to the Dungeon Master. No holy symbol or other item is needed unless the DM specifies otherwise. The success of this attempt depends on the cleric’s level and the type of undead faced, as indicated on the Turning Undead table.

If the cleric succeeds, one or more undead creatures will flee or be destroyed immediately, depending on the result. However, a failed attempt means that particular undead creature cannot be turned by the cleric again during the same encounter. Multiple attempts are allowed in future encounters.

Should the attempt succeed, the Dungeon Master rolls to determine how many Hit Dice worth of undead are turned. At least one undead creature will always be affected. A turned undead creature will retreat as far as possible, but it has not been destroyed and may return after some time.

Lich, Cleric (28HD)*.biography:
A lich is a powerful undead monster of magical origin. It looks like a skeleton wearing fine garments and was once an evil and chaotic magic-user or cleric of level 21 or greater (often 27-36). A lich is still able to use spells as it did while alive, making it extremely dangerous. A lich is not normally found wandering but instead remains in or very near a well-defended lair, which might be a dungeon, catacomb, tomb, or necropolis ("city of the dead").

The very sight of a lich causes fear in all characters below 5th level (no saving throw). Its mere touch causes [[/r 1d10 #Touch damage]] points of damage and can paralyze any creature for [[/r 1d100 #Paralyzed for this many days]] days (though a saving throw applies, and the paralysis is magically dispellable).

Before any encounter with a lich, the DM should select spells for the creature with care, as a lich is extremely intelligent and uses them to its best advantage. Note that the lich's morale is given as 10, but a lich flees if in actual danger.

Liches are undead and can be turned (but not destroyed) by clerics. They are immune to charm, sleep, feeblemind, polymorph, cold, lightning, and death spells, and can be harmed only by magical weapons. They are also immune to the effects of all spells of less than 4th level. Outside of its lair, a lich always carries [[/r 1d4 + 1 #Powerful items]] powerful magical items to be used in case of trouble. These should be chosen, not randomly determined. Within its lair, a lich has 4d8 additional temporary magical items (or more), plus the amounts of coins, gems, and jewelry given for Treasure Type H in Chapter 16 (with a 90% chance for each type). The number and severity of traps and other dangers to intruders should be appropriate to protect such a hoard.

A magic-user lich normally has [[/r 1d2 #Spells]] spells of a permanent nature, most often detect invisible or fly. A clerical lich normally has [[/r 3d4 #Types of undead lairs nearby]] types of other undead nearby, acting as servants, with a full lair of each type (maximum number appearing) usually present.

Either type of lich can summon other powerful undead for aid. The summons can be made simply by concentrating, and the creature(s) responding arrive [[/r 1d100 #rounds]] rounds later, depending on their distance. The summons may be made as often as desired, but any one type of creature will respond only once per day at most. To randomly determine the creatures appearing in response to the summons, roll [[/r 1d20 #See lich summon table for result]] and refer to the table. Roll again if a type of creature has already responded that day.

Lich, Cleric (30HD)*.biography:
A lich is a powerful undead monster of magical origin. It looks like a skeleton wearing fine garments and was once an evil and chaotic magic-user or cleric of level 21 or greater (often 27-36). A lich is still able to use spells as it did while alive, making it extremely dangerous. A lich is not normally found wandering but instead remains in or very near a well-defended lair, which might be a dungeon, catacomb, tomb, or necropolis ("city of the dead").

The very sight of a lich causes fear in all characters below 5th level (no saving throw). Its mere touch causes [[/r 1d10 #Touch damage]] points of damage and can paralyze any creature for [[/r 1d100 #Paralyzed for this many days]] days (though a saving throw applies, and the paralysis is magically dispellable).

Before any encounter with a lich, the DM should select spells for the creature with care, as a lich is extremely intelligent and uses them to its best advantage. Note that the lich's morale is given as 10, but a lich flees if in actual danger.

Liches are undead and can be turned (but not destroyed) by clerics. They are immune to charm, sleep, feeblemind, polymorph, cold, lightning, and death spells, and can be harmed only by magical weapons. They are also immune to the effects of all spells of less than 4th level. Outside of its lair, a lich always carries [[/r 1d4 + 1 #Powerful items]] powerful magical items to be used in case of trouble. These should be chosen, not randomly determined. Within its lair, a lich has 4d8 additional temporary magical items (or more), plus the amounts of coins, gems, and jewelry given for Treasure Type H in Chapter 16 (with a 90% chance for each type). The number and severity of traps and other dangers to intruders should be appropriate to protect such a hoard.

A magic-user lich normally has [[/r 1d2 #Spells]] spells of a permanent nature, most often detect invisible or fly. A clerical lich normally has [[/r 3d4 #Types of undead lairs nearby]] types of other undead nearby, acting as servants, with a full lair of each type (maximum number appearing) usually present.

Either type of lich can summon other powerful undead for aid. The summons can be made simply by concentrating, and the creature(s) responding arrive [[/r 1d100 #rounds]] rounds later, depending on their distance. The summons may be made as often as desired, but any one type of creature will respond only once per day at most. To randomly determine the creatures appearing in response to the summons, roll [[/r 1d20 #See lich summon table for result]] and refer to the table. Roll again if a type of creature has already responded that day.

Clerics have the divine power to repel or even destroy certain undead creatures, such as skeletons, zombies, and more powerful types. This ability is known as Turn Undead. When encountering these undead beings, the cleric can choose to either engage them in combat with weapons or spells, or attempt to turn them.

To turn undead, the cleric simply announces the intention to do so to the Dungeon Master. No holy symbol or other item is needed unless the DM specifies otherwise. The success of this attempt depends on the cleric’s level and the type of undead faced, as indicated on the Turning Undead table.

If the cleric succeeds, one or more undead creatures will flee or be destroyed immediately, depending on the result. However, a failed attempt means that particular undead creature cannot be turned by the cleric again during the same encounter. Multiple attempts are allowed in future encounters.

Should the attempt succeed, the Dungeon Master rolls to determine how many Hit Dice worth of undead are turned. At least one undead creature will always be affected. A turned undead creature will retreat as far as possible, but it has not been destroyed and may return after some time.

Lich, Cleric (33HD)*.biography:
A lich is a powerful undead monster of magical origin. It looks like a skeleton wearing fine garments and was once an evil and chaotic magic-user or cleric of level 21 or greater (often 27-36). A lich is still able to use spells as it did while alive, making it extremely dangerous. A lich is not normally found wandering but instead remains in or very near a well-defended lair, which might be a dungeon, catacomb, tomb, or necropolis ("city of the dead").

The very sight of a lich causes fear in all characters below 5th level (no saving throw). Its mere touch causes [[/r 1d10 #Touch damage]] points of damage and can paralyze any creature for [[/r 1d100 #Paralyzed for this many days]] days (though a saving throw applies, and the paralysis is magically dispellable).

Before any encounter with a lich, the DM should select spells for the creature with care, as a lich is extremely intelligent and uses them to its best advantage. Note that the lich's morale is given as 10, but a lich flees if in actual danger.

Liches are undead and can be turned (but not destroyed) by clerics. They are immune to charm, sleep, feeblemind, polymorph, cold, lightning, and death spells, and can be harmed only by magical weapons. They are also immune to the effects of all spells of less than 4th level. Outside of its lair, a lich always carries [[/r 1d4 + 1 #Powerful items]] powerful magical items to be used in case of trouble. These should be chosen, not randomly determined. Within its lair, a lich has 4d8 additional temporary magical items (or more), plus the amounts of coins, gems, and jewelry given for Treasure Type H in Chapter 16 (with a 90% chance for each type). The number and severity of traps and other dangers to intruders should be appropriate to protect such a hoard.

A magic-user lich normally has [[/r 1d2 #Spells]] spells of a permanent nature, most often detect invisible or fly. A clerical lich normally has [[/r 3d4 #Types of undead lairs nearby]] types of other undead nearby, acting as servants, with a full lair of each type (maximum number appearing) usually present.

Either type of lich can summon other powerful undead for aid. The summons can be made simply by concentrating, and the creature(s) responding arrive [[/r 1d100 #rounds]] rounds later, depending on their distance. The summons may be made as often as desired, but any one type of creature will respond only once per day at most. To randomly determine the creatures appearing in response to the summons, roll [[/r 1d20 #See lich summon table for result]] and refer to the table. Roll again if a type of creature has already responded that day.

A lich is still able to use spells as it did while alive, making it extremely dangerous. A lich is not normally found wandering but instead remains in or very near a well-defended lair, which might be a dungeon, catacomb, tomb, or necropolis ("city of the dead").

The very sight of a lich causes fear in all characters below 5th level (no saving throw). Its mere touch causes [[/r 1d10 #Touch damage]] points of damage and can paralyze any creature for [[/r 1d100 #Paralyzed for this many days]] days (though a saving throw applies, and the paralysis is magically dispellable).

Before any encounter with a lich, the DM should select spells for the creature with care, as a lich is extremely intelligent and uses them to its best advantage. Note that the lich's morale is given as 10, but a lich flees if in actual danger.

Liches are undead and can be turned (but not destroyed) by clerics. They are immune to charm, sleep, feeblemind, polymorph, cold, lightning, and death spells, and can be harmed only by magical weapons. They are also immune to the effects of all spells of less than 4th level. Outside of its lair, a lich always carries [[/r 1d4 + 1 #Powerful items]] powerful magical items to be used in case of trouble. These should be chosen, not randomly determined. Within its lair, a lich has 4d8 additional temporary magical items (or more), plus the amounts of coins, gems, and jewelry given for Treasure Type H in Chapter 16 (with a 90% chance for each type). The number and severity of traps and other dangers to intruders should be appropriate to protect such a hoard.

A magic-user lich normally has [[/r 1d2 #Spells]] spells of a permanent nature, most often detect invisible or fly. A clerical lich normally has [[/r 3d4 #Types of undead lairs nearby]] types of other undead nearby, acting as servants, with a full lair of each type (maximum number appearing) usually present.

Either type of lich can summon other powerful undead for aid. The summons can be made simply by concentrating, and the creature(s) responding arrive [[/r 1d100 #rounds]] rounds later, depending on their distance. The summons may be made as often as desired, but any one type of creature will respond only once per day at most. To randomly determine the creatures appearing in response to the summons, roll [[/r 1d20 #See lich summon table for result]] and refer to the table. Roll again if a type of creature has already responded that day.

Clerics have the divine power to repel or even destroy certain undead creatures, such as skeletons, zombies, and more powerful types. This ability is known as Turn Undead. When encountering these undead beings, the cleric can choose to either engage them in combat with weapons or spells, or attempt to turn them.

To turn undead, the cleric simply announces the intention to do so to the Dungeon Master. No holy symbol or other item is needed unless the DM specifies otherwise. The success of this attempt depends on the cleric’s level and the type of undead faced, as indicated on the Turning Undead table.

If the cleric succeeds, one or more undead creatures will flee or be destroyed immediately, depending on the result. However, a failed attempt means that particular undead creature cannot be turned by the cleric again during the same encounter. Multiple attempts are allowed in future encounters.

Should the attempt succeed, the Dungeon Master rolls to determine how many Hit Dice worth of undead are turned. At least one undead creature will always be affected. A turned undead creature will retreat as far as possible, but it has not been destroyed and may return after some time.

25m1OnivKJJKH2RW.description:
Upon reaching 9th level, a Magic-User may choose to build a tower, establishing themselves as a land-owning wizard. Unlike Fighters or Clerics, a Magic-User does not need permission from the local ruler to construct a stronghold, as rulers generally avoid antagonizing powerful wizards​.

Attracting Apprentices

Once a tower is built, the Magic-User will attract 1d6 apprentices, all Magic-Users of levels 1–3. These apprentices seek training, and while they are loyal, they will not sacrifice themselves for their master. The DM determines their names, backgrounds, and personalities​.

Stronghold and Dungeon Construction

A wizard's tower may include a dungeon beneath or near it. Some wizards construct dungeons as secure laboratories, while others leave an opening, attracting wandering monsters that take up residence. Some wizards encourage this, using monsters for research, spell experimentation, or personal defense​. However, monster-infested dungeons often cause conflict with local communities and attract adventurers seeking treasure.

Alternative to a Tower: Becoming a Magist

Instead of building a tower, a Name-level Magic-User may seek employment as a Magist in an existing stronghold. A Magist serves a ruler as an advisor on magical matters, handles magical needs, and is well-compensated—typically at least 3,000 gp per month. However, this requires the Magic-User to swear an oath of fealty to the ruler​.

Would you like additional details, such as construction costs or typical tower layouts?

If the saving throw is failed, the character becomes immobilized or petrified, depending on the effect. S9QGVlBRn4Md8rcs.description:
At 9th level, a Magic-User can begin crafting magic items, but only items usable by Magic-Users. The process involves:

  • Gathering rare materials related to the item's magic (e.g., dragon scales for fire resistance)
  • Spending time and gold to craft and enchant the item
  • A base cost of 500 gp per spell level for items that duplicate spell effects
  • A 15% minimum chance of failure, determined at the end of the process​

Scrolls and potions are the easiest to create, while more powerful items require months of work and possibly special rituals. The DM may set additional requirements for powerful magic items, such as needing a specific location or celestial alignment​.

cRfkrRzLX4wbXBJl.description:
Magic-Users harness arcane energy through intense study and careful memorization of spells recorded in their spellbooks. Unlike Clerics, who receive divine magic, Magic-Users must prepare spells in advance by studying their books each day. Once a spell is cast, it is erased from memory until re-memorized.

Magic-Users have a limited selection of spells they can prepare per day, increasing as they gain levels. Their spells range from minor utilities such as Read Magic to devastating attacks like Fireball and reality-warping incantations at higher levels​.

Because of their reliance on spellbooks, Magic-Users must protect and expand their libraries, seeking out lost tomes, scrolls, and ancient knowledge to improve their magical repertoire.

rLrrpGXF7OhuLDhw.description:
A Magic-User can attempt to create a new spell, but it must be of a level they can cast. The process requires:

  • 1,000 gp per spell level
  • Two weeks of research per spell level
  • Rare components, often requiring an adventure to obtain
  • A fully stocked laboratory or library

The chance of success depends on the Magic-User's Intelligence score and level, with modifications for spell difficulty​. If a research attempt fails, the process must be restarted, but each failure grants a +5% cumulative bonus to future attempts.

A Magic-User typically does not have a sufficient library for advanced research until 18th level, or at least 9th level if they have collected extensive magical tomes​. While research is technically possible at any level, low-level characters will likely struggle to meet the requirements.
rLrrpGXF7OhuLDhw.name: Spell Research

Each creature’s breath weapon has specific effects, such as damage, paralysis, or petrification. A successful saving throw generally halves the damage or avoids the secondary effect (such as paralysis or petrification), while failure applies the full consequences. The target number for the saving throw is determined by the character’s class and level.
umodpY6nw73CbFgL.name: Dragon Breath

Lich, Magic-User (22HD)*.biography:
A lich is a powerful undead monster of magical origin. It looks like a skeleton wearing fine garments and was once an evil and chaotic magic-user or cleric of level 21 or greater (often 27-36). A lich is still able to use spells as it did while alive, making it extremely dangerous. A lich is not normally found wandering but instead remains in or very near a well-defended lair, which might be a dungeon, catacomb, tomb, or necropolis ("city of the dead").

The very sight of a lich causes fear in all characters below 5th level (no saving throw). Its mere touch causes [[/r 1d10 #Touch damage]] points of damage and can paralyze any creature for [[/r 1d100 #Paralyzed for this many days]] days (though a saving throw applies, and the paralysis is magically dispellable).

Before any encounter with a lich, the DM should select spells for the creature with care, as a lich is extremely intelligent and uses them to its best advantage. Note that the lich's morale is given as 10, but a lich flees if in actual danger.

Liches are undead and can be turned (but not destroyed) by clerics. They are immune to charm, sleep, feeblemind, polymorph, cold, lightning, and death spells, and can be harmed only by magical weapons. They are also immune to the effects of all spells of less than 4th level. Outside of its lair, a lich always carries [[/r 1d4 + 1 #Powerful items]] powerful magical items to be used in case of trouble. These should be chosen, not randomly determined. Within its lair, a lich has 4d8 additional temporary magical items (or more), plus the amounts of coins, gems, and jewelry given for Treasure Type H in Chapter 16 (with a 90% chance for each type). The number and severity of traps and other dangers to intruders should be appropriate to protect such a hoard.

A magic-user lich normally has [[/r 1d2 #Spells]] spells of a permanent nature, most often detect invisible or fly. A clerical lich normally has [[/r 3d4 #Types of undead lairs nearby]] types of other undead nearby, acting as servants, with a full lair of each type (maximum number appearing) usually present.

Either type of lich can summon other powerful undead for aid. The summons can be made simply by concentrating, and the creature(s) responding arrive [[/r 1d100 #rounds]] rounds later, depending on their distance. The summons may be made as often as desired, but any one type of creature will respond only once per day at most. To randomly determine the creatures appearing in response to the summons, roll [[/r 1d20 #See lich summon table for result]] and refer to the table. Roll again if a type of creature has already responded that day.

Liches are master villains, coordinating armies and spy networks made up of the undead. OJ8iGgVa9sn9VLTH.description:
Upon reaching 9th level, a Magic-User may choose to build a tower, establishing themselves as a land-owning wizard. Unlike Fighters or Clerics, a Magic-User does not need permission from the local ruler to construct a stronghold, as rulers generally avoid antagonizing powerful wizards​.

Attracting Apprentices

Once a tower is built, the Magic-User will attract 1d6 apprentices, all Magic-Users of levels 1–3. These apprentices seek training, and while they are loyal, they will not sacrifice themselves for their master. The DM determines their names, backgrounds, and personalities​.

Stronghold and Dungeon Construction

A wizard's tower may include a dungeon beneath or near it. Some wizards construct dungeons as secure laboratories, while others leave an opening, attracting wandering monsters that take up residence. Some wizards encourage this, using monsters for research, spell experimentation, or personal defense​. However, monster-infested dungeons often cause conflict with local communities and attract adventurers seeking treasure.

Alternative to a Tower: Becoming a Magist

Instead of building a tower, a Name-level Magic-User may seek employment as a Magist in an existing stronghold. A Magist serves a ruler as an advisor on magical matters, handles magical needs, and is well-compensated—typically at least 3,000 gp per month. However, this requires the Magic-User to swear an oath of fealty to the ruler​.

Would you like additional details, such as construction costs or typical tower layouts?

Lich, Magic-User (24HD)*.biography:
A lich is a powerful undead monster of magical origin. It looks like a skeleton wearing fine garments and was once an evil and chaotic magic-user or cleric of level 21 or greater (often 27-36). A lich is still able to use spells as it did while alive, making it extremely dangerous. A lich is not normally found wandering but instead remains in or very near a well-defended lair, which might be a dungeon, catacomb, tomb, or necropolis ("city of the dead").

The very sight of a lich causes fear in all characters below 5th level (no saving throw). Its mere touch causes [[/r 1d10 #Touch damage]] points of damage and can paralyze any creature for [[/r 1d100 #Paralyzed for this many days]] days (though a saving throw applies, and the paralysis is magically dispellable).

Before any encounter with a lich, the DM should select spells for the creature with care, as a lich is extremely intelligent and uses them to its best advantage. Note that the lich's morale is given as 10, but a lich flees if in actual danger.

Liches are undead and can be turned (but not destroyed) by clerics. They are immune to charm, sleep, feeblemind, polymorph, cold, lightning, and death spells, and can be harmed only by magical weapons. They are also immune to the effects of all spells of less than 4th level. Outside of its lair, a lich always carries [[/r 1d4 + 1 #Powerful items]] powerful magical items to be used in case of trouble. These should be chosen, not randomly determined. Within its lair, a lich has 4d8 additional temporary magical items (or more), plus the amounts of coins, gems, and jewelry given for Treasure Type H in Chapter 16 (with a 90% chance for each type). The number and severity of traps and other dangers to intruders should be appropriate to protect such a hoard.

A magic-user lich normally has [[/r 1d2 #Spells]] spells of a permanent nature, most often detect invisible or fly. A clerical lich normally has [[/r 3d4 #Types of undead lairs nearby]] types of other undead nearby, acting as servants, with a full lair of each type (maximum number appearing) usually present.

Either type of lich can summon other powerful undead for aid. The summons can be made simply by concentrating, and the creature(s) responding arrive [[/r 1d100 #rounds]] rounds later, depending on their distance. The summons may be made as often as desired, but any one type of creature will respond only once per day at most. To randomly determine the creatures appearing in response to the summons, roll [[/r 1d20 #See lich summon table for result]] and refer to the table. Roll again if a type of creature has already responded that day.

Upon reaching 9th level, a Magic-User may choose to build a tower, establishing themselves as a land-owning wizard. Unlike Fighters or Clerics, a Magic-User does not need permission from the local ruler to construct a stronghold, as rulers generally avoid antagonizing powerful wizards​.

Attracting Apprentices

Once a tower is built, the Magic-User will attract 1d6 apprentices, all Magic-Users of levels 1–3. These apprentices seek training, and while they are loyal, they will not sacrifice themselves for their master. The DM determines their names, backgrounds, and personalities​.

Stronghold and Dungeon Construction

A wizard's tower may include a dungeon beneath or near it. Some wizards construct dungeons as secure laboratories, while others leave an opening, attracting wandering monsters that take up residence. Some wizards encourage this, using monsters for research, spell experimentation, or personal defense​. However, monster-infested dungeons often cause conflict with local communities and attract adventurers seeking treasure.

Alternative to a Tower: Becoming a Magist

aUk7olOXOFJRrCeL.description:
A Magic-User can attempt to create a new spell, but it must be of a level they can cast. The process requires:

  • 1,000 gp per spell level
  • Two weeks of research per spell level
  • Rare components, often requiring an adventure to obtain
  • A fully stocked laboratory or library

The chance of success depends on the Magic-User's Intelligence score and level, with modifications for spell difficulty​. If a research attempt fails, the process must be restarted, but each failure grants a +5% cumulative bonus to future attempts.

A Magic-User typically does not have a sufficient library for advanced research until 18th level, or at least 9th level if they have collected extensive magical tomes​. While research is technically possible at any level, low-level characters will likely struggle to meet the requirements.
aUk7olOXOFJRrCeL.name: Spell Research

ap8qUD3LuF6qESFL.description:
At 9th level, a Magic-User can begin crafting magic items, but only items usable by Magic-Users. The process involves:

  • Gathering rare materials related to the item's magic (e.g., dragon scales for fire resistance)
  • Spending time and gold to craft and enchant the item
  • A base cost of 500 gp per spell level for items that duplicate spell effects
  • A 15% minimum chance of failure, determined at the end of the process​

Scrolls and potions are the easiest to create, while more powerful items require months of work and possibly special rituals. The DM may set additional requirements for powerful magic items, such as needing a specific location or celestial alignment​.
ap8qUD3LuF6qESFL.name: Create Magic Items

c3cxvEdn9icMk9e9.description:
Magic-Users harness arcane energy through intense study and careful memorization of spells recorded in their spellbooks. Unlike Clerics, who receive divine magic, Magic-Users must prepare spells in advance by studying their books each day. Once a spell is cast, it is erased from memory until re-memorized.

Magic-Users have a limited selection of spells they can prepare per day, increasing as they gain levels. Their spells range from minor utilities such as Read Magic to devastating attacks like Fireball and reality-warping incantations at higher levels​.

Because of their reliance on spellbooks, Magic-Users must protect and expand their libraries, seeking out lost tomes, scrolls, and ancient knowledge to improve their magical repertoire.
c3cxvEdn9icMk9e9.name: Arcane Spellcasting

BPzz8mx3WSlRJJWE.description:
Magic-Users harness arcane energy through intense study and careful memorization of spells recorded in their spellbooks. Unlike Clerics, who receive divine magic, Magic-Users must prepare spells in advance by studying their books each day. Once a spell is cast, it is erased from memory until re-memorized.

Magic-Users have a limited selection of spells they can prepare per day, increasing as they gain levels. Their spells range from minor utilities such as Read Magic to devastating attacks like Fireball and reality-warping incantations at higher levels​.

Because of their reliance on spellbooks, Magic-Users must protect and expand their libraries, seeking out lost tomes, scrolls, and ancient knowledge to improve their magical repertoire.
BPzz8mx3WSlRJJWE.name: Arcane Spellcasting

I9BA1rWiLbhUzSH4.description:
At 9th level, a Magic-User can begin crafting magic items, but only items usable by Magic-Users. The process involves:

  • Gathering rare materials related to the item's magic (e.g., dragon scales for fire resistance)
  • Spending time and gold to craft and enchant the item
  • A base cost of 500 gp per spell level for items that duplicate spell effects
  • A 15% minimum chance of failure, determined at the end of the process​

Scrolls and potions are the easiest to create, while more powerful items require months of work and possibly special rituals. The DM may set additional requirements for powerful magic items, such as needing a specific location or celestial alignment​.

PJ9eX2YF44osDfar.description:
A Magic-User can attempt to create a new spell, but it must be of a level they can cast. The process requires:

  • 1,000 gp per spell level
  • Two weeks of research per spell level
  • Rare components, often requiring an adventure to obtain
  • A fully stocked laboratory or library

The chance of success depends on the Magic-User's Intelligence score and level, with modifications for spell difficulty​. If a research attempt fails, the process must be restarted, but each failure grants a +5% cumulative bonus to future attempts.

A Magic-User typically does not have a sufficient library for advanced research until 18th level, or at least 9th level if they have collected extensive magical tomes​. While research is technically possible at any level, low-level characters will likely struggle to meet the requirements.
PJ9eX2YF44osDfar.name: Spell Research

This saving throw is applicable to numerous magical attacks, such as charm spells, fireballs, or paralysis effects, and covers damage, control, or debilitating conditions caused by magical devices or spellcasters. The target number for success is based on the character's class and level.
RZCXhZ3c0KKbu7kA.name: Spells or Magic Staff

RjSmLOGNOVL16MEv.description:
Upon reaching 9th level, a Magic-User may choose to build a tower, establishing themselves as a land-owning wizard. Unlike Fighters or Clerics, a Magic-User does not need permission from the local ruler to construct a stronghold, as rulers generally avoid antagonizing powerful wizards​.

Attracting Apprentices

Once a tower is built, the Magic-User will attract 1d6 apprentices, all Magic-Users of levels 1–3. These apprentices seek training, and while they are loyal, they will not sacrifice themselves for their master. The DM determines their names, backgrounds, and personalities​.

Stronghold and Dungeon Construction

A wizard's tower may include a dungeon beneath or near it. Some wizards construct dungeons as secure laboratories, while others leave an opening, attracting wandering monsters that take up residence. Some wizards encourage this, using monsters for research, spell experimentation, or personal defense​. However, monster-infested dungeons often cause conflict with local communities and attract adventurers seeking treasure.

Alternative to a Tower: Becoming a Magist

Instead of building a tower, a Name-level Magic-User may seek employment as a Magist in an existing stronghold. A Magist serves a ruler as an advisor on magical matters, handles magical needs, and is well-compensated—typically at least 3,000 gp per month. However, this requires the Magic-User to swear an oath of fealty to the ruler​.

Would you like additional details, such as construction costs or typical tower layouts?
RjSmLOGNOVL16MEv.name: Establish Tower

The target number to save is determined by the character's class and level, as found on the saving throw table​​.

A failed roll often results in death (for poison) or other severe consequences, though optional rules may instead inflict substantial damage​​​.

Lich, Magic-User (27HD)*.biography:
A lich is a powerful undead monster of magical origin. It looks like a skeleton wearing fine garments and was once an evil and chaotic magic-user or cleric of level 21 or greater (often 27-36). A lich is still able to use spells as it did while alive, making it extremely dangerous. A lich is not normally found wandering but instead remains in or very near a well-defended lair, which might be a dungeon, catacomb, tomb, or necropolis ("city of the dead").

The very sight of a lich causes fear in all characters below 5th level (no saving throw). Its mere touch causes [[/r 1d10 #Touch damage]] points of damage and can paralyze any creature for [[/r 1d100 #Paralyzed for this many days]] days (though a saving throw applies, and the paralysis is magically dispellable).

Before any encounter with a lich, the DM should select spells for the creature with care, as a lich is extremely intelligent and uses them to its best advantage. Note that the lich's morale is given as 10, but a lich flees if in actual danger.

Liches are undead and can be turned (but not destroyed) by clerics. They are immune to charm, sleep, feeblemind, polymorph, cold, lightning, and death spells, and can be harmed only by magical weapons. They are also immune to the effects of all spells of less than 4th level. Outside of its lair, a lich always carries [[/r 1d4 + 1 #Powerful items]] powerful magical items to be used in case of trouble. These should be chosen, not randomly determined. Within its lair, a lich has 4d8 additional temporary magical items (or more), plus the amounts of coins, gems, and jewelry given for Treasure Type H in Chapter 16 (with a 90% chance for each type). The number and severity of traps and other dangers to intruders should be appropriate to protect such a hoard.

A magic-user lich normally has [[/r 1d2 #Spells]] spells of a permanent nature, most often detect invisible or fly. A clerical lich normally has [[/r 3d4 #Types of undead lairs nearby]] types of other undead nearby, acting as servants, with a full lair of each type (maximum number appearing) usually present.

Either type of lich can summon other powerful undead for aid. The summons can be made simply by concentrating, and the creature(s) responding arrive [[/r 1d100 #rounds]] rounds later, depending on their distance. The summons may be made as often as desired, but any one type of creature will respond only once per day at most. To randomly determine the creatures appearing in response to the summons, roll [[/r 1d20 #See lich summon table for result]] and refer to the table. Roll again if a type of creature has already responded that day.

Unlike Clerics, who receive divine magic, Magic-Users must prepare spells in advance by studying their books each day. Once a spell is cast, it is erased from memory until re-memorized.

Magic-Users have a limited selection of spells they can prepare per day, increasing as they gain levels. Their spells range from minor utilities such as Read Magic to devastating attacks like Fireball and reality-warping incantations at higher levels​.

Because of their reliance on spellbooks, Magic-Users must protect and expand their libraries, seeking out lost tomes, scrolls, and ancient knowledge to improve their magical repertoire.
UwYNZK0YaPqE8H1l.name: Arcane Spellcasting

lBVrBa92hmefxm1I.description:
A Magic-User can attempt to create a new spell, but it must be of a level they can cast. The process requires:

  • 1,000 gp per spell level
  • Two weeks of research per spell level
  • Rare components, often requiring an adventure to obtain
  • A fully stocked laboratory or library

The chance of success depends on the Magic-User's Intelligence score and level, with modifications for spell difficulty​. If a research attempt fails, the process must be restarted, but each failure grants a +5% cumulative bonus to future attempts.

A Magic-User typically does not have a sufficient library for advanced research until 18th level, or at least 9th level if they have collected extensive magical tomes​. While research is technically possible at any level, low-level characters will likely struggle to meet the requirements.
lBVrBa92hmefxm1I.name: Spell Research

nIJWFj4Qk8afg485.description: The saving throw against Breath Weapons is used to resist or mitigate the effects of a wide range of powerful exhaled attacks, not limited to dragons. This includes attacks like a dragon’s fiery or icy breath, a gorgon's petrifying breath, or a chimera's elemental breath. Each creature’s breath weapon has specific effects, such as damage, paralysis, or petrification. A successful saving throw generally halves the damage or avoids the secondary effect (such as paralysis or petrification), while failure applies the full consequences. The target number for the saving throw is determined by the character’s class and level.
nIJWFj4Qk8afg485.name: Dragon Breath

pDgkqn7UKowA74ST.description: The Death Ray or Poison saving throw is a roll made by a character to resist deadly effects like instant death or paralysis from poisons, spells, or traps. The player rolls a d20 and compares it to their class- and level-specific target number on the saving throw table; success means avoiding or mitigating the harm. A failed roll often results in death (for poison) or other severe consequences, though optional rules may instead inflict substantial damage​​​.
pDgkqn7UKowA74ST.name: Death Ray or Poison

qv4QkMmGmHTKW5bA.description: A clerical lich normally has [[/r 3d4 #Types of other undead lairs nearby]] types of other undead nearby, acting as servants. A full lair of each type (maximum number appearing) is usually present.
qv4QkMmGmHTKW5bA.name: Undead Servants

wO96nhpAYaCONYic.description: The saving throw for Spells or Magic Staff includes resistance against magical effects cast by rods, staves, wands, or through spells. A successful save, rolled on a d20, often reduces or negates the spell's effects entirely. This saving throw is applicable to numerous magical attacks, such as charm spells, fireballs, or paralysis effects, and covers damage, control, or debilitating conditions caused by magical devices or spellcasters. The target number for success is based on the character's class and level.
wO96nhpAYaCONYic.name: Spells or Magic Staff

yi3VPahARGEzQr7W.description:
At 9th level, a Magic-User can begin crafting magic items, but only items usable by Magic-Users. The process involves:

  • Gathering rare materials related to the item's magic (e.g., dragon scales for fire resistance)
  • Spending time and gold to craft and enchant the item
  • A base cost of 500 gp per spell level for items that duplicate spell effects
  • A 15% minimum chance of failure, determined at the end of the process​

Scrolls and potions are the easiest to create, while more powerful items require months of work and possibly special rituals. The DM may set additional requirements for powerful magic items, such as needing a specific location or celestial alignment​.
yi3VPahARGEzQr7W.name: Create Magic Items

zYze1nxU9RJ1Cwji.description:
Upon reaching 9th level, a Magic-User may choose to build a tower, establishing themselves as a land-owning wizard. Unlike Fighters or Clerics, a Magic-User does not need permission from the local ruler to construct a stronghold, as rulers generally avoid antagonizing powerful wizards​.

Attracting Apprentices

Once a tower is built, the Magic-User will attract 1d6 apprentices, all Magic-Users of levels 1–3. These apprentices seek training, and while they are loyal, they will not sacrifice themselves for their master. The DM determines their names, backgrounds, and personalities​.

Stronghold and Dungeon Construction

A wizard's tower may include a dungeon beneath or near it. Some wizards construct dungeons as secure laboratories, while others leave an opening, attracting wandering monsters that take up residence. Some wizards encourage this, using monsters for research, spell experimentation, or personal defense​. However, monster-infested dungeons often cause conflict with local communities and attract adventurers seeking treasure.

Alternative to a Tower: Becoming a Magist

Instead of building a tower, a Name-level Magic-User may seek employment as a Magist in an existing stronghold. A Magist serves a ruler as an advisor on magical matters, handles magical needs, and is well-compensated—typically at least 3,000 gp per month. However, this requires the Magic-User to swear an oath of fealty to the ruler​.

Would you like additional details, such as construction costs or typical tower layouts?
zYze1nxU9RJ1Cwji.name: Establish Tower

Lich, Magic-User (28HD)*.name: Lich, Magic-User (28HD)*

Lich, Magic-User (29HD)*.biography:
A lich is a powerful undead monster of magical origin. It looks like a skeleton wearing fine garments and was once an evil and chaotic magic-user or cleric of level 21 or greater (often 27-36). A lich is still able to use spells as it did while alive, making it extremely dangerous. A lich is not normally found wandering but instead remains in or very near a well-defended lair, which might be a dungeon, catacomb, tomb, or necropolis ("city of the dead").

The very sight of a lich causes fear in all characters below 5th level (no saving throw). Its mere touch causes [[/r 1d10 #Touch damage]] points of damage and can paralyze any creature for [[/r 1d100 #Paralyzed for this many days]] days (though a saving throw applies, and the paralysis is magically dispellable).

Before any encounter with a lich, the DM should select spells for the creature with care, as a lich is extremely intelligent and uses them to its best advantage. Note that the lich's morale is given as 10, but a lich flees if in actual danger.

Liches are undead and can be turned (but not destroyed) by clerics. They are immune to charm, sleep, feeblemind, polymorph, cold, lightning, and death spells, and can be harmed only by magical weapons. They are also immune to the effects of all spells of less than 4th level. Outside of its lair, a lich always carries [[/r 1d4 + 1 #Powerful items]] powerful magical items to be used in case of trouble. These should be chosen, not randomly determined. Within its lair, a lich has 4d8 additional temporary magical items (or more), plus the amounts of coins, gems, and jewelry given for Treasure Type H in Chapter 16 (with a 90% chance for each type). The number and severity of traps and other dangers to intruders should be appropriate to protect such a hoard.

A magic-user lich normally has [[/r 1d2 #Spells]] spells of a permanent nature, most often detect invisible or fly. A clerical lich normally has [[/r 3d4 #Types of undead lairs nearby]] types of other undead nearby, acting as servants, with a full lair of each type (maximum number appearing) usually present.

Either type of lich can summon other powerful undead for aid. The summons can be made simply by concentrating, and the creature(s) responding arrive [[/r 1d100 #rounds]] rounds later, depending on their distance. The summons may be made as often as desired, but any one type of creature will respond only once per day at most. To randomly determine the creatures appearing in response to the summons, roll [[/r 1d20 #See lich summon table for result]] and refer to the table. Roll again if a type of creature has already responded that day.

Liches are master villains, coordinating armies and spy networks made up of the undead. Each one has its own goal: one may want to achieve true immortality, another may serve an evil immortal of entropy, and yet another may wish to transform the entire world into a horrid playground for the undead.
