Lich, Magic-User (31HD)*.biography:
A lich is a powerful undead monster of magical origin. It looks like a skeleton wearing fine garments and was once an evil and chaotic magic-user or cleric of level 21 or greater (often 27-36). A lich is still able to use spells as it did while alive, making it extremely dangerous. A lich is not normally found wandering but instead remains in or very near a well-defended lair, which might be a dungeon, catacomb, tomb, or necropolis ("city of the dead").

The very sight of a lich causes fear in all characters below 5th level (no saving throw). Its mere touch causes [[/r 1d10 #Touch damage]] points of damage and can paralyze any creature for [[/r 1d100 #Paralyzed for this many days]] days (though a saving throw applies, and the paralysis is magically dispellable).

Before any encounter with a lich, the DM should select spells for the creature with care, as a lich is extremely intelligent and uses them to its best advantage. Note that the lich's morale is given as 10, but a lich flees if in actual danger.

Liches are undead and can be turned (but not destroyed) by clerics. They are immune to charm, sleep, feeblemind, polymorph, cold, lightning, and death spells, and can be harmed only by magical weapons. They are also immune to the effects of all spells of less than 4th level. Outside of its lair, a lich always carries [[/r 1d4 + 1 #Powerful items]] powerful magical items to be used in case of trouble. These should be chosen, not randomly determined. Within its lair, a lich has 4d8 additional temporary magical items (or more), plus the amounts of coins, gems, and jewelry given for Treasure Type H in Chapter 16 (with a 90% chance for each type). The number and severity of traps and other dangers to intruders should be appropriate to protect such a hoard.

A magic-user lich normally has [[/r 1d2 #Spells]] spells of a permanent nature, most often detect invisible or fly. A clerical lich normally has [[/r 3d4 #Types of undead lairs nearby]] types of other undead nearby, acting as servants, with a full lair of each type (maximum number appearing) usually present.

Either type of lich can summon other powerful undead for aid. The summons can be made simply by concentrating, and the creature(s) responding arrive [[/r 1d100 #rounds]] rounds later, depending on their distance. The summons may be made as often as desired, but any one type of creature will respond only once per day at most. To randomly determine the creatures appearing in response to the summons, roll [[/r 1d20 #See lich summon table for result]] and refer to the table. Upon reaching 9th level, a Magic-User may choose to build a tower, establishing themselves as a land-owning wizard. Unlike Fighters or Clerics, a Magic-User does not need permission from the local ruler to construct a stronghold, as rulers generally avoid antagonizing powerful wizards​.

Attracting Apprentices

Once a tower is built, the Magic-User will attract 1d6 apprentices, all Magic-Users of levels 1–3. These apprentices seek training, and while they are loyal, they will not sacrifice themselves for their master. The DM determines their names, backgrounds, and personalities​.

Stronghold and Dungeon Construction

A wizard's tower may include a dungeon beneath or near it. Some wizards construct dungeons as secure laboratories, while others leave an opening, attracting wandering monsters that take up residence. Some wizards encourage this, using monsters for research, spell experimentation, or personal defense​. However, monster-infested dungeons often cause conflict with local communities and attract adventurers seeking treasure.

Alternative to a Tower: Becoming a Magist

Instead of building a tower, a Name-level Magic-User may seek employment as a Magist in an existing stronghold. A Magist serves a ruler as an advisor on magical matters, handles magical needs, and is well-compensated—typically at least 3,000 gp per month. However, this requires the Magic-User to swear an oath of fealty to the ruler​.

Attracting Apprentices

Lich, Magic-User (34HD)*.biography:
A lich is a powerful undead monster of magical origin. It looks like a skeleton wearing fine garments and was once an evil and chaotic magic-user or cleric of level 21 or greater (often 27-36). A lich is still able to use spells as it did while alive, making it extremely dangerous. A lich is not normally found wandering but instead remains in or very near a well-defended lair, which might be a dungeon, catacomb, tomb, or necropolis ("city of the dead").

The very sight of a lich causes fear in all characters below 5th level (no saving throw). Its mere touch causes [[/r 1d10 #Touch damage]] points of damage and can paralyze any creature for [[/r 1d100 #Paralyzed for this many days]] days (though a saving throw applies, and the paralysis is magically dispellable).

Before any encounter with a lich, the DM should select spells for the creature with care, as a lich is extremely intelligent and uses them to its best advantage. Note that the lich's morale is given as 10, but a lich flees if in actual danger.

Liches are undead and can be turned (but not destroyed) by clerics. They are immune to charm, sleep, feeblemind, polymorph, cold, lightning, and death spells, and can be harmed only by magical weapons. They are also immune to the effects of all spells of less than 4th level. Outside of its lair, a lich always carries [[/r 1d4 + 1 #Powerful items]] powerful magical items to be used in case of trouble. These should be chosen, not randomly determined. Within its lair, a lich has 4d8 additional temporary magical items (or more), plus the amounts of coins, gems, and jewelry given for Treasure Type H in Chapter 16 (with a 90% chance for each type). The number and severity of traps and other dangers to intruders should be appropriate to protect such a hoard.

A magic-user lich normally has [[/r 1d2 #Spells]] spells of a permanent nature, most often detect invisible or fly. A clerical lich normally has [[/r 3d4 #Types of undead lairs nearby]] types of other undead nearby, acting as servants, with a full lair of each type (maximum number appearing) usually present.

Either type of lich can summon other powerful undead for aid. The summons can be made simply by concentrating, and the creature(s) responding arrive [[/r 1d100 #rounds]] rounds later, depending on their distance. The summons may be made as often as desired, but any one type of creature will respond only once per day at most. To randomly determine the creatures appearing in response to the summons, roll [[/r 1d20 #See lich summon table for result]] and refer to the table. Roll again if a type of creature has already responded that day.

LwEHzckbs2mIBgOJ.description:
At 9th level, a Magic-User can begin crafting magic items, but only items usable by Magic-Users. The process involves:

  • Gathering rare materials related to the item's magic (e.g., dragon scales for fire resistance)
  • Spending time and gold to craft and enchant the item
  • A base cost of 500 gp per spell level for items that duplicate spell effects
  • A 15% minimum chance of failure, determined at the end of the process​

Scrolls and potions are the easiest to create, while more powerful items require months of work and possibly special rituals. The DM may set additional requirements for powerful magic items, such as needing a specific location or celestial alignment​.
LwEHzckbs2mIBgOJ.name: Create Magic Items

OrDEulbgkLUp8aBS.description:
Magic-Users harness arcane energy through intense study and careful memorization of spells recorded in their spellbooks. Unlike Clerics, who receive divine magic, Magic-Users must prepare spells in advance by studying their books each day. Once a spell is cast, it is erased from memory until re-memorized.

Magic-Users have a limited selection of spells they can prepare per day, increasing as they gain levels. Their spells range from minor utilities such as Read Magic to devastating attacks like Fireball and reality-warping incantations at higher levels​.

Because of their reliance on spellbooks, Magic-Users must protect and expand their libraries, seeking out lost tomes, scrolls, and ancient knowledge to improve their magical repertoire.
OrDEulbgkLUp8aBS.name: Arcane Spellcasting

PQqxy7in3N7lxQou.description: The saving throw for Spells or Magic Staff includes resistance against magical effects cast by rods, staves, wands, or through spells. A successful save, rolled on a d20, often reduces or negates the spell's effects entirely. This saving throw is applicable to numerous magical attacks, such as charm spells, fireballs, or paralysis effects, and covers damage, control, or debilitating conditions caused by magical devices or spellcasters. The target number for success is based on the character's class and level.
PQqxy7in3N7lxQou.name: Spells or Magic Staff

X3Li8QD7fmDnvhac.description: The Magic Wand saving throw is used to avoid the effects of attacks or abilities activated through magical wands, such as paralysis rays or damage-dealing beams. A successful save, rolled on a d20, indicates that the character avoids or mitigates the harmful effects. The target number to save is determined by the character's class and level, as found on the saving throw table​​.
X3Li8QD7fmDnvhac.name: Magic Wand

jVL4EY1SE38Syez8.description: The saving throw against "Stone or Paralysis" protects a character from attacks or effects that could freeze them in place (paralysis) or turn them into stone. If the saving throw is failed, the character becomes immobilized or petrified, depending on the effect. Paralysis leaves a character aware but unable to act, while petrification turns the character and their carried equipment into a stone statue. The duration or permanence of these effects is specified by the source, and successful saving throws avoid them entirely​​​.
jVL4EY1SE38Syez8.name: Turn to Stone or Paralysis

r3ozua8hse2Hx880.description: The saving throw against Breath Weapons is used to resist or mitigate the effects of a wide range of powerful exhaled attacks, not limited to dragons. Each creature’s breath weapon has specific effects, such as damage, paralysis, or petrification. A successful saving throw generally halves the damage or avoids the secondary effect (such as paralysis or petrification), while failure applies the full consequences. The target number for the saving throw is determined by the character’s class and level.

wL8cinLNg7n2yjxF.description:
A Magic-User can attempt to create a new spell, but it must be of a level they can cast. The process requires:

  • 1,000 gp per spell level
  • Two weeks of research per spell level
  • Rare components, often requiring an adventure to obtain
  • A fully stocked laboratory or library

The chance of success depends on the Magic-User's Intelligence score and level, with modifications for spell difficulty​. If a research attempt fails, the process must be restarted, but each failure grants a +5% cumulative bonus to future attempts.

A Magic-User typically does not have a sufficient library for advanced research until 18th level, or at least 9th level if they have collected extensive magical tomes​. While research is technically possible at any level, low-level characters will likely struggle to meet the requirements.
wL8cinLNg7n2yjxF.name: Spell Research

Lich, Magic-User (36HD)*.biography:
A lich is a powerful undead monster of magical origin. It looks like a skeleton wearing fine garments and was once an evil and chaotic magic-user or cleric of level 21 or greater (often 27-36). A lich is still able to use spells as it did while alive, making it extremely dangerous. A lich is not normally found wandering but instead remains in or very near a well-defended lair, which might be a dungeon, catacomb, tomb, or necropolis ("city of the dead").

The very sight of a lich causes fear in all characters below 5th level (no saving throw). Its mere touch causes [[/r 1d10 #Touch damage]] points of damage and can paralyze any creature for [[/r 1d100 #Paralyzed for this many days]] days (though a saving throw applies, and the paralysis is magically dispellable).

Before any encounter with a lich, the DM should select spells for the creature with care, as a lich is extremely intelligent and uses them to its best advantage. Note that the lich's morale is given as 10, but a lich flees if in actual danger.

Liches are undead and can be turned (but not destroyed) by clerics. They are immune to charm, sleep, feeblemind, polymorph, cold, lightning, and death spells, and can be harmed only by magical weapons. They are also immune to the effects of all spells of less than 4th level. Outside of its lair, a lich always carries [[/r 1d4 + 1 #Powerful items]] powerful magical items to be used in case of trouble. These should be chosen, not randomly determined. Within its lair, a lich has 4d8 additional temporary magical items (or more), plus the amounts of coins, gems, and jewelry given for Treasure Type H in Chapter 16 (with a 90% chance for each type). The number and severity of traps and other dangers to intruders should be appropriate to protect such a hoard.

A magic-user lich normally has [[/r 1d2 #Spells]] spells of a permanent nature, most often detect invisible or fly. A clerical lich normally has [[/r 3d4 #Types of undead lairs nearby]] types of other undead nearby, acting as servants, with a full lair of each type (maximum number appearing) usually present.

Either type of lich can summon other powerful undead for aid. The summons can be made simply by concentrating, and the creature(s) responding arrive [[/r 1d100 #rounds]] rounds later, depending on their distance. The summons may be made as often as desired, but any one type of creature will respond only once per day at most. To randomly determine the creatures appearing in response to the summons, roll [[/r 1d20 #See lich summon table for result]] and refer to the table. Roll again if a type of creature has already responded that day.

Liches are master villains, coordinating armies and spy networks made up of the undead. Each one has its own goal: one may want to achieve true immortality, another may serve an evil immortal of entropy, and yet another may wish to transform the entire world into a horrid playground for the undead. Each lich in a campaign should have its own name, style, and motivation.

YPIGCgDUO3e0ikBp.description:
Upon reaching 9th level, a Magic-User may choose to build a tower, establishing themselves as a land-owning wizard. Unlike Fighters or Clerics, a Magic-User does not need permission from the local ruler to construct a stronghold, as rulers generally avoid antagonizing powerful wizards​.

Attracting Apprentices

Once a tower is built, the Magic-User will attract 1d6 apprentices, all Magic-Users of levels 1–3. These apprentices seek training, and while they are loyal, they will not sacrifice themselves for their master. The DM determines their names, backgrounds, and personalities​.

Stronghold and Dungeon Construction

A wizard's tower may include a dungeon beneath or near it. Some wizards construct dungeons as secure laboratories, while others leave an opening, attracting wandering monsters that take up residence. Some wizards encourage this, using monsters for research, spell experimentation, or personal defense​. However, monster-infested dungeons often cause conflict with local communities and attract adventurers seeking treasure.

Alternative to a Tower: Becoming a Magist

Instead of building a tower, a Name-level Magic-User may seek employment as a Magist in an existing stronghold. A Magist serves a ruler as an advisor on magical matters, handles magical needs, and is well-compensated—typically at least 3,000 gp per month. However, this requires the Magic-User to swear an oath of fealty to the ruler​.

Would you like additional details, such as construction costs or typical tower layouts?
YPIGCgDUO3e0ikBp.name: Establish Tower

Lizard Man.biography:
Lizard Men thrive in swamps, rivers, lakes, and coastal caverns, their humanoid forms adorned with scaly hides, clawed hands, tails, and reptilian heads. Ranging from drab green or brown to vivid reds, blues, yellows, or greens, these water-dwelling tribes hunt relentlessly, often capturing humans and demihumans for feasts at their lairs.

Semi-intelligent, they wield spears or large clubs—treated as maces—with a +1 damage bonus from their formidable strength (e.g., [[/r 1d6+1 #Weapon damage]] for spear). One in ten speaks rudimentary Common, allowing tense negotiations—though hunger may override talk if food isn’t offered, driving them to dine on their interlocutors.

Living arduous lives, they roam in bands of [[/r 2d4 #Lizard Men wandering]] or lairs of [[/r 6d6 #Lizard Men in lair]], sometimes serving other races as warriors or scouts for sustenance. Neutral and pragmatic, they hoard modest treasures, valuing only what aids their survival (HD 2 + 1, XP 25).

Terrain: Cavern, River/Lake, Swamps

Lizard, Draco.biography:
The Draco lizard is a 6' long creature with wide flaps of skin between its legs. It uses these flaps to glide through the air, much like a flying squirrel. Dracos are commonly found above ground, though they may take refuge in caves during periods of extreme weather.

They are carnivores and are known to attack adventurers when provoked. Although they can glide for long distances, they cannot actually fly. Draco lizards are generally not tamed as mounts without special training and DM approval.

Terrain: Cavern, Desert, Woods.
Load: Giant lizards can carry 500 cn x their HD at full speed or 1,000 cn x their HD at half speed.

Locust, Giant.biography:
Giant locusts are 2 to 3 feet long and live underground. They may be mistaken for statues or might not be noticed at all until approached, due to their stone-gray color. These creatures are herbivores and also consume fungus, such as yellow mold and shriekers. They cannot be harmed by yellow mold or most poisons.

Instead of fighting, giant locusts usually flee by jumping away, covering distances of up to 60 feet. Unfortunately, they often become confused and may accidentally jump into a party, with a 50% chance per jump. If this occurs, a victim is determined randomly, and an attack roll is made. If the giant locust hits a character, the victim suffers 1d4 points of damage before the locust flies away.

When frightened or attacked, giant locusts emit a loud shrieking noise to warn their companions. In dungeons, this shriek has a 20% chance per round of attracting wandering monsters. If cornered, a giant locust will spit a brown, gooey substance up to 10 feet. The target is treated as having an armor class of 9, regardless of their actual armor class. A victim hit by the giant locust's spittle must make a saving throw against poison or be unable to do anything for one turn due to the awful smell. After this time, the victim will become accustomed to the odor, but any character approaching within 5 feet must also make a saving throw or suffer the same effects. This aroma will persist until the spittle is washed off.

Terrain: Cavern.

Lycanthrope, Devil Swine*.biography:
Devil Swine are shape-changing lycanthropes, appearing either as massive swine or as obese humans. They freely change shapes at night but must remain in one form during daylight hours. Devil Swine are carnivorous, favoring human flesh, and often live near human settlements where they can hunt. They ambush their prey, and each Devil Swine can cast Charm Person up to three times per day, in either human or swine form. Victims must make a saving throw vs. spells with a -2 penalty; charmed humans become controlled minions, with [[/r 1d4-1 #Minions]] usually under a Devil Swine's control.

In animal form, Devil Swine can only be harmed by magical or silvered weapons and communicate with other swine. In human form, they can use any weapon, speak any known language, and are vulnerable to normal attacks.

Lycanthropy: Any human who loses more than half of their hit points to a Devil Swine’s gore or weapon attack becomes a Devil Swine within [[/r 2d12 #Days until victim becomes a Devil Swine]] days. The disease is fatal to demihumans and can only be cured by a cleric of 11th level or higher.

Terrain: Forests, swamps, or areas near human settlements

The spell does not affect animals, magical creatures, undead, or creatures larger than ogres.

The charmed creature obeys friendly commands but resists those that go against its nature or cause self-harm. The duration depends on the target’s Intelligence, allowing periodic saving throws:

Lycanthrope, Wereboar*.biography:
Wereboars are known for their semi-intelligence and short temper. In human form, they often appear as berserkers, gaining +2 on attack rolls and fighting to the death. Wereboars do not associate with devil swine. In combat, wereboars summon normal boars to assist.

In animal form, wereboars can only be harmed by magical or silvered weapons, and they communicate with boars. In human form, they may speak any known languages, be harmed by normal weapons, and wield any weapon.

Lycanthropy: Any human who loses more than half of their hit points to a wereboar’s tusk slash becomes a wereboar within 2d12 days. The disease is fatal to demihumans and can only be cured by a cleric of 11th level or higher.

Terrain: Variable, often as animal type

7Blvg1PRkdSXwtIG.description: The saving throw against Breath Weapons is used to resist or mitigate the effects of a wide range of powerful exhaled attacks, not limited to dragons. This includes attacks like a dragon’s fiery or icy breath, a gorgon's petrifying breath, or a chimera's elemental breath. Each creature’s breath weapon has specific effects, such as damage, paralysis, or petrification. A successful saving throw generally halves the damage or avoids the secondary effect (such as paralysis or petrification), while failure applies the full consequences. The target number for the saving throw is determined by the character’s class and level.
7Blvg1PRkdSXwtIG.name: Dragon Breath

7qj9TcXZ8TSilDxK.description: The saving throw against "Stone or Paralysis" protects a character from attacks or effects that could freeze them in place (paralysis) or turn them into stone. If the saving throw is failed, the character becomes immobilized or petrified, depending on the effect. Paralysis leaves a character aware but unable to act, while petrification turns the character and their carried equipment into a stone statue. The duration or permanence of these effects is specified by the source, and successful saving throws avoid them entirely​​​.

Lycanthrope, Werefox*.biography:
Werefoxes are intelligent and nimble lycanthropes who favor dense underbrush, where they maintain full or near-full movement. Highly intelligent, they may also be magic-users, though spells can only be cast in human form. Werefoxes can charm (either persons in human form or animals in fox form) up to three times per day, lasting up to 24 hours.

In animal form, werefoxes can only be harmed by magical or silvered weapons, and they communicate with other foxes. In human form, they can use any weapon, cast spells, and are vulnerable to normal attacks.

Lycanthropy: Any human who loses more than half of their hit points to a werefox’s bite or weapon attack becomes a werefox within [[/r 2d12 #Target becomes a Werefox in this many days]] days. This condition is fatal to demihumans and can only be cured by a cleric of 11th level or higher.

J0QeUOSFXyEGCTBb.description:
Can charm either persons (in human form) or animals (in fox form) up to three times per day. Each charm lasts up to 24 hours.

Affects humans, demihumans, and certain other creatures. The target must make a saving throw vs. spells; if failed, the target views the caster as a “best friend” and will defend them against any perceived threat. The spell does not affect animals, magical creatures, undead, or creatures larger than ogres.

The charmed creature obeys friendly commands but resists those that go against its nature or cause self-harm. The duration depends on the target’s Intelligence, allowing periodic saving throws:

  • High Intelligence (13-18): Save every day
  • Average Intelligence (9-12): Save every week
  • Low Intelligence (3-8): Save every month

Lycanthrope, Wererat*.biography:
Wererats are unusual lycanthropes because their natural form is that of a large rat, and they transform into human form as needed. Intelligent and sly, they often set ambushes and prefer man-sized rat form in combat, surprising foes on a roll of 1-4 on [[/r 1d6 #Opponent surprised on 1-4]]. Wererats summon giant rats to aid them in battle, and only their bite transmits lycanthropy.

In animal form, wererats can only be harmed by magical or silvered weapons or spells, and they communicate with rats. In human form, wererats may use any weapon, speak any known languages, and be harmed by normal weapons.

Lycanthropy: Any human who loses more than half of their hit points to a wererat's bite becomes a wererat within [[/r2d12 #Days until victim turns into a wererat]] days. The condition kills demihumans and can only be cured by a cleric of 11th level or higher.

Lycanthrope, Werewolf Leader*.biography:
Werewolves are semi-intelligent creatures known for their hunting packs. Groups of five or more have a leader with 30 hit points, attacking as a 5 HD monster and dealing +2 damage per hit. Werewolves can summon normal wolves to create larger packs for attacks.

In animal form, werewolves can only be harmed by magical or silvered weapons, and they communicate with wolves. In human form, they may speak any known languages, be harmed by normal weapons, and may wield any weapon.

Lycanthropy: Any human who loses more than half of their hit points to a werewolf bite becomes a werewolf within 2d12 days. This condition is fatal to demihumans and can only be cured by a cleric of 11th level or higher.

Terrain: Variable, often as animal type

Malfera*.biography:
A malfera is a creature from the Dimension of Nightmares, where many evil dreams are bred and released into the minds of sleeping people. A malfera appears only through the acts of a powerful magic-user or an Immortal; its dimension is believed to be poisonous and deadly to humans.

The malfera has a large, elephant-like face and a short trunk. The head is topped by large horns, and large fangs protrude from either side of the trunk. The chest is a mass of slimy, short tentacles. Long, muscular arms end in large, jagged pincers, and its feet are webbed and clawed. It is colored night-black but has red veins and eyes.

In combat, a malfera attacks with its pincers and bites. If both pincers hit the same target, the victim is dragged to the chest of the malfera on the next round. The tentacles then automatically trap the victim. These tentacles are coated with an acid slime and deal 2d6 points of damage each round. The victim can be freed only when the malfera is killed.

In addition, the breath of a malfera is poisonous. Each time it hits with a bite, its victim must save vs. poison (at a +3 bonus) or die. A malfera is immune to acid and can be struck only by magical weapons.

Aside from its combat abilities, a malfera can detect invisible creatures and open all doors as if it had a knock spell. Because of its tough constitution and highly magical nature, it saves as a 13th level fighter.

Terrain: Any; Dimension of Nightmares.

Manscorpion (8HD).biography:
The Manscorpion, a vile blend of man and scorpion, prowls caverns, deserts, and mountains, its human-like torso atop the segmented body of a giant arachnid. Driven by malice, it roams any climate, ambushing intruders and raiding desert human enclaves for sustenance.

It wields a huge pole arm (dealing [[/r 3d6 #Pole arm damage]]) or other weapons, paired with a venomous tail strike ([[/r 1d10 #Tail damage]] + poison, save vs. poison or die, paralysis for [[/r 1d8-1 #Rounds paralyzed]] even if saved). Immune to its kin’s venom, it strikes with deadly intent.

Intelligent yet hostile, bands of [[/r 1d8 #Manscorpions wandering]] or lairs of [[/r 2d10 #Manscorpions in lair]] hoard rich treasures, their chaotic nature spurning alliances save with giant scorpions. A relentless foe (HD 8, XP 1750), it destroys all unlike itself.
Terrain: Cavern, Desert, Mountain

Manticore.biography:
A manticore is a horrid monster with the body of a lion, leathery bat wings, a tail ridged with spikes, and the face of a man with large, sharp fangs. It usually lives in wild mountain ranges.

The manticore has 24 tail spikes and can shoot six each round even when flying (ranges 50/100/180). The creature regrows two spikes per day. Its favorite food is man.

Manticores frequently track humans, ambushing them with spike attacks when the human group stops to rest. Another tactic is to stalk its prey like a great cat, creeping up close on an unsuspecting victim. When that victim is alone, the manticore fires off a barrage of tail spikes to bring the victim down. The manticore then eats the victim. Less frequently, a pack of manticores will stalk and attack a group of victims.

Terrain: Mountain.
Load: 3,000 cn at up to full speed, or 6,000 cn at up to half speed.
Barding Multiplier: x 2.

Medusa.biography:
A medusa looks like a human female with live snakes growing from her head instead of hair. Medusae are very magical, and the mere sight of a medusa will turn a creature to stone unless the victim makes a saving throw vs. turn to stone. However, this will affect only one character per round, and characters may watch the reflection of a medusa in a mirror without danger. If a medusa sees her own reflection, she must make a saving throw vs. turn to stone or she will petrify herself!

In combat, the medusa makes one attack roll for the bites of the snakes, and if they hit, the victim must make a saving throw vs. poison (in addition to taking 1d6 points of damage) or die in one turn. A medusa will often wear a robe with a hood for disguise so she can trick her victims into looking at her. Medusae occasionally use weapons.

Anyone who tries to attack a medusa without looking at her must subtract 4 from the attack roll, and the snakes may attack with a +2 bonus to the attack roll. A medusa also gains +2 on all saving throws vs. spells due to her magical nature.

Many medusae are evil. Others are reclusive scholars, ancient sages who can guide heroes on their quests and who conceal their deadly visages under veils.

There are also medusa spellcasters (see "Monster Spellcasters").

Medusae are native to both the Prime Plane and their original home, the elemental plane of Earth.

Plane of Earth: On the plane of Earth, a medusa is an ugly writhing mass of 10-foot long tentacles connected to a small lumpy spherical body. Several eyes on foot-long eyestalks also protrude from the body; the mouth has many teeth. The tentacles are used both for movement (180' (60')) and combat. The medusa can attack with 10 tentacles per round; each hit requires a saving throw vs. paralysis (lasting 2d4 rounds if failed). A paralyzed victim is drawn to the mouth and bitten for 2-16 (2d8) points of damage per round (no attack roll required while the victim is paralyzed).

Elemental Plane of Earth Statistics: AC 4, HD 8**, MV 180' (60'), NA 1-4, Save F4, ML 9, TT(V) F, AL C, XP 1,750.

Terrain: Cavern, Ruins; Plane of Earth.

Mek (11HD).biography:
Meks, towering metallic constructs 15 to 25 feet tall, roam any terrain as relics of a vanished race of insectoid sorcerers. Crafted with insect-like features—barrel chests, barbed, double-jointed limbs—some mimic giants or lizards, serving as guards for masters or wandering chaotically to assail all in their path.

Striking twice with heavy limbs for [[/r 1d6*10 #Limb damage]] each, they unleash a 20' paralyzing breath cloud, forcing a save vs. breath weapon each round or paralysis for [[/r 1d3 #Turns paralyzed]] turns. Cold slows them to half speed, but only disintegrate pierces their immunity to other spells.

Unintelligent yet responsive to simple commands when mastered, they appear singly ([[/r 1 #Meks encountered]]), their alignment shifting from lawful servitude to chaotic rampage without guidance. Their treasures vary, hoarded from fallen foes (HD 11, XP 2700).

Terrain: Any

Mek (16HD).biography:
Meks, towering metallic constructs 15 to 25 feet tall, roam any terrain as relics of a vanished race of insectoid sorcerers. Crafted with insect-like features—barrel chests, barbed, double-jointed limbs—some mimic giants or lizards, serving as guards for masters or wandering chaotically to assail all in their path.

Striking twice with heavy limbs for [[/r 1d6*10 #Limb damage]] each, they unleash a 20' paralyzing breath cloud, forcing a save vs. breath weapon each round or paralysis for [[/r 1d3 #Turns paralyzed]] turns. Cold slows them to half speed, but only disintegrate pierces their immunity to other spells.

Unintelligent yet responsive to simple commands when mastered, they appear singly ([[/r 1 #Meks encountered]]), their alignment shifting from lawful servitude to chaotic rampage without guidance. Their treasures vary, hoarded from fallen foes (HD 11, XP 2700).

Metamorph.biography:
Metamorphs look very similar to humans but have pointed ears and pure white eyes. They are closely related to humans but, as a species, are masters of the ancient art of shapeshifting. They are not lycanthropes, though they are sometimes mistaken for them.

A metamorph can shapeshift up to 11 times each day, but only into certain forms. Unlike the polymorph self spell effect, this nonmagical shapeshift gives the metamorph all the abilities of the new form; even special attacks (such as a skunk's spray) are gained. Metamorphs cannot take giant-sized or fantastic forms but can take any normal nonmagical form.

The forms a metamorph can use each day are:

  • Worm
  • Insect
  • Reptile
  • Leech
  • Crustacean
  • Amphibian
  • Spider
  • Mammal
  • Fish
  • Centipede
  • Bird

For example, a metamorph can turn into a mammal once per day. One day, he may choose to become a monkey, and the next day a wolf. Once a choice has been used, the metamorph cannot change into that choice any more that day. Each shapeshift lasts up to 1 hour, and the metamorph can assume normal form at any time.

Metamorphs have good relations with elves, halflings, and druids but avoid most human settlements. They live in strongholds similar to those of demihumans, but with many differences adapted to their special abilities. Most are Chaotic (though Neutral and Lawful ones do exist), but few are noticeably evil or good.

If ten or more are present, one will be a leader with 5+2 Hit Dice. As long as the leader is with the group, their morale is 10.

Terrain: Open, Mountain, Woods.

Minotaur.biography:
The Minotaur stalks caverns and ruins, a towering beast 7 to 9 feet tall with a man’s form crowned by a bull’s head and hide. Driven by a ferocious temperament, it roams tunnels and mazes, preying on humans and attacking anything its size or smaller with relentless pursuit as long as its quarry remains in view.

In battle, it either gores and bites for [[/r 1d6 #Gore damage]] and [[/r 1d6 #Bite damage]], or wields a weapon—favoring spears, clubs, or axes—with a +2 damage bonus from its brute strength (e.g., [[/r 1d6+2 #Weapon damage]] for spear). When armed, it forgoes its natural attacks, relying solely on the weapon’s might.

Semi-intelligent, some Minotaurs wield tools, while rare, clever ones may cast spells. Roaming in bands of [[/r 1d6 #Minotaurs wandering]] or lairs of [[/r 1d8 #Minotaurs in lair]], they hoard modest treasures, their chaotic nature a constant threat in shadowed depths.

Terrain: Cavern, Ruins

A successful saving throw generally halves the damage or avoids the secondary effect (such as paralysis or petrification), while failure applies the full consequences. Mujina.biography:
The Mujina haunts regions where humans dwell, its natural form a chilling mimicry of humanity—featureless, with a smooth, egg-like face devoid of eyes, nose, ears, or mouth. A magical creation born to torment mankind, it crafts illusions to don any visage, often posing as an unassuming human until the moment it strikes.

Possessing uncanny strength, it wields two-handed weapons—save lances, pole arms, or crossbows—in each hand with equal prowess, dealing [[/r 1d6 #Weapon damage]] or more by type. Its blank face, revealed at will, terrifies foes: those of 5 HD or less flee for [[/r 1d3 #Rounds of fear]] at triple speed, while stronger beings must save vs. wands or join them in panic.

Cunning and hateful, the Mujina infiltrates adventurer bands as a loyal retainer, biding its time before robbing them blind and vanishing. Appearing in groups of [[/r 1d4 #Mujinas wandering]] or [[/r 1d4 #Mujinas in lair]], it speaks Common, its own tongue, and Chaotic, its loathing for human individuality driving its treachery.

Terrain: Any, where humans are found

Mule.biography:
A mule is a crossbreed between a horse and a donkey, known for its stubbornness. If provoked, a mule may either bite or kick in self-defense but cannot be trained to attack. Mules are particularly strong for their size and can carry heavy loads for their owners, moving at half speed when overloaded.

Mules can accompany adventurers into dungeons if permitted by the DM. When found alone, they might belong to an NPC party nearby.

Mummy*.biography:
Mummies are undead creatures created from the bandage-wrapped remains of nobles or guardians, usually lurking in ruins or tombs. Tasked with protecting their tombs, they will relentlessly pursue trespassers.

Upon seeing a mummy, characters must make a saving throw vs. paralysis or become frozen in fear until the mummy is out of sight. The mummy’s touch causes 1d12 damage and inflicts a disease that prevents all magical healing and reduces natural healing to 10% of normal. This disease can only be cured magically.

Mummies are only damaged by spells, fire, or magical weapons, and even then, these deal half damage. Mummies are immune to sleep, charm, and hold spells.

Terrain: Ruins

Neanderthal.biography:
Neanderthals, often called cavemen, roam hills, mountains, and prehistoric wilds in family groups, their squat, robust frames boasting large bones and powerful sinew. With apelike visages marked by prominent brow ridges, they dwell in caves and caverns far from human settlements or in hidden 'lost world' enclaves.

In combat, they hurl spears or swing stone axes, clubs, or hammers, each strike bolstered by a +1 damage bonus from their brute strength (e.g., [[/r 1d6+1 #Weapon damage]] for spear or club). Shy yet not inherently hostile, they avoid humans but stand firm if provoked, favoring lawful kin like dwarves and gnomes while despising goblins, kobolds, and ogres—the latter attacked on sight.

Living in groups of [[/r 1d10 #Neanderthals wandering]] or lairs of [[/r 1d4*10 #Neanderthals in lair]] with two leaders, they hunt cave bears, keep white apes as companions, and hoard modest treasures. Groomed and clad properly, they might pass for humans, though their grasp of Common remains rudimentary.

Terrain: Hill, Mountain; Any (prehistoric)

Neanderthal, Leader.biography:
Neanderthal Leaders tower over their kin, standing up to 10 feet tall with squat, muscular builds and apelike features—large brows framing fierce eyes. Found in hill, mountain, or prehistoric cave lairs far from human reach, they guide family groups with an almost distinct racial presence.

Wielding larger stone axes, clubs, or hammers, they strike with a +1 damage bonus from their immense strength (e.g., [[/r 1d8+1 #Weapon damage]] for axe), leading hunts against cave bears and keeping white apes as pets. Lawful in nature, they befriend dwarves and gnomes, loathe goblins and kobolds, and attack ogres without hesitation, rarely engaging humans unless threatened.

Two Leaders—one male, one female—oversee lairs of [[/r 1d4*10 #Neanderthals in lair]], their prowess evident in combat and leadership (HD 6, XP 950). Shy yet resolute, they amass treasures, and might mimic human guise if groomed, though their speech in Common falters.

Nekrozon.biography:
Lurking in the swampy depths of the wilderness, the Nekrozon looms as a formidable beast, its massive buffalo-like body crowned with a long neck, a boar’s fierce head, and a lengthy tail. Known in ancient tales as a 'catoblepas,' a name now lost to time, it haunts these boggy realms with a deadly presence.

It strikes with the bony tip of its tail, inflicting [[/r 1d6 #Tail damage]] and carrying a 50% chance to knock down and stun its target for [[/r 1d6 #Rounds stunned]] (save vs. paralysis to resist). Its gaze, a 60-foot magical death ray, activates only if it lifts its head—a 1-in-4 chance each round—killing instantly unless a save vs. death ray prevails. Accidental eye contact on complete surprise (1 on 1d6) brings unavoidable death.

Impervious to energy drains, death rays, and instant-death effects except through raw damage, the Nekrozon roams alone or in small groups of [[/r 1d3 #Nekrozons in lair]], guarding modest treasures amidst the mire.

Terrain: Swamps

Nightshade, Nightcrawler (25HD)*.biography:
The Nightshade, Nightcrawler slithers forth as a monstrous, jet-black worm, 100 feet long and 10-15 feet wide, its eyeless maw sensing all—seen or unseen—through eldritch power. Forged or summoned by greater evils for dire purposes, it prowls any terrain, its unbroken obsidian hue a mark of death’s intent.

Daylight hinders it with a -4 attack penalty, while its aura spoils all consumables within 120', chilling the air as a warning to the wise. Immune to illusions, wands, poison, charm, hold, cold, spells below 6th level, and weapons below +3, it halves dragon breath damage (quarter with a save), regenerating [[/r 3 #Hit points per round]]. It silently wields charm person, invisibility, haste, confusion, cloudkill (21st-level magic-user), darkness, hold person, cause disease, dispel magic, and finger of death (21st-level cleric) at will.

Its bite rends for [[/r 2d10 #Bite damage]] and its tail stings for [[/r 2d4 #Sting damage]], both poisoned (-2 save penalty). A 19-20 bite swallows, draining 1 level per round (no save, negated by protection from evil), while the sting has a 1-in-8 death chance. It shrinks one foe within 60' per round (save vs. spells or 1' size, +4 to hit thereafter), summons undead every 4 hours (1d6: 1-3 shade, 4-5 haunt, 6 hand druj), resists turning with a save vs. spells, and hoards swallowed treasures.
Terrain: Any

0YvjFXhI4jW0okaR.description: The Magic Wand saving throw is used to avoid the effects of attacks or abilities activated through magical wands, such as paralysis rays or damage-dealing beams. A successful save, rolled on a d20, indicates that the character avoids or mitigates the harmful effects. The target number to save is determined by the character's class and level, as found on the saving throw table​​.
0YvjFXhI4jW0okaR.name: Magic Wand

Nightshade, Nightcrawler (30HD)*.biography:
The Nightshade, Nightcrawler slithers forth as a monstrous, jet-black worm, 100 feet long and 10-15 feet wide, its eyeless maw sensing all—seen or unseen—through eldritch power. Forged or summoned by greater evils for dire purposes, it prowls any terrain, its unbroken obsidian hue a mark of death’s intent.

Daylight hinders it with a -4 attack penalty, while its aura spoils all consumables within 120', chilling the air as a warning to the wise. Immune to illusions, wands, poison, charm, hold, cold, spells below 6th level, and weapons below +3, it halves dragon breath damage (quarter with a save), regenerating [[/r 3 #Hit points per round]]. It silently wields charm person, invisibility, haste, confusion, cloudkill (21st-level magic-user), darkness, hold person, cause disease, dispel magic, and finger of death (21st-level cleric) at will.

Its bite rends for [[/r 2d10 #Bite damage]] and its tail stings for [[/r 2d4 #Sting damage]], both poisoned (-2 save penalty). A 19-20 bite swallows, draining 1 level per round (no save, negated by protection from evil), while the sting has a 1-in-8 death chance. It shrinks one foe within 60' per round (save vs. spells or 1' size, +4 to hit thereafter), summons undead every 4 hours (1d6: 1-3 shade, 4-5 haunt, 6 hand druj), resists turning with a save vs. spells, and hoards swallowed treasures.

Nixie.biography:
Nixies, delicate water sprites standing 3 feet tall, grace rivers and lakes with their ethereal beauty, their light blue, green, or gray-green skin shimmering faintly. Kin to the forest folk—centaurs, dryads, actaeons, and their ilk—they craft lairs in the deepest aquatic hollows, shunning the surface unless necessity calls.

These beings prefer evasion over conflict, wielding a potent charm cast collectively by ten Nixies to ensnare intruders. A failed saving throw vs. spells binds the victim to a year of watery servitude, sustained by a daily water breathing spell each Nixie bestows upon her thrall. Should battle arise, they strike with small tridents or daggers, dealing [[/r 1d4 #Weapon damage]], and may summon a giant bass to aid them.

Dwelling in communities of [[/r 2d20 #Nixies in lair]], Nixies blend cunning and grace, their high intellect guiding their subtle defenses within their watery realms.

Terrain: River/Lake

Normal Human.biography:
Normal Humans represent the everyday folk who shun the call of adventure, lacking the specialized training of character classes yet sometimes boasting General Skills tailored to their lives. Found across settled lands, they embody the common populace—peasants, children, housewives, workers, artists, villagers, townsfolk, fishermen, and scholars.

Their resilience varies by age, health, and trade, with hit points selected rather than rolled, ranging from 1 for a frail child or ailing beggar to 7 for a robust blacksmith. In combat, they wield a single weapon—its damage dictated by type—though most play little role in grand tales, their lives too mundane to stir the threads of heroism.

Certain professions elevate their utility: merchants offer goods, soldiers lend martial aid with bolstered morale, lords wield influence, scouts provide guidance, sages share wisdom, and healers mend wounds. These exceptions aside, Normal Humans remain humble threads in the tapestry of settled existence.

Terrain: Settled

Nuckalavee.biography:
Dwelling in coastal oceans, tranquil lakes, and desolate ruins, the Nuckalavee emerges as a malevolent amphibious kin to the centaur, its form marked by a grotesque, oversized head. Its transparent skin reveals a ghastly sight—white, sinewy muscles, yellow veins pulsing with life, and dark blood flowing beneath—evoking dread in all who behold it.

This fearsome creature shrugs off fire and poison, regenerating [[/r 3 #Hit points per round]] each round, yet it recoils from crossing flowing freshwater. Its mere presence radiates terror within a 50' radius, forcing all nearby to save vs. paralysis or flee for [[/r 2d6 #Rounds of fear]], a test repeated each round they linger. Small creatures and insects with 2 hit points or less perish instantly within 120' of its aura.

In battle, the Nuckalavee rends with two claws, each dealing [[/r 3d8 #Claw damage]] plus a deadly curse—victims must save vs. death ray or perish. Every three rounds, it unleashes a chilling cone of cold, 60' long and 10' wide at the base, inflicting damage equal to its current hit points (save vs. dragon breath for half). Allied with undead, it converses freely with them, immune to their attacks unless under strict command.

Terrain: Lake (not river), Ocean (coastal), Ruins
Load: 3,000 cn at full speed; 6,000 cn at half speed

Ochre Jelly*.biography:
The Ochre Jelly lurks as a massive, ochre-hued amoeba, thriving in the dank confines of caverns and ruins. This amorphous creature shrugs off all but fire and cold assaults, its gelatinous form seeping through tiny fissures with ease.

In combat, it delivers a corrosive touch, inflicting [[/r 2d6 #Damage per round]] to bare flesh, while swiftly dissolving wood, leather, and cloth in a single round—though metal and stone remain impervious. Weapon strikes or lightning merely fracture it into [[/r 1d4+1 #Number of smaller jellies]] smaller versions, each with 2 Hit Dice and dealing half damage ([[/r 1d6 #Smaller jelly damage]]).

These smaller offshoots persist, posing continued threats unless consumed by flame or frost, the only forces capable of halting this relentless ooze.

Terrain: Cavern, Ruins

Ogre.biography:
Ogres are huge, fearsome humanlike creatures standing 8 to 10 feet tall. They are primitive, wearing animal skins for clothes and often living in caves. Ogres are greedy and aggressive, preferring to ambush travelers or bully them for food and gold rather than hunting for themselves.

When found outside their lair, each ogre carries [[/r 1d6 × 100 #Ogre gold pieces]] gp in large sacks. Ogres are notorious for hating neanderthals and will attack them on sight. They have no special combat tactics, relying on brute strength and large clubs to beat their prey into submission.

Weapon Damage: By weapon +2 (typically a large club).
Terrain: Cavern, Wilderness (any).

Orc.biography:
Orcs are ugly, humanlike creatures with a blend of animal and human features. Most orcs have human-shaped bodies, but many display bestial facial traits and sharp teeth.

Orcs are nocturnal omnivores and prefer to live underground. When forced to fight in daylight, they suffer a -1 penalty on attack rolls. They are short-tempered and tend to dislike other living creatures.

Each group of orcs has a leader with 8 hit points who gains a +1 bonus on damage rolls. If this leader is killed, the morale of the group drops to 6 instead of 8. Orcs are fearful of creatures larger or stronger than themselves but can be driven to fight by their leaders.

Orcs are frequently used as soldiers by Chaotic leaders, whether human or monster. They prefer using swords, spears, axes, and clubs in battle but cannot operate mechanical weapons like catapults, except for their leaders who understand such devices.

Orc tribes come in many varieties, with each tribe containing as many females as males and at least two children ("whelps") for every two adults. The leader of a tribe is a chieftain with 15 hit points, who fights as a 4 Hit Dice monster and gains a +2 bonus on damage rolls. For every 20 orcs in a tribe, there is a 1 in 6 chance that an ogre is present. Additionally, there is a 1 in 10 chance of a troll ally living in the tribe's lair.

Terrain: Wilderness (any)

Orc, Chieftain.biography:
The Orc Chieftain reigns over its tribe, a menacing humanoid with animalistic features—bestial teeth and rugged visage—etched into a manlike frame. Preferring the shadows of underground lairs, it leads its nocturnal kin, shunning daylight where its attacks suffer a -1 penalty.

Wielding a favored weapon—sword, spear, axe, or club—with a +2 damage bonus, the Orc Chieftain strikes as a 4 Hit Dice foe despite its base resilience. It governs a tribe of [[/r 1d6*10 #Orcs in lair]], bolstered by a leader per group, maintaining a morale of 8 that drops to 6 if the group leader falls, reflecting their dread of mightier adversaries unless compelled.

Chaotic overlords harness Orc Chieftains to fortify armies, leveraging their grasp of mechanical devices like catapults, a skill beyond lesser orcs. Tribes harbor equal numbers of females and at least two whelps per adult pair, with chances of ogre or troll allies enhancing their lairs.

Orc, Leader.biography:
The Orc Leader stands as a formidable figure among its kin, a brutish humanoid blending animalistic traits with a manlike form, often sporting beastly facial features and jagged teeth. Nocturnal by nature, it thrives underground, leading its group with a harsh temperament and a distaste for outsiders.

In daylight, the Orc Leader suffers a -1 penalty to attack rolls, wielding a preferred weapon—sword, spear, axe, or club—with a +1 bonus to damage rolls due to its prowess. It commands a group of 2d4 orcs in the wild or up to [[/r 1d6*10 #Orcs in lair]] in a lair, maintaining a morale of 8; if slain, the group’s morale drops to 6, reflecting their fear of stronger foes unless driven by its authority.

Chaotic leaders, both human and monstrous, often enlist Orc Leaders to bolster their forces, exploiting their inability to use complex machinery like catapults, a skill reserved for these commanders alone. Each tribe includes females and whelps, doubling the adult count with at least two children per pair.

Phantom, Apparition*.biography:
The Apparition emerges as a semi-transparent humanoid figure, reminiscent of a wight, haunting ruins across various locales while shunning sunlight, though untroubled by magical illumination. It lurks in an ethereal state initially, immune to damage from the Prime Plane until it materializes for combat.

Upon sighting, all within 120' must resist its fearsome presence with a saving throw vs. spells or flee in terror; creatures of 3 Hit Dice or less succumb automatically, refusing to return.

It begins combat by conjuring a swirling, semi-transparent mist—10' high, 20' radius—entrancing those within who fail a saving throw vs. spells, rendering them inactive for up to 12 rounds or until the mist dissipates.

Once it ensnares a victim, the Apparition solidifies (AC 0) and attacks with bony claws, gaining a +4 bonus to hit and dealing [[/r 1d6+2 #Claw damage]] per strike, favoring entranced targets. Resistant to clerical turning (saving throw vs. spells reflects 'T' results), it hoards its victims’ treasures nearby. Victims slain by it rise as Apparitions within a week unless a dispel evil precedes a raise dead spell; otherwise, they fade into undeath.

Terrain: Ruins

Similar to an apparition, this creature looks like a single humanoid wielding a dagger, haunts indoor and underground ruins, evading sunlight but unfazed by magical light. It begins in an ethereal state, untouchable from the Prime Plane until it strikes.

With a 90% chance to surprise, it emerges through walls or doors, its gaze forcing a victim within 120' to save vs. spells or flee (3 HD or less fail automatically, refusing to return). Its initial assault brandishes the dagger, requiring a save vs. death ray or instant death from horror.

Phoenix, Greater*.biography:
Born of the elemental plane of Fire, the Greater Phoenix takes the form of an immense red-orange eagle cloaked in searing flames. Rarely seen on the Prime Plane, it adapts to any climate but eschews underground haunts. It remains tranquil unless challenged.

Impervious to all fire, charm, and hold spells, it also deflects strikes from weapons below +3 enchantment. In combat, it wields its claws and beak, its radiant blaze searing enemies within a 20' radius for [[/r 6d6 #Fire damage per round]], unhindered by fire defenses due to the distinct nature of phoenix flame.

When overcome, the Greater Phoenix bursts in a 20' radius explosion, unleashing [[/r 1d10*10 #Explosion damage]] (save vs. dragon breath for half, bypassing fire protection), then resurrects from its ashes 1 round later, fully renewed, and takes flight to escape. A wish alone can eradicate it permanently; its rebirth cycle is an unsolved enigma.

Each vanquishing yields one feather. A single feather (worth 25,000 gp) crafts a potion of phoenix fire resistance, providing total immunity to normal and magical fire, halving fire breath damage (quarter with a save), and conferring standard resistance to phoenix fire.

Pixie.biography:
Pixies are small humanoid creatures with insect-like wings. Standing at only 1-2 feet tall, they are distantly related to elves. Pixies are naturally invisible unless they wish to be seen or are detected by magic.

Unlike creatures affected by invisibility spells, pixies can attack while remaining invisible. They always gain surprise when doing so, and cannot be attacked in the first round of combat. In subsequent rounds, attackers can attempt to strike them, but with a -4 penalty to attack rolls.

Pixies live in secluded wilderness communities and rarely attack humans unless provoked. They may, however, assist friendly adventurers with guidance through the wilderness or lead them to hidden locations.

Terrain: Woods.
Flight Limitation: Pixies can fly for up to three turns before requiring a full turn of rest.

A plasm looks like a human- or giant-sized skeleton made of elemental matter.

There are four types, one for each element, composed of elemental material and ectoplasm (solid ether). It cannot safely exist outside the Ethereal Plane or wormholes, losing 1 Hit Die per round from energy drain on other planes, vanishing when dead.

It feeds on its element, regenerating 1 hit point per round, and gains Hit Dice from elemental magic attacks (e.g., a 9th-level fireball adds 9d8 HP to a fire plasm).

Immune to poison and normal weapons, magical weapons deal only their 'plus' damage (e.g., sword +4 deals 4 damage). Only magical weapons and opposing elemental attacks harm it.

Once per turn, it can spend 10 hit points to create a 30' diameter acid cloud lasting [[/r 1d6 #Rounds of cloud duration]] rounds, dealing 20 damage (save vs. dragon breath for half), often used when fleeing.

Purple Worm.biography:
Purple Worms are huge, slime-covered creatures over 100' long and 8' to 10' in diameter. These monsters tunnel through the earth, burrowing up from the ground to feed on surface-dwelling creatures.

They attack by biting and stinging with their tails. If the bite attack roll is 4 or more greater than needed (or a 20), they swallow man-sized or smaller creatures whole, dealing [[/r 3d6 #Damage per round swallowed]] damage each round thereafter. A tail sting requires a save vs. poison or the victim dies. Underground, tunnel size may limit attacks.

When tunneling to approach, they have a 1 in 4 chance to surprise, but [[/r 1d4+1 #Rounds until tail free]] rounds pass before the tail is free.

Terrain: Cavern, Ruins, Swamp, Woods (dense)

Revener.biography:
This monster appears as a human figure with skeletal hands and a skull-like head adorned with flowing white hair. A Revener prowls through dark, underground caverns, as well as dust-filled tombs and crypts.

When it touches a victim, it permanently drains one of the victim's senses. The victim may make a saving throw against spells; success indicates that the loss is temporary, lasting only [[/r 2d6 #Rounds of sense loss]] rounds. The lost sense can be chosen or randomly determined, and subsequent hits always drain different senses.

A rescore spell will restore one lost sense.

Taste: The victim cannot identify tastes (such as those of potions).

Smell: The victim is immune to vile odor effects but suffers a -1 penalty to surprise rolls.

Hearing: The victim cannot hear and loses the ability to speak clearly, which may ruin spellcasting.

Touch: The victim's Dexterity drops by 4 points (and, if the victim is an elf, they cannot find secret doors).

Sight: The victim is blinded.

Sixth Sense: The victim may not use ESP, crystal balls, telepathy, or similar extra-sensory magical effects.

Terrain: Ruins.

Rhagodessa.biography:
The Rhagodessa is a giant spiderlike carnivore, roughly the size of a small horse, with an oversized yellow head and mandibles, and a dark brown thorax. It has five pairs of legs, the front pair ending in suckers that grasp prey.

A leg hit deals no damage but sticks the victim, pulling them to the mandibles for an automatic bite in the next round. Note: The rules don't state how to free oneself from the leg grab. One option is that a successful Strength ability check results in the grasped victim being free. A more unforgiving rule is that the grasp remains until the creature is slain.

These nocturnal hunters operate only in darkness, typically residing in caves and capable of climbing walls.

When its antennae hit a target, any nonmagical metal armor or weapon crumbles to rust instantly. Magical metal items lose one 'plus' per hit unless they resist (10% chance per 'plus'—e.g., a shield +1 has a 10% chance to survive). The creature can be struck by any weapon type without harming the weapon if the body is hit, not the antennae.

It resembles a massive snakelike lizard, measuring between 12 and 16 feet in length, with bright orange-yellow and orange-red scales. Sasquatch.biography:
Sasquatches are shy, low-intelligence humanoids dwelling deep in dark woods and high mountains. These tall, apelike creatures have crested heads, large feet, and thick hair—dark brown in woodlands, white in mountains. Omnivorous, they occasionally slay animals but prefer plants and berries.

Though not aggressive with a low morale of 6, they defend their cavern lairs fiercely, raising their morale to 11 when protecting their home, using clublike fists. They can also throw boulders up to 50 feet. If both claws hit one victim, they hug for an additional 4d6 damage.

Known as 'Bigfoot' in woods and 'Yeti' or 'Abominable Snowman' in mountains, they can rarely be spellcasters.

Sea Hag*.biography:
The Sea Hag is one of the most repulsive creatures known, feared for its horrifying appearance and deadly powers.

Horrific Visage: Any creature that sees the Sea Hag or comes within 10 feet must make a saving throw vs. spells at -6 or flee in terror for 1d20+5 rounds.

Energy Draining Touch: A Sea Hag’s touch acts as an energy drain, reducing the victim’s level by one (as a wight). Additionally, it causes disease (no saving throw).

Undead Control: Though not undead itself, the Sea Hag can command undead as if it were a 16 HD undead creature.

Weaknesses & Resistances: A Sea Hag can only be harmed by silver or magical weapons.

Environment & Lair: It lives primarily in shallow coastal waters but can venture onto land for up to three hours at a time.

Companions: Often accompanied by undead or other sinister creatures.

Shadow*.biography:
Shadows are ghostly, intelligent creatures that are noncorporeal in nature, resembling real shadows. Despite their eerie appearance, they are not undead. These beings dwell in dark, foreboding places such as dungeons, dense forests, or ancient ruins. Shadows are immune to damage from non-magical weapons and can only be harmed by enchanted arms.

They possess the ability to alter their shape slightly, which helps them blend into their surroundings. Due to their elusive nature, shadows are difficult to detect and often surprise their opponents, achieving surprise on a roll of 1-5 on a d6.

When a shadow attacks and hits, it inflicts both physical damage and drains 1 point of Strength from the victim. This Strength loss lasts for 8 turns. If a creature’s Strength is reduced to zero, they are transformed into a shadow themselves.

Shadows are immune to sleep and charm spells. While they share some characteristics with undead creatures, they are not classified as undead and cannot be turned by clerics.

Common Terrain: Ruins, Woods.

Shrew, Giant.biography:
Giant Shrews resemble large, brown-furred rats with elongated snouts. They are adept at burrowing, climbing, or jumping up to 5 feet. Their weak eyes render them unaffected by light or darkness, relying instead on radar-like squeaks to 'see' within 60 feet as effectively as normal sight. A silence 15' radius spell blinds them, reducing their AC to 8 and imposing a -4 penalty on attack rolls due to confusion.

These shrews always take initiative on their first attack and gain a +1 bonus on initiative rolls thereafter. Their ferocious bites target the head and shoulders, forcing victims of 3 Hit Dice or less to save vs. death ray or flee in fear.

Though they only eat insects and vegetable matter, their nervousness and aggression lead them to attack anything within 20 feet.

Terrain: Open, Ruins, Woods

Shrieker.biography:
Shriekers resemble giant mushrooms, thriving in underground caverns and capable of slow movement. They react to light within 60 feet or movement within 30 feet by emitting a piercing shriek lasting for [[/r 1d3 #Rounds of shrieking]] rounds. Each round of shrieking prompts a 1d6 roll by the DM; a result of 4-6 means a wandering monster hears the noise and arrives in [[/r 2d6 #Rounds until arrival]] rounds.

This shriek can stun small animals, particularly birds and bats, which the shriekers then crawl over to consume through feeding orifices on the bottom of their stalks. They also scavenge carrion left nearby.


Terrain: Cavern, Ruins

Slug, Giant (10 HD).biography:
The Giant Slug is a massive, boneless creature inhabiting underground caverns and dungeons. Its rubbery body can squeeze through any opening 5' x 5' or larger. The slug can burrow at a rate of 30' per turn, 10' per round.

Due to its elasticity, attackers cannot apply strength bonuses to damage, blunt weapons only inflict magical damage (none if non-magical), and edged weapons deal half damage plus magical adjustments. The fighter's Smash option inflicts no additional damage. It can bite with its sharp tongue or spit acid, preferring the latter. The acid attack has a range of 5' per Hit Die, with the first shot always missing to range in, followed by normal attacks. Victims hit by acid take damage equal to the slug's current hit points, halved with a successful save vs. dragon breath, and failed saves may destroy equipment. Giant slugs can have up to 20 Hit Dice.
Terrain: Cavern, Ruins

Slug, Giant (20 HD).biography:
The Giant Slug is a massive, boneless creature inhabiting underground caverns and dungeons. Its rubbery body can squeeze through any opening 5' x 5' or larger. The slug can burrow at a rate of 30' per turn, 10' per round.

Due to its elasticity, attackers cannot apply strength bonuses to damage, blunt weapons only inflict magical damage (none if non-magical), and edged weapons deal half damage plus magical adjustments. The fighter's Smash option inflicts no additional damage. It can bite with its sharp tongue or spit acid, preferring the latter. The acid attack has a range of 5' per Hit Die, with the first shot always missing to range in, followed by normal attacks. Victims hit by acid take damage equal to the slug's current hit points, halved with a successful save vs. dragon breath, and failed saves may destroy equipment. Giant slugs can have up to 20 Hit Dice.
Terrain: Cavern, Ruins

Spectral Hound*.biography:
Spectral Hounds are eerie creatures hailing from the Dimensional Vortex, the void between dimensions. They manifest in this world as ghostly, pale, translucent dogs with eyes like formless pools of utter blackness. Renowned for their tracking prowess, they pursue their quarry relentlessly for days. These hounds are bred and trained by interplanar beings such as elemental rulers, amirs, and pashas as hunting animals, often deployed to track intrusive adventurers back to their home planes or, conversely, potentially charmed by adventurers to hunt villains across dimensions. They never appear on the Prime Plane unless summoned by greater powers.

In combat, a spectral hound bites, dealing damage and triggering a save vs. spells. A successful save limits the damage to 2d6, but failure initiates a gradual fading process, turning the victim translucent like the hound over 24 hours. The victim's equipment remains unaffected, but once fully faded, they cannot hold normal items, hear, or speak to unfaded beings, perceiving normal things as translucent while faded entities appear solid.

A dimension door spell can restore a faded character to normal at any time by allowing them to step through it.

Spectral hounds can only be harmed by silver or magical weapons, not normal ones, and are immune to fire- and cold-based spells.

Terrain: Any; including all dimensional planes

Spider, Planar (10 HD).biography:
The Planar Spiders are intelligent, plane-traveling arachnids with an enigmatic civilization. They can move through planes and dimensions at will, often appearing from the Ethereal plane to attack and then 'shift' back. Most commonly encountered with 5 Hit Dice, leaders can have up to 12. Their home plane is described as a world covered with cities made of imperishable white webs, though no such cities have been found.

These spiders speak Common and are not inherently hostile, capable of interactions similar to human NPCs. In combat, they gain automatic initiative when shifting planes, and there's a 75% chance they cannot be attacked before leaving unless the opponent is hasted.

Their bite deals damage and requires a saving throw vs. poison at -4, or death, though they can choose to not use their poison.

May have [[/r 1d3 #miscellaneous magical items]] miscellaneous magical items or [[/r 1d4 #odd but nonmagical items]] odd but nonmagical items familiar to spiders.

Rarely, some are spellcasters, either clerics or magic-users up to 9th level, with extra asterisks for XP calculation based on spellcasting ability. Spellcasting spiders cannot phase out in the same round they cast a spell.

Terrain: Any

Spirit, Druj*.biography:
Druj appear as body parts, floating or crawling about in a horrible way. A druj is usually encountered in the form of a hand, eye, or skull. Druj are very intelligent and strongly evil, far more dangerous than they may seem.

A druj can split its essence, creating four (identical) forms instead of one. This can be performed only once per night. Each of the forms can attack separately, but only one of the forms is able to cast spells (as given above). The form using the spells can often be distinguished, as it will hover nearby while the other forms attack. If that form is slain, one of the surviving forms immediately gains all unused spellcasting abilities. All four forms are poisonous.

If turned by a cleric, the parts of a druj turned are forced to reunite into one creature, remaining united for [[/r 1d4 + 1 #Rounds united]] rounds. Further success at turning is handled normally.

Druj are always encountered singly unless commanded into service by a lich or more powerful member of the Sphere of Death. In such cases, two druj eyes may rest within a druj skull, accompanied by two druj hands; no more than these five druj can ever gather in one place.

Eye: An eye druj darts about, trying to touch (poison) its opponent; a touch does not inflict any damage other than poisoning. Each eye druj can also gaze at one victim per round (30' range), in addition to its physical attack. The victim must make a saving throw vs. paralysis or be paralyzed for [[/r 1d4 #Turns paralyzed]] turns. The eye druj may touch a paralyzed victim automatically.

Hand: A hand druj inflicts [[/r 1d4 #Points of damage]] when it hits, and thereafter holds onto its victim, causing automatic damage each round thereafter. The damage caused is equal to the AC of the victim, ignoring dexterity and shield bonuses, plus [[/r 1d4 #Points]] each round. If the adjusted armor class is a negative number, the attack will still inflict [[/r 1d4 #Points of damage]] each round.

Skull: A skull druj floats toward and bites its victim. When first approached, the victim must make a saving throw vs. spells or be frozen with fear, allowing the skull druj to bite (no attack roll needed) for [[/r 2d4 #Points of damage]]. The normal saving throw vs. poison applies to each bite.

All Spirits

Spirits are powerful evil beings inhabiting the bodies (or body parts) of others; they are among the nastiest of undead monsters. They are immune to spells below 4th level, and cannot be harmed by normal weapons or magical weapons of less than +2 enchantment.

All spirits are travelers, never staying in one place for more than one night; they become invisible and nearly powerless (except to move) with the light of dawn, regaining their powers at dusk. In daylight, any spirit can travel up to 24 miles per day (1 hex).

All spirits are poisonous. When hit by a spirit in hand-to-hand combat, the victim must make a saving throw vs. poison or die immediately. A new saving throw must be made for each hit by the spirit.

The poisonous presence of a spirit causes all consumable items within 30', including normal food and water, holy water, all rations (even iron) and even magical potions to become spoiled and useless (but not poisoned), with no saving throw allowed. Even living plants and small insects within this area are paralyzed, dying if the spirit remains there more than an hour. This effect negates all forms of plant control, insect swarms and plagues, both normal and magical.

All spirits can sense invisible things, and can attack them without penalty. All spirits can, once per round, at will, create the following cleric spell effects: darkness, silence 15' radius, cause disease, animate dead, finger of death (all as if cast by a 16th level cleric). A spirit will often pause to animate the body of a fallen victim, creating and controlling it as a zombie to fight for it and add to the chaos. (Attempts at turning such zombies are made as if turning the spirit itself!) All of these spell-like abilities require concentration, as do normal spells, so while using an ability, a spirit cannot attack physically. Unlike normal cleric spells, no words or gestures are needed.

Spirit, Odic*.biography:
This evil spirit travels up to 24 miles each day, settling into a plant by night. It is dangerous even if avoided, as it animates parts of the plant to do its bidding. The plant can easily be seen at long range (up to 300 yards), as the odic radiates a purplish light in a 20' radius. Any living being within this light must make a saving throw vs. spells or lose 1 level because of energy drain (as if struck by a wight).

Once it has settled for the night, an odic cannot move from the spot until daybreak. While using its spells, it can attack by animating part of the plant. The longest branch or vine of the plant reaches out (10-30' range), attacking as a 16 HD monster and inflicting 1d12 points of damage per hit (in addition to poison).

The plant is immediately killed when the odic possesses it. The creature uses the plant's parts to seek out other life to feed on. Most commonly, it animates individual leaves, which float away (movement rate 30' per round) in search of victims; it can animate up to 6 such leaves at one time. The leaves may be seen up to 1 mile from the odic. Animated leaves normally gain surprise (90% chance). Each leaf attacks as if a 4 Hit Dice monster; no damage is inflicted, but each victim hit must make a saving throw vs. spells or be charmed. A charmed victim is drawn toward the odic and has a -4 penalty on the saving throw against the energy drain when entering the purple aura.

If the plant possessed has no detachable leaves, the odic may animate other portions (pine needles, flowers, etc.) in a similar manner, as described above—up to 6 at once, each with a charm ability per touch.

Odics occasionally inhabit the bodies of plantlike monsters. The creature may make a saving throw vs. spells to avoid the possession, but may die from the level draining and other abilities of the odic even if the saving throw is successful. The odic gains the abilities of any plantlike monster possessed. They may be used in addition to the normal abilities of the odic.

Odics are always encountered singly.

All Spirits

Spirits are powerful evil beings inhabiting the bodies (or body parts) of others; they are among the nastiest of undead monsters. They are immune to spells below 4th level, and cannot be harmed by normal weapons or magical weapons of less than +2 enchantment.

All spirits are travelers, never staying in one place for more than one night; they become invisible and nearly powerless (except to move) with the light of dawn, regaining their powers at dusk. In daylight, any spirit can travel up to 24 miles per day (1 hex).

All spirits are poisonous. When hit by a spirit in hand-to-hand combat, the victim must make a saving throw vs. poison or die immediately. A new saving throw must be made for each hit by the spirit.

The poisonous presence of a spirit causes all consumable items within 30', including normal food and water, holy water, all rations (even iron) and even magical potions to become spoiled and useless (but not poisoned), with no saving throw allowed. Even living plants and small insects within this area are paralyzed, dying if the spirit remains there more than an hour. This effect negates all forms of plant control, insect swarms and plagues, both normal and magical.

All spirits can sense invisible things, and can attack them without penalty. All spirits can, once per round, at will, create the following cleric spell effects: darkness, silence 15' radius, cause disease, animate dead, finger of death (all as if cast by a 16th level cleric). A spirit will often pause to animate the body of a fallen victim, creating and controlling it as a zombie to fight for it and add to the chaos. (Attempts at turning such zombies are made as if turning the spirit itself!) All of these spell-like abilities require concentration, as do normal spells, so while using an ability, a spirit cannot attack physically. Unlike normal cleric spells, no words or gestures are needed.

A spirit normally has no treasure, though it may occasionally serve as a guard for some special item. Those characters who risk travel at night may encounter a spirit with 1d6 of its victims, who may carry treasure.

This horror appears to be a zombie, though it walks at a faster rate. It never carries weapons. The revenant roams the night in search of victims, surprising them 50% of the time. It can leap once per turn to a 60' range; when both surprising and leaping on a victim, its three attacks all hit (no attack rolls needed), causing normal damage and three separate saving throws vs. poison.

Once per night, a revenant can summon 1d4 spectres to come to its aid. The spectres will arrive 1d6 + 2 rounds after being summoned, and will obey and fight for the revenant. They may be turned as normal spectres.

Revenants are resistant to turning attempts. If any "D" result is indicated, the revenant may make a saving throw vs. spells; if successful, the attempt has no effect. A "turn" result gives no saving throw, but the revenant will return in 1d4 turns.
