Sporacle.biography:
The sporacle appears identical to a beholder at first glance: a floating ball-like creature, in diameter, with a huge gaping mouth and a large central eye above it. Tentacles sprout from its entire body. It has six eyes, positioned evenly about the surface of the body (top, bottom, front, back, sides). It normally keeps all but a few upper tentacles retracted.

A sporacle regenerates by submersing itself in fresh water (but not in brine) at the rate of 3 hit points per round so lost body parts may be rapidly regrown. If a loose tentacle falls or is placed in water, it will grow into a whole creature in 1 hour. This is their only method of reproduction, so they are often found near a water source.

A sporacle may attack anything, but prefers humanoids as food. As it moves into combat, it extends all its tentacles, appearing to sprout them as it attacks. It moves through air or water by magical flight, but is very quick. It spins rapidly in all directions when in combat, using all of its tentacles each round against 1 or 2 opponents. A sporacle has average intelligence (10) and cannot use spells or magical items.

The sporacle prefers not to bite victims that are still moving. It uses its tentacle attacks only until all have been destroyed; only then will it resort to its ferocious bite. Each tentacle hit inflicts 1 point of damage, and each requires a saving throw vs. paralysis. Failure indicates that the venomous tentacle has struck skin, and takes effect. This paralysis is a delayed sort, however, taking effect after 1 round passes; it lasts for 1 turn thereafter unless cured. If its opponents flee, it will remain to feast upon its paralyzed victims; if there are none, it always pursues.

The sporacle may be damaged by any sort of edged weapon, and by any missile weapon except a sling. However, it is immune to blunt weapons and to all spells and magical devices except those that cause damage; these will destroy one tentacle per die of damage (or per magic missile), not affecting the creature's hit points. Once all the tentacles are destroyed, such spells have no further effect. Sporacles cannot hear and are immune to all sound-based effects; they are also immune to poison, paralysis, and charms.

If any attacker declares the tentacles to be the target of the blow and wields an edged weapon, the tentacle is AC 4 and easily severed. After falling off, a tentacle will live for up to 1 hour, remaining venomous for that time. When the creature is reduced to 0 hit points or less, its body comes apart grotesquely, spinning wildly and sending all remaining tentacles in various directions. (Make final attack rolls as applicable.)

Terrain: Cavern

Statue, Living Crystal.biography:
A living crystal statue is a life form made of crystals instead of flesh. Crystal statues can look like statues of anything, but often appear human.

All Living Statues

Living statues are created by a powerful wizard. They appear to be perfectly normal statues—until they move! A living statue may be any size or material; the sizes given are typical. Living crystal, iron, and rock statues are given as examples, and the DM may create others. (Not every statue in a campaign should be a living statue. If every statue in your campaign is a living statue, PCs will know that any statue they see can attack them. Have noblemen possess statuary as treasure and decoration; have expensive public buildings and plazas be decorated with statues; living statues are very rare in comparison with the numbers of "real" statues.)

Living statues are not affected by sleep spells.

Statue, Living Iron.biography:
A living iron statue has a body that can absorb iron and steel. It takes normal damage when hit, but if a nonmagical metal weapon is used, the attacker must make a saving throw vs. spells or the weapon will become stuck in the body of the living iron statue, and can only be removed if the statue is killed. (If the weapon is left in the statue, the statue will eventually absorb the metal completely and eject nonmetal parts, so the statue will not forever walk around with weapons sticking out of it.)

All Living Statues

Living statues are created by a powerful wizard. They appear to be perfectly normal statues—until they move! A living statue may be any size or material; the sizes given are typical. Living crystal, iron, and rock statues are given as examples, and the DM may create others. (Not every statue in a campaign should be a living statue. If every statue in your campaign is a living statue, PCs will know that any statue they see can attack them. Have noblemen possess statuary as treasure and decoration; have expensive public buildings and plazas be decorated with statues; living statues are very rare in comparison with the numbers of "real" statues.)

Living statues are not affected by sleep spells.

Terrain: Dungeon, Castle

Each creature’s breath weapon has specific effects, such as damage, paralysis, or petrification. A successful saving throw generally halves the damage or avoids the secondary effect (such as paralysis or petrification), while failure applies the full consequences. Stirge.biography:
A stirge is a birdlike creature with a long nose. It attacks by thrusting its beak into the victim's body and feeds on blood. A successful hit (for [[/r 1d3 #Points of damage]]) points of damage means that it has attached itself to the victim, sucking for [[/r 1d3 #Points of damage]] points of damage per round until the victim is dead.

A flying stirge gains a bonus of +2 on its first attack roll against any one opponent due to its speedy diving attack.

Terrain: Cavern, Ruins, Woods.

Termite, Water (Fresh Water).biography:
Water termites range from 1'-5' long, the largest found only in ocean waters. All are shaped like normal termites, except for an elastic sac in their abdomen that can intake and expel water for movement and feeding. When the sac is completely expanded, the creature looks like a large balloon with a small insect-like head on the front.

The creature does not bite unless cornered; instead, it uses an inky spray for defense. When frightened above water, a normal attack roll must be made. A victim hit by the spray must make a saving throw vs. poison or be paralyzed for 1 turn. If the creature is frightened underwater, its ink does not paralyze, but merely provides an inky cover for the creature's retreat.

The real terror of these creatures is the destruction they bring to ships. They cling to hulls, each causing points of hull damage equal to their bite before letting go. Once any damage has been inflicted, there is a 50% chance per round that someone will notice the leakage.

Terrain: Swamp, Lake, Ocean.

The Thug, also called an Assassin, belongs to the Pragmati, a ruthless organization of rogue executioners who take contracts for murder. Unlike the Thieves' Guild, the Pragmati operate independently, using secrecy, extortion, and violence to maintain power.

Stealth & Deception: Thugs rely on disguise, ambush tactics, and treachery. They use garrotes, poison, and cheap but effective weapons, avoiding traceable magical items. They rarely attack openly, preferring to strike unseen and disappear without a trace.

Guild Secrecy: Thugs work in the shadows, often blackmailing former clients. They will betray anyone, even their employers, for the right price.

Combat & Assassination: Thugs have the abilities of a thief of the same level, including move silently, hide in shadows, and climb walls. When setting an ambush, they roll 1-3 on 1d6 for surprise instead of the usual 1-2. If they gain surprise, they may attempt an instant kill with a base 50% ± (5% per HD difference). If the attempt fails, they deal normal weapon damage.

Weakness & Strategy: If wounded or exposed, thugs prefer retreat over combat. They sometimes work as guards for high-ranking criminals, occasionally partnering with bandits or renegades, though often without their allies' knowledge.

Terrain: Any; Settled.

Thug (2HD).biography:
The Thug, also called an Assassin, belongs to the Pragmati, a ruthless organization of rogue executioners who take contracts for murder. Unlike the Thieves' Guild, the Pragmati operate independently, using secrecy, extortion, and violence to maintain power.

Stealth & Deception: Thugs rely on disguise, ambush tactics, and treachery. They use garrotes, poison, and cheap but effective weapons, avoiding traceable magical items. They rarely attack openly, preferring to strike unseen and disappear without a trace.

Guild Secrecy: Thugs work in the shadows, often blackmailing former clients. They will betray anyone, even their employers, for the right price.

Combat & Assassination: Thugs have the abilities of a thief of the same level, including move silently, hide in shadows, and climb walls. When setting an ambush, they roll 1-3 on 1d6 for surprise instead of the usual 1-2. If they gain surprise, they may attempt an instant kill with a base 50% ± (5% per HD difference). If the attempt fails, they deal normal weapon damage.

Weakness & Strategy: If wounded or exposed, thugs prefer retreat over combat. They sometimes work as guards for high-ranking criminals, occasionally partnering with bandits or renegades, though often without their allies' knowledge.

Terrain: Any; Settled.

Thug (5HD).name: Thug (5HD)

Thug (6HD).biography:
The Thug, also called an Assassin, belongs to the Pragmati, a ruthless organization of rogue executioners who take contracts for murder. Unlike the Thieves' Guild, the Pragmati operate independently, using secrecy, extortion, and violence to maintain power.

Stealth & Deception: Thugs rely on disguise, ambush tactics, and treachery. They use garrotes, poison, and cheap but effective weapons, avoiding traceable magical items. They rarely attack openly, preferring to strike unseen and disappear without a trace.

Guild Secrecy: Thugs work in the shadows, often blackmailing former clients. They will betray anyone, even their employers, for the right price.

Combat & Assassination: Thugs have the abilities of a thief of the same level, including move silently, hide in shadows, and climb walls. When setting an ambush, they roll 1-3 on 1d6 for surprise instead of the usual 1-2. If they gain surprise, they may attempt an instant kill with a base 50% ± (5% per HD difference). If the attempt fails, they deal normal weapon damage.

Weakness & Strategy: If wounded or exposed, thugs prefer retreat over combat. They sometimes work as guards for high-ranking criminals, occasionally partnering with bandits or renegades, though often without their allies' knowledge.

Terrain: Any; Settled.

Thug (9HD).biography:
The Thug, also called an Assassin, belongs to the Pragmati, a ruthless organization of rogue executioners who take contracts for murder. Unlike the Thieves' Guild, the Pragmati operate independently, using secrecy, extortion, and violence to maintain power.

Stealth & Deception: Thugs rely on disguise, ambush tactics, and treachery. They use garrotes, poison, and cheap but effective weapons, avoiding traceable magical items. They rarely attack openly, preferring to strike unseen and disappear without a trace.

Guild Secrecy: Thugs work in the shadows, often blackmailing former clients. They will betray anyone, even their employers, for the right price.

Combat & Assassination: Thugs have the abilities of a thief of the same level, including move silently, hide in shadows, and climb walls. When setting an ambush, they roll 1-3 on 1d6 for surprise instead of the usual 1-2. If they gain surprise, they may attempt an instant kill with a base 50% ± (5% per HD difference). If the attempt fails, they deal normal weapon damage.

Weakness & Strategy: If wounded or exposed, thugs prefer retreat over combat. They sometimes work as guards for high-ranking criminals, occasionally partnering with bandits or renegades, though often without their allies' knowledge.

Terrain: Any; Settled.

Toad, Giant.biography:
The Giant Toad is roughly the size of a very large dog, weighing between 150-250 pounds. It has the ability to change its skin color to camouflage itself in woods or poorly lit dungeons, surprising its prey on a roll of 1-3 on 1d6. Its tongue can extend out to 15 feet, dragging victims of dwarf size or smaller towards its mouth for biting. On a natural 20 attack roll, it can swallow small prey whole, dealing [[/r 1d6 #Damage per round after being swallowed]] damage each subsequent round.

Toad, Rock/Cave.biography:
The Rock Toad, or Cave Toad, resides in rocky, cold areas like high mountains or frozen deserts. It's roughly the size of a large dog, weighs about 150 pounds, and has a hard, bumpy shell like a turtle. Its most notable feature is its multi-faceted, hypnotic eyes that compel creatures to save vs. paralysis or be paralyzed for [[/r 2d4 #Rounds paralyzed]] rounds. After death, its eyes emit a feeble light for [[/r 1d3 #Hours of light]] hours, but lose their hypnotic effect. It attacks with a horny, beaked mouth.

Terrain: Cavern; Desert (cold), Mountain

Treant.biography:
A treant is an intelligent, 18-foot-tall creature resembling a tree, with recognizable facial features. It has two large branches that act as arms with hands and walks on root-like feet. Treants are guardians of the forest and plant life, and they are friendly with other intelligent forest creatures like actaeons, centaurs, and dryads. They speak a slow and complex language and are distrustful of anyone who uses fire.

Treants blend in almost perfectly with normal trees, and all encounters with them begin at a distance of 30 yards or less. They surprise on a roll of 1-3 on a d6 due to their camouflage. Although normal weapons can harm them, blunt weapons (such as maces) only inflict 1 point of damage per hit, plus any magic and strength bonuses.

In combat, a treant attacks with two powerful branch strikes. Additionally, it has the ability to animate nearby trees, commanding up to two within a 60-foot radius to move and fight as treants with a movement rate of 30' per turn. The treant can choose new trees to animate each round, allowing it to adapt to the flow of battle.

Terrain: Woods

Triceratops.biography:
The Triceratops is an armored, herbivorous dinosaur, akin to an elephant in temperament. This creature, measuring about 30 feet in length and weighing between 10 to 12 tons, features a distinctive collar-like armor plate around its neck for protection. Its offensive capabilities include a short horn on its snout and two long horns above its eyes, making it a formidable opponent even against large carnivorous dinosaurs.

Despite being a herbivore, the Triceratops is known for its aggressive behavior, often charging into combat. It can deliver a double-damage charge attack if it's the first attack or if it has moved 20 yards or more away from its enemy before attacking again.

Terrain: Open (prehistoric)
Load: Can carry 10,000 cn at full speed, 20,000 cn at half speed.

Troglodyte.biography:
Troglodytes are intelligent, reptilian humanoids with short tails, long legs, and spiny combs on their heads and arms. They walk upright, similar to humans, and are adept at using their hands. Troglodytes are known for their hostility towards most other species. They possess a chameleon-like ability to change color, blending into their surroundings like rock walls, which allows them to surprise opponents (on a roll of 1-4 on 1d6). Additionally, they secrete an oil that gives off a foul stench, which can nauseate humans and demihumans unless a saving throw vs. poison is successful. Nauseated characters suffer a -2 penalty to attack rolls when fighting troglodytes in melee.

Some troglodytes can be spellcasters; see the section on 'Monster Spellcasters' for more details.

Terrain: Cavern, Ruins

Troll.biography:
Trolls are tall, thin humanoids standing 8 feet tall. They possess sharp teeth, ferocious features, and mottled rubber-like skin. Trolls are carnivorous, preferring human and humanlike prey. They are found in a variety of terrains, often living in the ruins of their victims' dwellings.

Trolls are extremely dangerous due to their regenerative powers. Three rounds after being damaged, a troll will start to heal itself at a rate of 3 hit points per round. Even severed limbs can crawl back to the troll’s body to rejoin. However, trolls cannot regenerate damage from fire or acid, and when attacked by these means, their morale drops to 8.

Regeneration: Trolls heal 3 HP per round starting 3 rounds after damage. Severed limbs rejoin the body unless destroyed by fire or acid.

Terrain: Cavern, Wilderness (any).

Undine*.biography:
The undine is an intelligent creature composed entirely of water, rare even in the Elemental Plane of Water, its home, and seldom encountered on the Prime Plane. Though chaotic, undines possess good intentions and despise evil. On their home plane, they typically take the form of a featureless, transparent snake but can change shape at will, often using multiple tentacles to manipulate objects. They can swim at an accelerated rate, forming a revolving coil for short bursts.

Undines are immune to poison, normal weapons, all 1st and 2nd level spells, and fire-based attacks. They can detect invisible creatures at will and use spells like detect magic, web, dispel magic, ice storm/wall, and fire to ice three times per day, as if cast by a 9th level magic-user. Their web, made of ice strands, functions like a normal web but melts harmlessly when exposed to flame.

An undine's attack involves shaping water into a 'fist' for melee combat or coiling around an opponent for constriction damage. On the Prime Plane, they resemble water elementals, becoming invisible in water and regenerating damage, but they take damage from drying out when not submerged. Unlike elementals, they are not limited by protection from evil or proximity to water.

Undines have natural enemies in the hydrax and hordes, and they are wary of air-type creatures and attacks.

Terrain: Plane of Water

Unicorn.biography:
A unicorn resembles a slender, graceful horse with a long, spiraling horn protruding from its forehead. Known for their beauty, no one has ever witnessed an unattractive unicorn. Though they are shy and elusive, they become fierce defenders when threatened. Only a pure maiden can speak to or ride a unicorn, forming a bond with these mystical creatures.

Unicorns possess the magical ability to teleport themselves (and a rider) up to 360' once per day. If they have a rider, their morale improves to 9. These rare beings prefer to live deep within forests, far from sentient creatures. Unicorn horns are highly prized by evil wizards for use in alchemical potions and magical research, making them targets for hunters.

Terrain: Woods.
Load: 2,000 cn at full speed; 4,000 cn at half speed.

Vampire* (Human).biography:
Vampires rank among the most dreaded undead in the game. They dwell in forsaken places like ruins, tombs, and crypts, emerging under the cover of night to hunt humans. These creatures are known for their ability to transform shape, their supernatural resilience, and their capacity to drain life force.

Vampires are immune to spells like sleep, charm, and hold, and can only be harmed by magical weaponry. They possess the chilling power to transform into a human guise, a dire wolf, a giant bat, or a cloud of gas, with each transformation requiring one round. No matter the form, vampires regenerate at a rate of 3 hit points per round once injured. Should their hit points reach zero, they turn into gas and escape to their coffins to heal.

In human form, a vampire can attack with a deadly touch that not only deals damage but also drains double the life energy of the victim, or use its gaze to enthrall opponents. The gaze requires a saving throw vs. spells at a -2 penalty to resist the charm. Additionally, a vampire can call forth allies within 300 feet (or 300 yards outdoors) including swarms of rats, bats, or packs of dire wolves.

A human killed by a vampire rises as one themselves three days later, under the control of their creator. Vampires can also be spellcasters.

Weaknesses: They are repelled by strongly presented holy symbols, cannot approach garlic without making a saving throw vs. poison, and are unable to cross running water except at bridges or within their coffins. During daylight, they must rest in their coffins or lose hit points, which won't regenerate until they've rested for a full day. Vampires cast no reflection, thus they shun mirrors. They can be destroyed by a wooden stake through the heart or by prolonged exposure to running water. In sunlight, they must save vs. death ray each round or disintegrate; however, a continual light spell does not have this effect. If all their resting places are blessed or destroyed, they weaken, losing hit points until they perish.

Terrain: Ruins, Tombs, Crypts

War Horse.biography:
Horses are four-legged equines already familiar to players. They're herbivores: they run wild in the plains and can be tamed as riding beasts.

This type of horse is bred for its warlike temperament and strength. Unlike other horses, it is trained to charge. When charging, its rider can do double damage when using a lance. The horse cannot fight while charging and cannot move at charging speed for more than three rounds at a time.

Terrain: Open.

Weasel, Giant.biography:
A giant weasel is an 8- to 9-foot-long predator with richly colored fur, typically white, gold, or brown. These quick and vicious hunters either stalk prey alone or in small groups. They possess infravision up to 30 feet and can track creatures by scent, prioritizing wounded prey.

Once a giant weasel bites, it latches onto its victim and begins draining blood, automatically dealing 2d4 points of damage each round until the prey is dead or the weasel is slain. These creatures make their homes in underground tunnels and often ambush their targets from below.

Terrain: Cavern, Ruins, Woods.

Load: 2,000 cn at full speed; 4,000 cn at half speed.

Whale, Great.biography:
This huge whale is about 60' long on average. It preys on the most feared denizens of the deep (such as the giant octopus and giant squid). Man-sized or smaller creatures will be swallowed whole on a die roll that is 4 or more than the score needed to hit. A swallowed creature will take [[/r 3d6 #Points of acid damage]] points of damage per round. Great whales will sometimes (10%) attack ships, attempting to ram. The monster whale does [[/r 6d6 #Hull points of damage]] points of hull damage in a successful ram.

Extremely rare great whales might grow to double or triple this size, with a corresponding increase in Hit Dice and damage. There are rumors of monster whales large enough to swallow an entire harbor of ships!

Terrain: Ocean

Wight*.biography:
A wight is an undead spirit that inhabits the body of a deceased human or demihuman. It resembles its living form but appears bone-white and emaciated, with hollow, lifeless eyes. Its burial garments are typically tattered and filthy.

Wights can only be harmed by silvered or magical weapons. They are greatly feared due to their ability to drain life energy with each strike. Each successful hit drains one level of experience or Hit Die from the victim. Any individual completely drained of life energy by a wight will transform into a wight themselves within 1d4 days and will be under the control of the slayer.

Terrain: Barren Lands, Ruins.

Wraith*.biography:
A wraith is a spectral undead entity, a pale and almost transparent mist-like figure. It is the spirit of the selfish dead, clinging to the Prime Plane by draining life from the living.

Defenses: A wraith is immune to sleep, charm, and hold spells. It can only be harmed by silver or magical weapons, but silver weapons inflict half damage.

Energy Drain: The touch of a wraith drains 1 experience level from its victim and also deals 1d6 damage. Any creature slain by a wraith will rise as a new wraith in one day, under the control of its slayer.

Terrain: Barren Lands, Ruins.

6UXVybFEzFEZIdRW.description: As an incorporeal undead, a wraith is highly resistant to attacks. It can only be harmed by silver or magical weapons, and silver weapons only deal half damage.
6UXVybFEzFEZIdRW.name: Wraith Form

FhUyTQ3uE0xghzUy.description: The saving throw for Spells or Magic Staff includes resistance against magical effects cast by rods, staves, wands, or through spells. A successful save, rolled on a d20, often reduces or negates the spell's effects entirely. This saving throw is applicable to numerous magical attacks, such as charm spells, fireballs, or paralysis effects, and covers damage, control, or debilitating conditions caused by magical devices or spellcasters. The target number for success is based on the character's class and level.
FhUyTQ3uE0xghzUy.name: Spells or Magic Staff

IgzOFhriYmyxUR1Z.description: The touch deals 1d6 damage and drains 1 experience level from its victim. A saving throw vs. death ray negates the level drain.
IgzOFhriYmyxUR1Z.name: Touch (Energy Drain)

aiGAy8rInd4uTP0B.description: The saving throw against "Stone or Paralysis" protects a character from attacks or effects that could freeze them in place (paralysis) or turn them into stone. If the saving throw is failed, the character becomes immobilized or petrified, depending on the effect. Paralysis leaves a character aware but unable to act, while petrification turns the character and their carried equipment into a stone statue. The duration or permanence of these effects is specified by the source, and successful saving throws avoid them entirely​​​.
aiGAy8rInd4uTP0B.name: Turn to Stone or Paralysis

bYmzdhQhcbVbWfZt.description: The Magic Wand saving throw is used to avoid the effects of attacks or abilities activated through magical wands, such as paralysis rays or damage-dealing beams. A successful save, rolled on a d20, indicates that the character avoids or mitigates the harmful effects. The target number to save is determined by the character's class and level, as found on the saving throw table​​.
bYmzdhQhcbVbWfZt.name: Magic Wand

jgH9IIbRLqST4mXc.description: The Death Ray or Poison saving throw is a roll made by a character to resist deadly effects like instant death or paralysis from poisons, spells, or traps. The player rolls a d20 and compares it to their class- and level-specific target number on the saving throw table; success means avoiding or mitigating the harm. A failed roll often results in death (for poison) or other severe consequences, though optional rules may instead inflict substantial damage​​​.
jgH9IIbRLqST4mXc.name: Death Ray or Poison

pcdBLWKxB0T2tZST.description: The Flight ability allows a character or creature to move through the air, either through magical means or natural capabilities, such as having wings. This ability enables the user to ascend, descend, and navigate in three-dimensional space, often at a specified speed. Flight may come with limitations, such as a maximum altitude, duration, or specific conditions for its use.
pcdBLWKxB0T2tZST.name: Flight

y9P7UWZTxrpwf1dH.description: The saving throw against Breath Weapons is used to resist or mitigate the effects of a wide range of powerful exhaled attacks, not limited to dragons. This includes attacks like a dragon’s fiery or icy breath, a gorgon's petrifying breath, or a chimera's elemental breath. Each creature’s breath weapon has specific effects, such as damage, paralysis, or petrification. A successful saving throw generally halves the damage or avoids the secondary effect (such as paralysis or petrification), while failure applies the full consequences. Wyvern.biography:
A wyvern is a fearsome creature that resembles a two-legged dragon, complete with a long, spiked tail. Unlike true dragons, wyverns lack forelimbs and are usually seen in hues of brown, red, or rust-red. They are commonly found in mountainous regions or dense forests, though they can be encountered in many environments.

In battle, wyverns use both their bite and their venomous stinger. The creature arches its tail over its head to sting enemies in front of it, and those struck by the stinger must make a saving throw vs. poison or die. Wyverns are carnivorous, often preying on large herd animals such as elk and moose, but they will not hesitate to attack humans if encountered.

Terrain: Mountain, Woods.
Load: 3,500 cn at full speed; 7,000 cn at half speed.
Barding Multiplier: x 3.

Yellow Mold.biography:
Yellow Mold is a dangerous fungus that covers an area of up to 100 square feet. It does not move, but reacts aggressively when disturbed.

It is immune to all damage except fire, which deals normal damage. Torches inflict 1d4 damage per round when used to burn it. Yellow mold can dissolve wood and leather in an instant, but it cannot harm stone or metal.

When touched, there is a 50% chance that it releases a cloud of spores in a 10' x 10' x 10' area. Anyone caught in the spores takes 1d6 damage and must make a saving throw vs. death ray or suffocate within six rounds.

Terrain: Cavern, Ruins.

Zombie.biography:
Zombies are mindless, undead humans or demihumans reanimated through evil magic. They are commonly used by malevolent rulers and dark spellcasters as disposable soldiers or laborers. Their vacant expressions and shuffling gait make them eerie guardians of crypts and ancient ruins.

Unlike living creatures, zombies are immune to sleep and charm spells. They can be turned by clerics but otherwise follow their commands without question. While they can be harmed by normal weapons, their sluggish reflexes make them always lose initiative in combat.

Zombies are often stationed to guard treasures, standing eerily silent until disturbed. When encountered in lairs, they may be found in large numbers, standing vigil over long-forgotten tombs.

Terrain: Ruins.
